PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we commenced the fourth day of debate in the Senate of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and the three associated Bills. The end of the second reading and Committee debate is not yet in sight. So by the time we have finished we will have devoted more time to these Bills than to any others in the memory of most honourable senators. The Opposition has contributed importantly to the length of the debate and we make no apology for that. With these Bills we are considering the future of this nation: Our freedoms, our rights, our traditions, our values - the whole structure of our society. The Liberal and National parties stand for the freedom of the individual, for his or her basic rights to privacy, to own property, to the protection of the law, to the preservation of the role of the democratically elected representatives of the people and to the protection and the nurturing of the family as the basic unit of our society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is because the Liberal and National parties place these and similar freedoms, rights and values at the pinnacle of importance for our nation and for all Australians that we are bitterly opposed to the Bills before the Senate. These Bills, the details of which have been outlined by many previous speakers and which will be further outlined at the Committee stage of the debate, do not strengthen, preserve or guarantee in any way the rights of individual Australians. On the contrary, they pose many threats to our Australian society which already has one of the most liberal societies on earth and in which our rights and freedoms are already enshrined in our system of law, of government and, most important of all, in our value systems. The human rights legislation contained in the Bills before the Senate does not strengthen our freedoms. Rather it devalues many of the freedoms we already enjoy. Fortunately, the Australian people are awake to this. Members and senators in this Parliament have received more protest letters on these Bills than on virtually any other subject in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them have not known what they have been writing about.

—Significantly, Senator Haines, these protests are coming from the widest imaginable cross section of the people. They come from people from all walks of life and from virtually all parts of the political spectrum, with the exception perhaps of the powerful socialist left of the Australian Labor Party. The people are telling us loud and clear that they do not want this legislation and that they fear it, and well they might. I have received several hundred letters of opposition to the proposals. I have received only one letter of support and that was from the socialist left dominated Coburg City Council which is in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Liberal and National parties are, as I said earlier, violently opposed to the Hawke Government's proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people should be aware that the only way that the socialist Government will get this legislation through will be with the support of the Australian Democrats. What will the Australian Democrats do? We do not know what the Democrats will do. They have not told us yet. They do not like the present Bill because they regard it as too weak, despite the fact that it takes away rather than strengthens our basic rights. Although they regard the Bill as weak they may still vote with the Government and against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians. If the Government is prepared to make the Bills even more horrific, more draconian, more Orwellian than they already are, the Australian Democrats will certainly support the legislation. So much for the role of the Australian Democrats in Australian life. With 7 per cent of the vote of the Australian people, a measly 7 per cent, the Australian Democrats hold the freedom of 16 million Australians in their hands. If the Democrats support the Government on this legislation the Australian people will confine the Democrats to the dust-bowl of political history at the first available opportunity, and rightly so. But by then the damage could be done. Nothing could be less democratic-and Senator Haines's performance in the chamber today demonstrates her views of democracy-than that a minor splinter party with no representation whatsoever in the House of Representatives where governments are formed can, nevertheless, be the final arbiter in determining the freedoms and rights of every Australian man, woman and child.

This package of so-called human rights legislation-a misnomer, if ever there was one-is in fact an inept, confused and ambiguous ragbag of so-called rights. It is incomplete, contradictory and dangerous. It is dangerous because it presents a highly selective package of rights and pretends that those rights are the totality of those that we require in contemporary Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are what we have already.
—That is correct. As the Returned Services League of Australia said in a submission dated 30 November 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: To define rights in an Act of Parliament is in itself a limitation of rights. If a right is not included does that right exist?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it does, you silly man.
—Well, if it does, why not put it in the Bill of Rights? The RSL continues:

SPEECH.PARA: How can the few people who work to draft the list of rights include all rights and freedoms? How can all rights and freedoms be covered within the limitations of the words of our language? . . . Governments should not legislate to tell free people what they can do. Rather they should legislate to tell free people what they cannot do and then let them get on with living their lives.
So says the RSL's submission and that is a statement with which I fully agree.

We are all aware of the fact that there are societies which have very wide freedoms and rights enshrined in legislation. In many countries these rights exist merely for show; they are found in some of the worst totalitarian societies on earth. The classic example is the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union purports to establish very wide rights for its citizens, yet the reality is very different. The Soviet Union is the greatest abuser of civil liberties. It is obvious that the mere stating of rights is no protection. True human rights depend upon something much more profound and solid. They depend upon the tradition of a thousand years of habeas corpus and the respect for the Magna Carta; they depend upon rights established centuries ago; and they depend upon that great body of law known as the common law. I know that comments have been made during this debate that the common law does not sufficiently protect the rights of individuals in our society. I do not necessarily dispute that and I do not say that the common law is the be all and end all of human rights. However, it is certainly a major basis of the rights that we have and are so proud of-rightly so-in this nation. As Sir Robert Menzies once said:
To live in a common law country is, in itself, the very best guarantee of the rights of the individual.

It is this tradition of respect for property, trial by jury and vigilance against abuse of the royal prerogative which has enabled Australians to enjoy the privileges that few other nations on earth have. The irony of the Hawke Government's proposals is that they extol many of the rights already possessed by Australians, yet the powers to be given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will violate many of the rights now available.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not.
—They will, Senator Haines.
—But they are exactly the same as-
—I seek your protection, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Senator Haines will refrain from interjecting.

—One of the major dangers in this Bill is that it excludes many rights. There is no guarantee of the right to non-State education. Private property rights are not protected. Why are private property rights not protected? They are not protected because when the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, from which the Government's proposals flow, was being drafted that great protector of human rights, the Soviet Union, opposes its inclusion. There is no protection of the right to engage in a lawful trade, profession or occupation. Rights such as these could be interpreted as some limitation perhaps on the octopus-like expansion of trade union power in Australia. Of course, expanding trade union power in Australia is exactly what this Simon Crean, Bill Kelty and Bob Hawke Government is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: As Professor Mark Cooray pointed out recently, the exclusion of proprietary rights from the Bill is not an oversight. It is a deliberate omission from a document designed to promote the socialist agenda in this country. Again, as Cooray has pointed out, it is often overlooked that the right to private property undergirds all other rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have never had it in this country.

—Senator Haines has had her go. I ask her to let me have mine. In particular, political rights lose much of their effectiveness when the right to private property is denied. There are other serious and deliberate omissions from the proposed Bill. For example, in clause 9 (3) of the Bill of Rights Bill companies and other incorporated associations are specifically excluded. The implication of that restriction for the freedom of expression and the rights of the Press is immense. In this modern age it is almost impossible to establish a communications outlet without forming a company.
—Without a great deal of money.

—But without establishing a company. Companies are excluded from this Bill. The public should be aware that this Hawke Labour Government refused to accept an Opposition amendment to grant companies and other incorporated associations similar rights when these Bills were debated in another place at the end of 1985. It is a fundamental right in a free society for persons to associate in the corporate form in order to enjoy and exercise their rights. The denial of freedom of expression and of the Press is a dangerous curtailment of that freedom. It is preposterous to believe that the Hawke Government can summarise the rights and freedoms of Australians in one document.

SPEECH.PARA: The rights that this Bill purports to give us really are the passing preoccupations of an unrepresentative minority. Even the great Bill of Rights of the United States has serious flaws. It is a document that was meant to protect the rights of early Americans against the intrusion of the Government. Its major impetus was memories from the revolutionary days of armed struggle with the British. One of the rights enshrined in the Bill was the right to bear arms.

Such a right is quite out of tune with the needs of a modern, highly urbanised society. In fact, it is the major reason for the appallingly high homicide rate in some cities in the United States. The right to bear arms might have been arguable in the 1790s but it is a highly dubious proposition in the 1980s.

Similarly, our proposed Bill of Rights has many transitory rights which may well be considered irrelevant in future years. Of course, the Bill can be altered in future years by the government of the day to ensure that it is relevant. But why legislate in the first place if such rights can be taken away in the future? By listing our so-called rights the Government in fact is curtailing those rights. If this legislation is passed the Hawke Government will forever stand condemned for taking rights from Australian citizens. The legislation presages a massive and unprecedented opportunity for and determination to intervene federally in State affairs and for a major centralist shift in the balance of power between the Federal Government and the States.

I think it is a not unreasonable proposition to assert that one of the basic reasons for this legislation and why the Australian Democrats are likely to support it, particularly if it is strengthened, is that this legislation is about a get Queensland campaign and about a get other States campaign-a campaign to get the States which do not fall into line with the views of the Federal socialist Labor Government. If we are talking about problems in the States, let us look at what is happening in my own State of Victoria at this very moment. The editorial in yesterday's Melbourne Age states:

Labor's Socialist Left is not averse to electoral engineering in contempt of democratic principles. Its malign influence was behind a resolution of the party's state conference last October which, if implemented, would eliminate minority parties . . . from the Legislative Council and disenfranchise more than 200,000 Victorians.

That is what is going on in States such as mine. That is the type of thing which needs to be looked at very seriously. This Bill could do fundamental damage to the Federal structure of government. The expanded Human Rights Commission will have the power to inquire into any act or practice not only of the Commonwealth but also of a State or authority of a State. The Commission will have the power to investigate acts of a State Parliament. Additionally, it will have the power to conduct so-called education campaigns to correct perceived abuses.

That brings me to the final concern which I wish to express at this second reading stage about the Government's proposals. I refer to the fact that the Bill of Rights would be administered by the expanded Human Rights Commission. I, along with many others, have been concerned for some time now about the activities of the Human Rights Commission. I do not deny that some form of advisory body may be advisable in the area of human rights in Australia, although I believe even that proposition needs much more searching analysis. The Government proposes to expand the existing Human Rights Commission-a Commission set up with bipartisan approval by the Fraser Government in the late 1970's-into a much larger bureaucratic organisation with considerably expanded powers.

I believe that several of the recent activities of the existing Commission raise very serious questions about the desirability of giving it expanded and powerful powers over the lives of every Australian. I will give a few examples to illustrate my concern. They include the stupid and wrongful exclusion last year of the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown, from the Human Rights Commission's offices; its ridiculous proposal for some form of racial taunts legislation; its absurd claims of torture of demonstrators at Pine Gap; its suppressing of a report on affirmative action which it commissioned from Dr Gabriel Moens because it did not like the results of that report; and, perhaps most serious of all, its infiltration of Australia's education system from the infants school level to the secondary school level with human rights literature and material which it is no exaggeration to describe as subversive and deliberately undermining of many of the basic values of Australian society.

I will give the Senate a few examples of this kind of literature. Last year the Human Rights Commission published and distributed what it calls a teaching kit for general use and distribution throughout schools in Australia. The kit comprises a number of pamphlets and a textbook of more than 150 pages entitled Teaching For Human Rights. The book was written by the Commission's Assistant Director for Education, Dr Ralph Pettman. The book is divided into some 10 chapters. One of these chapters is entitled `Life'. The first two paragraphs of that chapter talk about the horrors of World War II and of genocide-a very acceptable introduction. However, the third paragraph states:

There has been mass assassination, too, by more covert and indirect means. The construction of a capitalist world economy, predicated upon dishonesty and greed, has slaughtered uncounted millions the world over through the exploitation and the mis-development of global resources. The United States and the other erstwhile `free market' democracies have much to answer for in this regard.

Marx and Lenin could not have done a better job of drafting more hard core communist propaganda than that. Is the Human Rights Commission saying that every person engaged in private enterprise and the whole private enterprise system is corrupt and that the system is based on greed and dishonesty? What does that say of the small business person in Australia and his desire and the desire of every Australian to strive as individuals to achieve, to succeed and to be rewarded for that?

TALK.START.PARA: —How much are they paying the teachers to disseminate this rubbish?
—I shall come to that in a second, it is a very interesting point. Another chapter in the book is called `The Family'. The third paragraph of that chapter says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a liberal, capitalist, multicultural democracy, with social welfare proclivities, a highly stratified class structure, a value system that is secular, racist, sexist, and materialistic-the family reflects and promotes this fact.
I do not believe that the values of the average Australian family are racist, sexist and materialistic. I do not believe that too many other Australians would believe that either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quote it in context.

—I will debate that with the honourable senator at any time. It is not a fact either that Australia has a highly stratified class structure. It may be that our society is capitalistic though that too is an overstatement in a mixed economy, but it is certainly not the type of capitalism that is described elsewhere in Dr Pettman's book, where he writes of capitalism:

SPEECH.PARA: The rich want to keep what they have. They run the governments and the armies-
That is possibly true nowadays under the present Government we have in power.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new rich; the ACTU.
—Yes, the new rich. Dr Pettman continues:

SPEECH.PARA: They see change as needed only where it means preserving the kind of life they are used to. As conditions get worse the poor overwhelm all but a few pockets of rich resistance.
The Commission, in the same document, rejects the notion that education should be neutral and states:

Teachers adopting teaching human rights should be aware that the program makes no pretence at all at being value-free. It is value-heavy, has explicit ideological commitments, and eschews the notion of neutrality in education.

It certainly does, and it does so in a way that is repugnant and which virtually all freedom-loving Australians would find totally unacceptable and subversive with regard to everything for which this nation so proudly stands. Not only is this subversive material being distributed to schools but also it is being actively promoted to teachers through advertisements in major newspapers. I am sorry I did not seek the Minister's permission beforehand, but I seek leave--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will exercise greater tolerance than you would.

—I seek leave to table the advertisement which appeared on 8 February in most of the major daily newspapers. In summary, it calls on teachers to participate in using the teaching kit to explore human rights issues with the infant, lower primary, upper primary and secondary classes. The advertisement offers grants, which, I understand, are from $500 to $1,000, to teachers who participate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contact point within the Human Rights Commission is listed in this advertisement as none other than Dr Pettman, the author of the book from which I have been quoting. These should be matters of the gravest concern to all Australians. Large amounts of taxpayers' funds are being used to promote values and concepts that totally undermine Australia's basic socio-economic and cultural values. The Hawke Government stands condemned for allowing such a subversive activity to occur in one of its own agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: In my final comments on the Government's human rights proposals, I can do no better than to quote from last week's editorial in one of the major local newspapers in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The paper is the Brunswick Sentinel. The editorial states:
The Australian people have fought two world wars and have been involved in others to preserve the freedoms we hold sacred.
Now these freedoms are under threat from the Federal Government, the very body entrusted with their protection.
If the proposed Bill of rights is passed through the Senate, democracy in Australia will be gravely imperilled.
The editorial goes on to say later on:

If we allow this Bill to pass we will be rejecting the constitutional legacy we inherited from England, and start down the path taken by the Soviet Union and others who have comprehensive Bills of Rights, but permit bureaucracies to define and limit, as they see fit, the rights and freedoms declared in those bills.

The Prime Minister, his Government and the Australian Democrats would do well to heed this warning. To do otherwise would be to condemn this nation and its people to a progressive erosion of those individual freedoms and rights which are the hallmark and the pride of our nation and the envy of most of the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President-(Quorum formed) I rise to support the Australian Bill of Rights proposal which is before the chamber not because its passage into law in Australia would mark a revolutionary change in throwing off some oppressive and tyrannical regime and the inauguration of a new social era, in the sense of the Bill of Rights in the United States of America, but simply because I believe it is very useful in a democracy to put as many hurdles as possible between government and the people's enjoyment of their freedoms.

SPEECH.PARA: As I see it, the proposed Bill of Rights will do no more than reinforce, reaffirm and say to the Australian people: `These are values which on the whole at the moment throughout Australia we greatly prize and value'. It is not enough to leave those values rather vague. It would be a good idea, would it not, to set them down in a form which would act as a bench-mark and guideline for the electors and citizens of Australia so that they can judge our performance as governments and as parliamentarians?

The fact is-it must not be forgotten and it needs to be reasserted-that this Bill will have an impact and effect only on governments. It is directed, in the traditional style of Bills of Rights, to curbing those government powers and the exercise of such powers which would modify and have a deleterious effect on the rights and freedoms which ordinary citizens wish to enjoy. It is not directed against ordinary people or even those who associate in companies; it will have an impact only against governments.

It would be very good for Australian society to set down in a reasonably concise form those rights and freedoms which we value and, on the whole, want to see continued. Why not reassert and reaffirm them in this form? The fact is that a very vicious, misleading and mischievous campaign is being waged around Australia at the moment which is actually creating real fear amongst large segments of otherwise good, sensible and tolerant people. I have received letters which have talked about civil war, blood on the streets and destruction of the family. These are matters which I will address during the latter part of my remarks. But what I am trying to establish first of all very clearly is that no revolutionary claims are made about this Bill. It is a reaffirmation, a reassertion, a listing, so that it can be used by the electors and citizens as a guide to enable them to assess the performance of governments and parliaments in relation to these matters.

What must be asserted from the outset is that we will not be misled by those on the conservative side of politics who keep saying that the Government is intending to confer these rights on people. There is no sense in which it is claimed that this is a bestowal of rights by government on the people. That would be contrary to what is being attempted in this legislation and, indeed, by most Bills of Rights around the world. One is saying that these rights are inherent in the dignity of human beings and in their capacity and status as citizens in a free society. It is up to government to recognise that fact, to draw limits and restrain itself from imposing on those rights which inhere in the people of a democracy such as Australia. So this Bill is no more than a declaration of some of the rights which are so important in preserving the character of our democratic society.

Both the words `declaration' and `some' in that sentence are important. It is a declaration, as I say, an affirmation and a recognition. It is not a conferring, it is not a granting by government. It is a recognition of some of the rights. It does not pretend to be exhaustive. It does not prevent either the common law judges or the parliaments of Australia, whether at the Federal, State or territorial level, or even at local government level, from conferring additional rights. It is supplementary. It builds on a tradition already established by the combination of common law and parliamentary action. It supplements, complements and reaffirms, but it in no sense displaces any of our existing rights. It leaves plenty of room for the recognition by the courts and parliament of rights that are not listed in this Bill. To affirm that point, I will read article 2 which is headed `Effect of Bill of Rights on existing rights and freedoms'.

A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by reason only that the right of freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights.

I believe there could be no more clear statement by this Parliament that in no sense does this Bill, in its failure to list particular rights, either extinguish them or displace them if they presently exist, nor does it prevent their later recognition by the courts or by way of parliamentary action.

It is very important nevertheless, as I say, to recognise that the common law needs some supplementing. I think it has been pointed out in other speeches that the common law-certainly this was the finding of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which looked at the broad question of the Bill of Rights on behalf of the Senate in the latter part of last year, which Committee, by the way, took public evidence and had the benefit of many written submissions-was defective and needed supplementing and, in fact, historically had not played the great role which is sometimes ascribed to it in the mythology of the conservatives. I do not say that the common law is not a precious part of our inheritance. In fact, in many ways, for example in its insistence on natural justice, in recent years it has shown a certain robust creativity in its application which is to be welcomed. But the fact is that the common law did not give us the right to vote-as most people in Western Australia, Tasmania and the division of Scullin did last weekend-without discrimination on the ground of sex. The common law never recognised what we would surely term in Australia the great and precious right of religious freedom or freedom of conscience. I have in my hand a decision of the South Australian Supreme Court as recently as 6 July 1984 in which the Full Court of the Supreme Court in the case of Grace Bible Church Inc. against Reedman stated quite clearly that the common law does not guarantee freedom of religion.

I think it is very important that we try to reaffirm in this Bill of Rights our belief that governments should be judged and brought under the criterion of a respect for that particularly precious freedom. People will know the problems that Jehovah's Witnesses experienced in the Second World War and which many good Christian young men experienced during the Vietnam War when their conscientious objections were not able to gain them exemption from military service which might have involved killing another human being, even though they had a conscientious objection to that conflict. In those situations one would know that it would be very useful to have as a criterion against which this Federal Parliament could be judged, articles 8 and 9, which read:
Every person has the right to freedom of thought and conscience, including the right to hold opinions without interference.

Every person has the right to have or adopt a religion or belief of that person's choice without coercion of any kind, and to manifest that religion or belief in worship, observance, practice and teaching, whether individually or in community with others and whether in public or in private.

I would have thought that those articles were extremely valuable. I say to those members of the various churches who have been manipulated in the campaign that is gathering pace at the moment to reflect on the possible worth of those provisions.

One of the arguments that is heard-quite often it is put in letters which are based on an anonymous pamphlet which has been circulated around the country-is that this Bill of Rights is based on some sort of international covenant which emanates from some odious ogre of international dimensions and appeals only to Warsaw Pact countries. This has been a constant theme of letters that I have received. The fact is that the mother of the common law tradition, the United Kingdom, has ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The fact is that democracies such as Canada, New Zealand, Japan, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Austria, Norway, Denmark, Spain and Sweden have all made themselves parties to the International Covenant. It is very largely reflected in the international European arrangements to which, of course, the United Kingdom has acceded. To paint this as a sort of communist conspiracy that appeals only to Warsaw Pact countries, as my short reading of the list of countries demonstrates, is completely false and misleading. In any case, if those countries have acceded to the International Covenant and have not observed it, I fail to see how that is an argument for Australia not observing and adhering to its articles as scrupulously as possible. The fact that some countries act in a hypocritical fashion is certainly no reason for us not to adopt this Bill in the form that is before the Senate today.

It would be hard to say that the basis of the Bill, the International Covenant, is part of a general conspiracy against freedom-loving democracies when one knows the history of Australia's participation in it. The Australian Labor Party Government in the 1940s was involved in its drafting. I presume that Dr Evatt played a large part in that process. But the fact is that the then Liberal and Country Party Government under Mr Harold Holt in 1966 directed the Australian delegation to the United Nations to show our desire for it to be adopted and that it be opened for signature. It was signed in 1972 by the ALP Government under Mr Whitlam and ratified in 1980 by Mr Malcolm Fraser on behalf of the Liberal National Party Government. One could hardly say that Mr Fraser was in the vanguard of the socialist revolution. Nevertheless, the fact is that the constant claim is made that it is part of a general conspiracy to undermine our Western democratic values. I think I have demonstrated in a short time that the hysteria engendered on that point is quite ill-founded.

Then, of course, one comes to the claim that this is really designed to undermine the federal system. It has to be said very clearly that the Bill in its form before the chamber has an immediate impact only on Commonwealth laws and administrative activities. It is only directed in a way which would enable a court to strike down an inconsistent Commonwealth law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't mislead the people. Come on, Michael-you are more honest than that.

—I do not need a lesson in honesty from the honourable senator. In relation to the States, the question of the operation of the Bill is such that it simply enables the Human Rights Commission-through a very complex process of negotiation and consultation between the relevant State Minister-to produce a report for the consideration of the national parliament. There is nothing in the Bill which purports, as some versions have in previous years, to render invalid, null and void, of no effect whatsoever, State laws which are thought not to comply with any particular article of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I think it is very important that that particular point be reaffirmed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time given to me I will not dwell too much on that because there are some more outrageous attacks that I need to deal with. I suppose it is true to say that one of the legitimate fears of many in the community is that if we establish a Bill of Rights on a pattern which people vaguely associated with the United States Bill of Rights we may be importing into Australia some of the history of litigation and the role of the United States Supreme Court justices in relation to this particular Bill. It has to be said very clearly that the Government and, indeed, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs have set their face against incorporating any such Bill in the Constitution. Once that is done we hand over to a non-elected bench of justices a very final, absolute power in relation to the interpretation of the words of the Bill. That is not the intention. The intention is that, as with every piece of legislation passed by this Parliament, there be the usual relationship between the courts and the Parliament whereby we define and set down in the statute the general principles and the courts interpret them and apply those principles to particular actions, activities and events in the community. That role between the parts--

TALK.START.PARA: —But not by overtly political criteria.

—That would be a large argument too. The fact is that this Bill does put into the open, overtly as Senator Harradine quite rightly says, the sort of criteria which we would want the courts to use rather than much of the overt, unspoken of criteria which the courts can apply from time to time from the historical background of the judiciary and the personal prejudices of the judges. We want it to be out in the open, but the fact is that the Parliament remains in control of the situation. To say, as Senator Short did in his concluding remarks, that the Human Rights Commission will be defining and limiting our rights is quite incorrect. The Human Rights Commission will not be defining and limiting in our rights, that is a role which is confined to the Parliament in the first instance and the interpretation, which is where the limiting and further refinement in application to particular events and activities would occur, is a matter for the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to say against those who have been misled, I believe, by much of the propaganda in relation to the Human Rights Commission-I do not defend the Commission in respect of every facet of its activities and some of the publications which I have not had a chance to read in their total context, which have been mentioned would be causes for concern-that the Commission cannot enforce anything. It cannot insist that any government body change a particular course of conduct which is found to flout or not to be in harmony with the Bill of Rights. It commences an investigation, it carries out that investigation with certain powers and it needs quite strong powers because, as I have said, it will be acting against governments. Governments must not be allowed to say to their particular officials who need to come in to the situation: `You shall not attend before the Human Rights Commission'. They need to be brought before the Human Rights Commission and they need to answer certain questions because governments will always try to cloak and shield their employees and their officials against the ordinary people who are trying to assert their rights and freedoms in a particular case. The fact is that the Human Rights Commission is not given power to impose penalties. I have been at many a meeting where it has been feared that the Human Rights Commission could impose fines or throw people into prison. That is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, it can.

—Senator Lewis says it can; the fact is that it cannot. The Human Rights Commission has no such power to impose a penalty on people. That can be done only by the courts, and Senator Austin Lewis knows that to be the case. There have been more attacks than that on the Human Rights Bill. Some of them are quite outrageous. I suppose that one that has caused most concern amongst reasonably fair-minded people is the assertion that the Bill amounts to an assault against the family and family values.

SPEECH.PARA: I was at a public meeting in Devonport a couple of weeks ago on behalf of the Federal Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen. A Mr Jim Bowen, a Crown prosecutor from Melbourne, appeared on the platform and I believe misled the crowd by his constant refrain: `There is no protection in this Bill for the family'. One can only think it was deliberate on his part not to quote Article 13 or Article 14 of the Bill. But I am going to do that for the benefit of honourable senators present in the chamber and, more particularly, for those who are listening. Article 13 is headed: `Right to marry and to found a family'. These are important words which will govern the interpretation by the courts of the legislation of this Parliament from the date of the passage of this Bill. It states:
Recognising that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State-
(a) every man and woman of marriageable age has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex and to found a family; and
(b) no marriage shall be entered into without the free and full consent of the intending spouses.

There is nothing there, by the way, about homo- sexual marriages on which the people have also been misled. It is quite clear the Article refers to persons of the opposite sex having a right to marry but, more importantly, is that statement of principle which I believe is a very important one and excellent to see the Commonwealth Parliament adopting as a benchmark against which the electorate can judge it. I will repeat it. It states:
Recognising that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State-
Article 14 speaks about the rights of the child. It states:
Recognising that every child has the right to such measures of protection as are required by the child's age-
(a) every child is entitled to the fundamental rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights to the greatest extent compatible with the age of the individual child;
That is clear enough:
(b) every child shall be registered immediately after birth and shall have a name;
(c) every child has the right to acquire a nationality; and
Here is the important provision of that Article which has been so deliberately distorted:
(d) the liberty of parents and legal guardians to ensure the religious and moral education of their children in conformity with their own convictions is to be respected.

I believe that that particular provision is a bulwark of the family and its integrity against a totalitarian state which would take away children, try to indoctrinate them or try to foist its ideas of what those children should receive by way of religious and moral education. As I see it, the paramount consideration in that particular provision is the child and the first responsibility of the child rests with its parents. This provision recognises that the moral and legal education of children should conform to the convictions of the parents. The fact is that the state is thereby precluded from overriding that first responsibility, the primacy of parents in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I invite the honourable senator to look at it to see whether the argument I am putting forward is not open. There are some real fears about this. I acknowledge the fears, for example, about the indoctrination by teachers of students in their classrooms which could be founded on the Article which deals with freedom of expression. It would take a long time for me to rehearse all the legal arguments, but the fact is, firstly, that the right of a teacher to freedom of expression is not an absolute right. It is curtailed by Article 3 of the Bill of Rights, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

There is no doubt that a properly constituted education authority would be able, under that provision, to set down the curriculum to be taught in the school and to curtail any teacher who indulged in a program peculiar to that teacher from trying to indoctrinate children in a way which was not within the general curriculum set down by that lawfully constituted authority. If it still came to a battle between the authority and the parents-I have mentioned the article which relates to the moral and religious education of children being the primary responsibility of the parents and being given due observance-the courts, as always, would need to come to a balanced view in relation to these competing rights. The mere fact that the Parliament has specially set out the moral and religious education of children and has said that that is the primary duty and responsibility of parents which must be respected by the Parliament would give very clear guidance to the court as to the balance being tipped in favour of parental decision-making in that area. I do not see this Bill as an attack on the family. On the contrary, I see it as providing a very good foundation for the family in Australian society.

Another attack made on the Bill was in respect to the so-called stripping of necessary police power to deal with persons whom they want to arrest and take into custody. The fact is that the Articles are almost unexceptionable. For example, Article 22 reads:
Any person detained in custody has the right to remain silent and the right to consult with a lawyer.

I would have thought that was a very strong reinforcement of the common law position, which says that if a person is brought to criminal trial, that person does not have to open his mouth. It is up to the prosecution to bring forward the evidence - not from the lips of the person who is being held as a suspect, charged with an offence or put on trial. It is the golden thread that runs through the whole common law tradition, and one that this Senate has been at great pains to always insist on in its various committees by not allowing reversals of the onus of proof. The fact is that it is up to the prosecution to prove the guilt of the accused and nothing at all need fall from the lips of the person concerned. This Article takes that right to remain silent into the custody stage, as at the trial, and that is a very good affirmation of that common law position. Much has been made of Article 21, which states:

Any person who is arrested shall be informed at the time of the arrest of the reasons for the arrest, and shall be informed promptly and in detail of any charges in a language which that person understands.

It has been said that this will create chaos for a policeman who wants to arrest somebody in the middle of a demonstration and is met with a violent reaction. It needs to be clearly stated that the stages between arrest and charge are quite distinct. What is being asked for is that on arrest the reasons for the arrest be given in general terms. When charges are laid, they have to be spelt out, but that is a subsequent stage and there is no requirement that a person be charged in a language he understands at the time of arrest. We should keep in mind what is at stake. We are trying to create a society where the police of a totalitarian state do not come and knock on the door and take a person away without giving a reason, which is the case in the Warsaw Pact countries and in other countries with Right or Left dictatorships. We want a situation--

TALK.START.PARA: —But that's where they have a Bill of Rights.

—But they do not observe it. We are trying to create a situation where, in these democratic traditions of Australia, a person cannot be arrested without being told by the police or by a government official why that person's freedom is being restricted, and that seems to me to be a very good and reasonable thing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, it has been said that the provision that a person arrested or detained shall be brought promptly before a judge, magistrate or justice of the peace can impede the process of the police in procuring confessions. I take it to be a very fundamental matter that persons should be properly brought before judges or magistrates on their arrest and should not be allowed to languish in some sort of detention by the police. I think that most Australians would agree with that, as they would with Article 25, which states and reaffirms:
Any person charged with a criminal offence shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law.

It has also been said that, if police entered a situation with a warrant to look for stolen property-say, video cassette recorders-and found heroin on the premises, they could not impound the heroin. That is also a quite incorrect assertion. Provisions within the Bill make it very clear that where there is a compelling need for immediate action, as there would be in a situation where heroin would be disposed of if the police had to go and get another warrant, as provided for in Article 12 (2) (d), the police could seize the heroin they found.

I am taking up some of the examples which have been put to me in a campaign of letters, with which most honourable senators have been inundated. On the whole this has been a most mischievous and misleading campaign which has created a lot of heartburn and heartache amongst otherwise good, tolerant Australians who have been presented with a picture of a socialist ogre prowling this country, seeking what it may devour and particularly putting their families and the education of their children at the mercy of some doctrinaire, ideologically motivated, totalitarian state. Nothing could be further from the truth. This Bill of Rights is designed to re-assert those democratic values which we prize so highly. It is designed to put more hurdles in the way of governments which attempt to trample on or diminish those rights which we think are so important for all Australians, particularly those citizens who come into conflict with, or under the attention of, those in authority, with all the powers and possibilities of state power which can be exercised against them. I believe that the Bill of Rights deserves the support of the Senate as one of the elements, together with the common law and other parliamentary action, in constructing an edifice and a bastion of freedom for all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear again, as my friend and colleague Senator Janine Haines did so splendidly in her contribution to this debate, that the Australian Democrats have a very strong policy commitment to the enactment of a strong Bill of Rights which gives legislative recognition to basic human rights and freedoms and provides remedies for their enforcement. Given this commitment, I cannot express too strongly our extreme disappointment at the Government's failure to produce a Bill of Rights which matches those requirements. The Australian Bill of Rights Bill is weak and clearly the product of political cowardice. I never thought I would live to see the day when men such as Bob Hawke, Paul Keating, Gareth Evans and their kind would bow down to men such as Robin Gray and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. That is precisely what they have done. It is political cowardice of the worst kind.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no greater champion for a proper Bill of Rights in this country than Senator Gareth Evans, and I commend him for it. Yet we have this weak, disgusting attempt to satisfy the strong arm boys in the States. The Government has squibbed on a fight with miniature politicians such as Robin Gray and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Even Malcolm Fraser-and this chamber knows that I am not his greatest admirer-did not back away from a fight with Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen on the question of mining at Fraser Island. What happened to Malcolm Fraser over that fight? He not only won it, but he won it among the people. He took on a tyrant. He went out and explained what he was doing and he won the fight. I suggest to the Labor Government that when it knows it is in the right, when it knows that woodchipping in Tasmania is evil, fight it. It should put the political cost to one side because people generally have enough common sense and decency to understand what is right if it is explained to them in the proper way.

This Bill is weak because it does not apply to the States or to local government. It is in those two areas where massive infringements of civil and human rights occur. One has only to look at the kind of legislation that was proposed in Tasmania in respect of the searching of people suspected of carrying drugs and the legislation being enacted in Queensland to see the massive infringement of civil rights and human rights that is being perpetrated in those States.

Most people listening to this debate on radio at the moment are saying: `That is all right, but if you are a decent, law abiding person you will not get into trouble with the police, you will not get into trouble with the bureaucracy'. One would hope that that is always the case. However, we know that that is not so. One hopes that the police or bureaucracy will interfere if the law is broken. Let me give the example of what happened to a Brisbane couple in their late sixties who are very close to me. The husband, who is virtually a teetotaller but has an odd social drink, was advised by his doctor that his heart condition would be assisted and he would be able to sleep better if he had a small touch of brandy in his cup of tea before going to bed at night. This man called into a drive-in bottle shop and purchased a small bottle of brandy. He did not have a drink in the hotel at all; he just went to the bottle shop. About 200 yards from the hotel two young policemen in a car swerved in front of him and forced his car to the kerb. They pulled him bodily from the car-this is a man of 62 or 63 years of age with a heart condition-and, with his wife helplessly looking on, slammed his face on the bonnet of the car, put his arms up on the bonnet, searched him and accused him of being drunk. To my knowledge this man has never broken a law in his life. He is an honest citizen.

This is the sort of reason why the Democrats are saying that we need a strong Bill of Rights. The good people in the Australian Labor Party, such as Senator Tate, say that we need a Bill of Rights to protect citizens from that sort of intrusion into human rights. Yet this Bill does not extend any coverage at all to State governments, local governments or their employees. My wife and I have built two houses in the last five years and we know of the massive infringements of human rights and civil liberties that take place when one comes into contact with some local government building inspectors. Unfortunately, local government is not included in this Bill. We are not talking about the protection of criminals; we are not talking about the people who take a sly puff of marihuana or whatever. We are talking about totally and utterly innocent people who may be enveloped by the bureaucracy and police activities.

In short, we say that this Bill is pathetic. As we have announced, the Australian Democrats will attempt at the Committee stage to rectify these shortcomings and will put the Government to the test. We will also put the Opposition to the test. Senator Robert Hill, a member of the Opposition, astonished every member of this chamber last evening by giving fierce and enthusiastic support for the Bill and everything that is in it and then announcing that he was going to vote against it. It is pathetic that honourable senators can make speeches like that and then vote against everything that they have just espoused.

The Government has responded to our proposals with no more than a useless so-called compromise. Publicly, I pay the highest tribute to Senator Janine Haines, the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, and members of my staff who over the past several months have worked tirelessly on this Bill of Rights, trying to get Labor back benchers and Labor Ministers to give this Bill some teeth and have it applied to the States.

However, my disappointment with the Government's attitude in no way matches my absolute disgust with the Opposition, the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia and its fellow travellers. I do not know what has happened to the Liberal Party. I would shiver if I were still a member of the Liberal Party-thank God I am not-and organisations such as the League of Rights, the Festival of Light and the National Civic Council and people such as J. K. Bowen were fellow travellers with me. I would shiver and be ashamed that people knew of that association. Thankfully, I still have many friends in the Liberal Party. However, it passes my comprehension how they can stomach creatures such as that who spread lies and whip innocent people up in a frenzy.

That is not the Liberal Party that I used to know, the Liberal Party that was headed by Sir Robert Menzies, Harold Holt and John Gorton. The Liberal Party of those days would not have stomached those sorts of people for one second. These people have been responsible for whipping up a campaign of frenzy, misrepresentation and lies which has been directed at decent, innocent Australian citizens. Thousands of people have written to me and other members of Parliament on the basis of the deceptive information they have been given. I would like to quote from some of the letters, hopefully to instil some semblance of shame into the minds and hearts of members of the National Party and the Liberal Party, once they know what they have done and the sorts of crimes that they have committed in the name of political expediency.

I have received a frightening number of letters. I have not counted them but each day they have to be brought into my office in a box. I would say that I have received between 10,000 and 20,000 letters and telegrams from mostly decent, honourable, innocent people who have been whipped up by this campaign of frenzy. During the whole of the Vietnam war or any other national catastrophe. I did not get anywhere near the number of letters or representations that I am getting on this matter.

One must ask oneself why this campaign has been whipped up. I invite Senator Gareth Evans, who will respond on behalf of the Government and who perhaps knows more about what a Bill of Rights should contain than any other member of his Government, to answer the genuine question I am posing of why these fanatics have whipped up this campaign of frenzy. This is one of the most innocent pieces of legislation that I have ever seen. Not one aspect of it offends or worries me. I do not think even my harshest critics could ever accuse me-and they could accuse me of a lot of things-of having totalitarian tendencies. I cannot see one part of this proposed Act which frightens me.

I would like to sum up my feelings about this letter writing campaign-not about the people who have written the letters but about the members of parliament and their fellow travellers who have whipped up the campaign. A parliamentary member of the National Party, whom I respect and admire as a human being, recently asked me to visit his constituency to debate the Bill of Rights legislation with Lady Bjelke- Petersen. As much as I admire the lady and would appreciate a night out with her in some remote country town, I decided that I could not accept. I say categorically to this gentleman that, whether I am free or not on any date, under no circumstances will I visit any constituency that has been whipped up to a frenzy by mischievous people on any issue on which the level of misrepresentation has now reached that of a national disgrace. I accuse the National Party of Australia of responsibility in this matter. I list below, for example, some extracts from some of the thousands of letters I have received from people after they have been addressed by National Party members and some other persons. I will come to those in a moment. I went on to say in my letter to this National Party member:

As much as I admire you personally I cannot understand how a person of your integrity can belong to a political party which in Queensland has engineered the most outrageous gerrymander in all Western democracies, whereas a political party can be returned to power with a mere 35% of the primary vote.

Yet the National Party is opposing this Bill of Rights. Where does the Liberal Party fit into this? It has been massacred, devastated, by the National Party in Queensland for years by a gerrymander. One way of fixing the gerrymander would be to have a Bill of Rights including a one vote one value article and have it apply to the States. That would allow the Liberal Party to be returned in Queensland at the next election. Yet, what does the Liberal Party do? It votes against the Bill of Rights. It will vote against a referendum for one vote one value. I say again with some sadness, particularly to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is not the Liberal Party that I once belonged to. It does not have the calibre of people in it who would not have stood for these sorts of standover tactics by a Bjelke-Petersen for five minutes. Can anybody listening understand Sir Robert Menzies being stood over by a Bjelke-Petersen? Can anybody see a Harold Holt copping that for five minutes? Can anybody see my friend John Gorton standing for it at all? What has the Liberal Party come to? In this place it is following the National Party by destroying the one chance it has of having electoral sanity in Queensland.

Worse still, the National Party is proposing legislation which forces a court of law to impose a mandatory sentence-that means minimum life sentence-on a kid on the mere presumption of a policeman that he is carrying four marihuana cigarettes. This is a proposal by a government that is elected by 35 per cent of the people, and the Liberals are supporting it and opposing a Bill of Rights which would stop this occurring. I am not talking about a kid who is perpetually smoking marihuana or who trades in it, or whatever-I have views about those kids, but I am not canvassing those now. I am talking about an innocent kid of 16, 17 or 18 years of age who is arrested by a policeman in Queensland because the policeman suspects that the kid is carrying four marihuana cigarettes-he presumes it. This could be anybody's child. It could be a child who belongs to a God-fearing family who goes to church every week. But a policeman presumes that that kid has four marihuana cigarettes-he does not even have to search him-he can arrest him, and on the basis of that presumption, a jury can find that kid guilty of an offence. Guess what the mandatory sentence for that kid is? It is life imprisonment for a 17 year-old kid who has never carried a marihuana cigarette in his life, but a policeman presumes he has. This is supported by the Liberal Party because it will not support a Bill of Rights that can extend to State governments.

There is worse still in this proposed legislation. The parents of a child under 18 years of age can automatically face charges of child neglect if the child is convicted of a drug offence. The onus of proof is on the parents to prove that they were not neglectful. I am not talking about Soviet Russia, I am not talking about an Iron Curtain country, I am talking about Australia. The parents of a child in Queensland can be convicted and gaoled simply because a policeman has suspected that their child was carrying four marihuana cigarettes. I get worried about that.

A lady who lives in Queensland spoke to me this week. She has an 18-year-old child who has just concluded a course in Sydney. The child has decided not to go back to Queensland. This mother loves her child, but she said: `I thank God that he made that decision because Queensland is no longer a safe place in which children can be brought up'. That person is not a Labor Party voter; she is a Liberal Party voter. This is the sort of thing that people like Senator Walters and others are supporting. This kind of legislation is a blight on democracy. In my view the most shameful institution in Australia is the National Party of Australia to which, frankly, I am surprised that decent people can still belong. This campaign which has been whipped up by people such as Senator Walters is one of the most shameful campaigns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I take strong exception to Senator Chipp speaking on air-he only put his name on the list today because he knew we were on air-and maligning Senator Walters outrageously by accusing her of whipping up a campaign.
—There is no point of order. Senator Walters has the right of saying that she takes exception to it.
—Senator Walters might be impressed by Senator Lewis's chivalry, but I am not. I am sure the honourable senator is.

—On a point of order: I challenge Senator Chipp to say that any letter refers to my name, or where and when I have whipped up any sort of reaction at all in my State or anywhere else. I challenge Senator Chipp to verify what he has been saying.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—I reply by referring Senator Walters to her own speech which by itself has been responsible for dozens more telegrams to my office today. The honourable senator should read her own speech. I have a letter here which says:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like the sound of the Bill of Rights. I do not like the powers that are given to the Human Rights Commission. I object because of Article 21:
Any person who is arrested shall be informed of the reason of the arrest.
This person is objecting to that. But it does not remain there. Someone else objects to it, none other than Senator Walters's colleague Senator Archer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not accuse me.
—Senator Archer is the honourable senator's colleague. On page 557 of last night's Hansard Senator Archer said:

SPEECH.PARA: If a policeman sees an armed robber fleeing the bank, the existing law does not require the policeman to explain the reason for the arrest, but under this proposal he has got to be able to give the person the exact and correct reason for the arrest, or it can be held to be an improper arrest.
Senator Archer thinks that it is awful for a person who is arrested to be told the reason for his arrest. Senator Haines, in shock, interjects:
Don't you think someone ought to know why he is being picked up by some policeman?
Senator Archer did not. He said:
If one is on the side of the criminals, yes I do.
This indicates the kind of moronic level to which some members of the Liberal Party and the National Party have descended to score a few cheap political points.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If Senator Chipp is going to make these accusations he had better include the Law Council of Australia which has made the same accusations.
—I think Senator Chipp is entitled to make his speech in due silence. If the honourable senator has any comments I am sure she will have another opportunity during this debate to make her reply.
—I have another letter from a Mr George Oughton from Homebush West. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is noteworthy that the vast majority of the subversives who are the main energisers of this Bill and the ID Card lead unsatisfying sexual lives and show it in unsatisfying married lives, if any of them get around to that formality.
These are the kind of people who are fellow travellers of the Liberal Party and the National Party. It passes my comprehension. I read another one:
The Hon. D.L. Chipp,
It will be of no concern of us farmers if the law should find a few extra bodies lying around if the Bill of Rights is passed.
The following letter came from Glen Edwards of Tasmania:
The social engineering proposed is alarming.
As a christian parent, a teacher-
God help us; this man is a teacher-
and Australian citizen I urge upon you to look closely at the many wrongs in the Bill, such as legalising homo- sexual marriage and adoption, abortion on demand and the reduction of police powers.
This man is a teacher.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not read the Bill, that's for sure.

—He has not read the Bill. This man whom we have unleashed on the children to teach has said that this Bill has `many wrongs such as legalising homosexual marriage'. He wrote the letter because he has been told lies.
—No, they weren't lies.
—Senator Lewis is defending the position of this teacher who says:

SPEECH.PARA: the many wrongs in the Bill, such as legalising homosexual marriage and adoption . . .

That is nonsense. I use this opportunity to quote from Article 13 to expose how wicked has been the technique of lies and distortion being put around by members of this Parliament and their fellow travellers-the Australian League of Rights, the Festival of Light, the National Civic Council and so on. Article 13, under the heading `Right to marry and to found a family', states:
Recognising that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State-
(a) every man and woman of marriageable age has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex and to found a family; and
(b) no marriage shall be entered into without the free and full consent of the intending spouses.

I cannot think of any form of words in the English language that could more clearly express that marriages would only be between men and women. Yet these people, the Senator Walterses of this world, are allowing the distortion and the untruths to be perpetuated. Senator Boswell, who is attempting to interject, is indicating that it is not a distortion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to associate my name with anything against the Bill of Rights. Please broadcast it.

—I acknowledge that interjection. If it was not unparliamentary, I can only distinguish it as being absolutely and totally moronic. But I acknowledge the interjection, so that it will go into Hansard, that he will support any tactic to outlaw the Bill of Rights.
—That's right; mention my name too.

—I do not even know how to spell it! I cannot spell his name. There are many other such letters that show the sort of campaign that has been whipped up. Apart from the extraordinary gerrymanders which exist in Queensland and Western Australia, the twisted thinking of the Queensland Government has led to extraordinary legislation that could be directed against innocent people in the next few years. What sorts of dreadful things does the Bill of Rights do? It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Every person has the right without any discrimination to the equal protection of the law.
The Liberal Party opposes this. It wants the Bill of Rights to be destroyed. Article 5 states:

Persons who belong to an ethnic, religious or linguistic minority have the right, in community with other members of their own group, to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practise their own religion, or to use their language.
the Liberal Party opposes that. Under the heading `Right of participation in public life' the Bill states:
Every Australian citizen has the right and shall have the opportunity- (a) to take part in the conduct of public affairs, directly or through freely chosen representatives;-
the Liberal Party is opposed to that-
(b) to vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections-
The National Party will be opposed to that, for sure-
(c) to have access on general terms of equality to public employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are almost all opposed to that.
—They are all opposed to that. Under the heading `Freedom of expression' the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: Every person has the right to freedom of expression, including the freedom of the press and other media of communication, and the freedom to seek, receive and impart ideas or information of any kind in any form, without interference and regardless of frontiers.
What a dreadful thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not leave out slavery and torture.

What a shocking thing to allow people the freedom to believe in any god they please! The Liberal and National parties want to stop that. This is a sad day for the country because a worthless Bill is before us. The Government has announced that it will not accept the meaningful amendments that the Democrats have proposed. The National and Liberal parties, with their fellow travellers-the League of Rights, the Festival of Light and the National Civic Council-have conducted a nation-wide campaign of fear which, in my political experience, is unparalleled. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some matters which the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has raised which unfortunately I will have to respond to in this debate on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. I had hoped to be able to limit my time on my feet to about 15 minutes but Senator Chipp has raised some matters which undoubtedly require some sort of a response. Regarding his allegations as to what various policemen have done to various suspects, may I say to him that I have the greatest empathy and compassion for people who are so maltreated. There is no way that a legislature can protect people from the activities of policemen who become power crazy. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp has maligned people who were concerned that the Bill of Rights would allow homosexual marriages. TALK.START.PARA: —In cowards' castle.

—He stands up here in cowards' castle, says Senator Boswell-and I can spell his name, B-o-s-w-e-l-l-and purports to speak on behalf of people and in favour of the protection of their rights, yet he names some fellow who has obviously been misled through looking at the Bill as it was originally presented by Senator Gareth Evans. Interestingly enough that body also criticised Article 21, the article criticised by one of the authors of a letter to Senator Chipp, as it criticises many of the Articles in the Bill of Rights. Let me quote one section of this letter of 22 November 1985. This letter was addressed to me and I presume that copies went to all other senators. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the important matters raised in the Law Council's report-
and this was attached to the letter-
are:
(a) The Council's concern that the Australian Bill of Rights permits `reverse discrimination' in favour of disadvantaged races and groups;
(b) The Council's concern at the wide range of powers given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and of the secret nature of its investigations;
(c) The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has the potential to be used as a lever to put pressure on State Governments to change their laws;

(d) That the right to refuse to answer questions or provide information on the grounds of self-incrimination have been removed from persons who are summoned before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
In response to Senator Tate, I say that this Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, as it will be extended under this Bill, really has vast powers. Let me quote clause 28 (1):
The Commission has power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of its functions under this Act.
It has the power to do anything it wants to do in order to carry out its functions under this Act. Clause 29 (1) says:

For the purpose of the performance of its functions under this Act, the Commission may make an examination or hold an inquiry in such manner as it thinks fit and, in informing itself in the course of an examination or inquiry, is not bound by the rules of evidence.

What an enormously powerful clause that is. Just think of the power that that gives to this body. I ask the Government, particularly Senator Gareth Evans, who is in the chamber, why in clause 29 (1) this body is just given the power to conduct an inquiry or an examination in such manner as it thinks fit? Why has the Government not said `by regulation'? Then at least Parliament would have an opportunity to examine and consider the means whereby there should be an inquiry. Of course, as Senator Tate was saying, the penalties resulting from any alleged criminal offences will have to be imposed as a result of prosecution. I do not deny that but I draw attention to the vast power contained in clause 29 (1) of the Bill.

I was surprised to hear Senator Tate say that this Federal Government had no intention of interfering with the States. Let me quote from the third last paragraph of the second reading speech of Senator Button in this place when he introduced the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985. He said:

. . . the Commonwealth expects the States and the Northern Territory to take action to amend or repeal legislation which offends human rights . . . The Government wishes to make it clear that if such action on the part of the States in not forthcoming, the Commonwealth reserves the right to enact specific overriding Commonwealth legislation.
Senator Button has made it perfectly clear what the Government intends to do with regard to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the deal that has been done with Caucus?

—Senator Durack mentions Caucus where the members are split asunder.
