That is why Senator Chipp put his name on the speaking list today-a broadcast day. He has not been on the list to speak on this Bill since the Bill came into this chamber, yet today-a broadcast day-he puts his name on the list and comes in here to speak. Why? Because we know that the Democrats are split asunder. Two of their number want to oppose this Bill on the ground that it does not go far enough and the other five want to go along with the Government, or part of the Government's proposed arrangements, whereby it allegedly will fix up Queensland at a later date.
—What deal have they done?
—We do not know what deal they have done. We do not know what sort of deal has been done between the Government and the Democrats but my suspicion is that they will split--
—There is no good dealing with you, you deal with Joh Bjelke-Petersen. He breaches a confidence; he is a liar and a cheat.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Gareth Evans referred to the Premier of Queensland as a liar and a cheat. I ask you to ask him to withdraw that comment. He knows that he is required to do so under Standing Orders.
—On the basis of its being unparliamentary, but not inaccurate, I will of course withdraw the statement.
—I ask that the withdrawal be given in an unqualified way.
—You are looking at me, Mr Acting Deputy President, in a way that is not benign, so I will make an unqualified withdrawal.

—This misnamed Bill of Rights-and it is misnamed because it talks about people having rights, but the truth of the matter is that anyone who appears before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has no rights at all-is not needed. This misnamed Bill of Rights will lead to legal confusion and ambiguity on a grand scale. This misnamed Bill of Rights confers on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission the role of enforcement by inquisition, contrary to basic notions of justice. This misnamed Bill of Rights ignores violation of human rights by individuals. This misnamed Bill of Rights overlooks or ignores what many people in Australia believe are their basic rights. This misnamed Bill of Rights raises the basis for deliberate, massive and unprecedented Federal intrusion into the affairs of State governments, instrumentalities and local governments. Finally, this misnamed Bill of Rights will add greatly to costs and delays in the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal first with the first point I mentioned in that list-that this misnamed Bill of Rights is not needed. In common law countries we have been blessed with freedoms which have been won from governments over many centuries, starting at the time of the Magna Carta. I emphasise that the freedoms are won from governments, not bestowed by governments. Indeed, in most democratic countries it is only the Parliament which protects the freedom of the people, not the Government. I say to the people of Australia that it is this Senate which will protect them from the imposition of this Bill of Rights; only this Senate will be able to protect the people from this Bill of Rights. When one looks at the freedoms that Western democratic countries have won over many centuries, one sees that these are the freedoms which the academics in the United Nations in the 1940s tried to put together when they were looking at a Bill of Rights. They came up with a minimum Bill of Rights-I stress that it was a minimum Bill of Rights because it included only what the Soviet Union was prepared to sign at that time-which was signed by countries where, as Senator Tate acknowledged, the rights are not being enforced. This minimum Bill of Rights will be reimposed on the people of Australia. So we will have the freedom to marry! I do not know whether Senator Gareth Evans thinks that is in jeopardy in Australia at present, but I do not think it is. We will have the freedom to take part in public affairs, the freedom to associate with other people, the freedom to assemble and the freedom to enjoy our own culture and not to be held in slavery. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may think that these freedoms are important, as I think that they are important. However, who would seriously suggest that they are in any way in jeopardy in this country at the moment?

TALK.START.PARA: —All the slaves will now go free.

—Senator Crichton-Browne had indicated that all the slaves in Australia will now be allowed to go free. Similarly, if one is charged with a criminal offence, this Bill will give one the right to be present at the trial and to present a defence. Of course that is a most important right in Australia. However, is anyone suggesting that that right is in jeopardy? In fact, the truth is that in Australia if one endeavours to avoid being present during one's trial the authorities will issue a warrant of arrest to make one be present at one's trial.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, in Australia there are certain rights and freedoms which we have won but which do not get a mention in a dictatorship. Therefore, they do not rate a guernsey in this Bill. There is nothing in this Bill which guarantees the right to own property and not to have it confiscated, such as the Wran Government did in 1981 when it took over people's right to mine on their own land without paying adequate compensation at all. That is not covered in any way in this Bill. There is no covenant to protect people from being forced to join trade union movements. There is no covenant to give any clear guarantee that parents have the right to educate their children in the school of their choice. However, all children in Australia will be delighted to know that after this Bill of Rights is passed they will have the right to have a name. I am sure that will be of enormous value to the children of Australia.

The Bill does not guarantee, as does the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the rights of children both before and after birth. That is one of the things which really upset me about this debate. The Bill will do nothing to look at the major problems which this Parliament and the people of Australia are concerned about in regard to any future debates on rights of freedom. I ask Senator Evans to tell me when he speaks following me in what way this Bill will assist the people of Australia who have to deal with the problem of euthanasia. That is a major matter which we need to be inquiring into to determine which path we will be taking this country down. How will this Bill help such people? How will it help the people concerned about abortions in this country? There are honourable senators opposite who want free abortions and there are those of us on this side of the Parliament who are concerned about abortion and the enormous use of abortion at present as a contraceptive device. Many hundreds of thousands of potential children have been destroyed in Australia by abortion. I ask Senator Evans to tell me how this so-called Bill of rights in any way assists us to come to some sort of conclusion in regard to those difficult problems. They are the sorts of areas on the frontiers of the rights of people which this Parliament ought to be considering, not going back and trying to protect the people of Australia from slavery.

There are other things to which we need to be applying our minds, such as the protection of the people of Australia from the rapacity of governments and the desire of governments to rape the pockets and the purses of the people of this nation. It may be that there ought to be a provision in this Bill that no government is allowed to bring in a Budget for more than a certain amount of the gross national product. That is the sort of right which might get the support of people on my side of the Parliament, but not the sort of nonsense which guarantees each child in this country the right to a name. That is absolute nonsense. Let me come last of all to a matter which I really consider to be of major importance. I refer to Article 3 of the Bill of Rights, which states:
1. The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

They are good-sounding and high-sounding words which, when we put them together, are very difficult to interpret. I looked at this Article and wondered what its meaning was. It seems to me that ultimately this Article, which, as I said, is vague of interpretation at the present, must mean that a Federal Court judge in due course will be able to determine that an Act of Parliament is invalid, not because it is outside the Constitution or outside the powers of the Parliament, but because it is unreasonable. That means that that judge will be applying his views and his mind to something as vague as whether limitations are reasonable. What on earth will that mean?

What I ask Senator Evans and the Parliament to do in regard to this Article is to think of the power that this Article would give to some future government, especially some future government controlled by a dictator type. We have in the world at the moment a person who is showing the world how one can become a dictator over a long period in government and not be prepared to hand over the reins of government. I ask honourable senators to consider how a Prime Minister of this country would be able to misuse such a power. All that he would need to do would be to appoint Federal Court judges who are of the same political persuasion and who, perhaps, would be dependent on him for their appointment and allow them to go around this countryside determining that legislation validly passed by Parliament was invalid because it was unreasonable.

I say to Senator Evans that a future dictator of the Right or the Left could misuse this power abominably. I cannot understand why he should bring in legislation which will allow this to happen when the whole point of our Parliament is to protect people in future from such a result. I am not the only one who believes this. Senator Michael Tate, who sits on the other side of the chamber, believes it too. Senator Tate wrote an article which was published in the Australian of 2 January this year and which I find quite incredible. Talking about the Bill of Rights being entrenched in the Constitution, Senator Tate said that he does not want it entrenched. His reasons for saying that were:

Entrenchment would give to the judiciary the final word on many social issues and could encourage members of the judiciary to take an active role, imposing their own values and policies on governments and society, and over-riding policy decisions of elected parliaments.
Senator Tate recognises that and criticises it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not want the Bill of Rights.
—I agree with Senator Boswell. It is clear that Senator Tate does not want the Bill of Rights. Senator Tate continued:

SPEECH.PARA: A bench of non-elected judges-
I totally agree with him that the judges would be non-elected; they would be appointed by the Prime Minister or the Prime Minister's nominee -
politically answerable to no one should have no conclusive dominance over the elected representatives.
Having made this massive attack on the Bill of Rights, Senator Tate said:
These kinds of concerns lead me to the view that a Bill of Rights should, at least for a trial period, be contained in an ordinary Commonwealth stature.

What he is saying is: `The power contained in Article 3 is so horrendous that we could not possibly put it in the Constitution. So what we will do is put it in a Commonwealth statute'. In other words, he has found some way of convoluting an argument to enable him to vote in favour of this Bill. Of course, that is because of his political ambitions and the political electorate to which he is responsible. However, the truth of the matter is clear from his article: He is totally opposed to the Bill of Rights. Senator Tate also quotes the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, as stating:
If society is tolerant and rational, it does not need a Bill of Rights; if it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

Clearly, Senator Tate is showing his way. What he now says is: `We will not put it in the Constitution. What we will do instead is have it in a statute'. Once it is in the statute books, how will we ever override it? How will we be able to pass legislation in the Senate at some stage which says: `This Act is contrary to the Bill of Rights, but nevertheless it stands'? Could honourable senators imagine getting the numbers in the Senate to do that? I say to the people who may be listening to the broadcast of proceedings that we would like to revoke this Bill of Rights which it appears the Government, with the assistance of, say, five out of seven members of the Australian Democrats, will be able to carry. But the only way we can revoke it is if the people of Australia give us the numbers in the Senate. We would have to have a majority in the Senate to be able to revoke the legislation at some stage in the future. So I make a plea to all those who may be listening and who are opposed to this Bill of Rights, as I am opposed to it: If you want this Bill of Rights thrown out, the only way to do it will be to return the Liberal-National Party at the next election with the numbers in the Senate as well as in the House of Representatives so that we can revoke this nonsense and revoke this tragedy.

I say finally to the Senate and to the people of Australia that this Bill of Rights is at best an unnecessary addition to our system of jurisprudence. It will do nothing to protect our rights but, at worst, it could be a real threat to the existing rights which have been well developed and best preserved by our traditional democratic institutions and our highly respected system of justice as it stands at present.

If there are problems in the country which need to be dealt with-if there are some rights that need to be overcome-the Parliaments of the Commonwealth and of the States will be able to enact pieces of legislation which will deal with those rights and which will overcome the problems which may be confronting the people of a State or the Commonwealth. To bring down some general Bill of Rights such as this will in no way protect those people in this country who feel that they have a right that needs to be protected. Those people who have been assaulted by a policeman, for example, will get no protection from this legislation. Those public servants who believe that they want to be free and upright will get no protection from this Bill of Rights. This Bill of Rights is a nonsense and fails to protect those fundamental freedoms for which so many of us in this country have worked and will continue to work, certainly throughout the life of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When one strips away so much of the over-heated rhetoric that has characterised this debate and when one looks calmly and objectively at what this Australian Bill of Rights is about and what it is actually seeking to do, it is really quite extraordinary that it should have generated the hysterical reaction and opposition that it undoubtedly has both inside and, in some quarters, outside this Parliament. The Opposition, some of it, to put it at its most kindly, has been misguided. Some of it, a great deal of it, has been quite mindless. Some of it, indeed a considerable amount of it, has been quite cynical and malicious in its character, designed to secure political ends other than those inherently involved in the objections to the legislation itself. Senator Boswell let the cat out of the bag in this respect this morning when he said that he would favour any tactic, any distortion, any lie however outrageous, if it served his end of denying the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Because there has been that kind of opposition, I think it is important, as a result, that at the conclusion of this very long second reading debate we go back to basics and I indicate very briefly at the outset just what this Bill of Rights is trying to do. It is trying to do four quite simple things: First, it is trying to enshrine in our law, served by effective remedies, standards of behaviour which have been agreed to be fundamental by the international community of nations and, incidentally, agreed at a time when Western democratic cultural values were undoubtedly the prevailing values in that international community that produced the document in question.

The second thing the Bill is trying to do is seek to formalise and reinforce such rights and freedoms as we already possess, to recognise the formally and to enshrine them in legal and enforceable terms in language of Commonwealth statutes. The third thing that the Bill is trying to do is to provide a firm legal basis to fight for those standards and values that are not presently effectively protected by law, not just to provide a formal recognition of things that might arguably be protected effectively already but to provide a peg on which to hang endeavours to seek protection in practice of rights which are not presently enjoyed and not presently protected by statute or common law.

The final thing the Bill undoubtedly does, and not just seeks to do, is that it acknowledges quite frankly and quite openly that there are rights other than those which are listed in the Bill which do exist and do deserve protection. The Bill says quite explicitly in relation to those other rights which may not be canvassed in the list in the Bill itself that those rights are to go on being protected and recognised to the extent that they already exist. Article 2 of the Australian Bill of Rights, under the heading `Effect of Bill of Rights on existing rights and freedoms' makes that absolutely clear when it says:

A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by reason only that the right of freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights.

So that, in very short compass, is what this Bill is seeking to do. It is the case that a Bill of Rights of this kind, expressing rights and freedoms in a succinct and generalised way, is an innovation in the Australian legal system. Traditionally, we have not gone in for this sort of thing. Traditionally, we have relied first on the self-restraint of legislators around the country in making laws and, secondly, on the self-restraint of judges making common law themselves and interpreting the statute law that has been made by legislators. Thirdly, we have relied on the self-restraint of officials-the police officers-administering government powers in circumstances where the law is silent as to the manner and nature of the exercise of those powers, as the law so often is.

While that has been the tradition of the past and while it is the case that a Bill of Rights of this kind is innovative in seeking to add another whole layer to that tradition, it ought to be recognised also at the outset that this Bill of Rights approach is not innovative at all in the context of Western democratic jurisprudence with which we are-most of us anyway-so familiar. It is, of course, an enormously long-standing tradition in the United States of America, which, some 200 years ago, was the first country to enact a Bill of Rights which at least in its modern form as endorsed by the United States Supreme Court over the last couple of generations reflects exactly the sorts of values and approaches to the protection of those values which are enshrined in the document now before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that is true about gun control laws?

—I do not want to be diverted by that question. I will be happy to deal with it in the Committee stage. The right to bear arms is not and has not been construed by any American court for over a century as guaranteeing the untrammelled and unrestricted right of individuals to acquire hand-guns, rifles or anything else. It has been acknowledged over and over again by the courts to have historical reference and application only to the rights of citizen militias in the context of the social conditions prevailing 200 years ago. The fact that the national rifle association chooses to flaunt that particular language and misconstrue it in a way that would never now be acknowledged by the courts is not something that I think should pervert us from an understanding of the proper interpretation of those provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

Let me continue by saying that the Bill of Rights tradition is by now a very familiar one in the Western democratic context, not only in the United States, which we have just been talking about, but in Europe, where the European convention, reflecting all of these values, was put together some 10 years before the International Covenant on which the present Bill is based. In Canada a Bill of Rights has been part of national legislation since 1959 and has been more recently incorporated in the Constitution of that country. In the United Kingdom an active debate has been proceeding for some years and a Bill of Rights is now before the Westminster Parliament. In New Zealand an active debate has also been running for some time. A Bill of Rights has been introduced and is presently before a committee in that country. The concepts, which do have, and have had in the past, an unfamiliar ring to Anglo-Saxon juristic ears over the last decade or so, have now become very familiar. We are talking about legal guarantees for individuals against governments-guarantees which have a long and honourable history in countries squarely within our own legal and cultural tradition.

This is perhaps the occasion to make the point, in answer to such a recurring theme of this debate, that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, on which this Bill of Rights is squarely based, was drafted in the 1950s and early 1960s at a time when Western nations unquestionably dominated the United Nations. In Australia it was the Menzies Government-according to Senator Sir John Carrick, in his contribution, it was especially the Menzies Government-which fought to introduce the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights into international affairs. It was the Fraser Government, of course, which ratified that Covenant in 1980. It was former Attorney-General Durack, who is present in this chamber, who chose to define the very concept of human rights in his Human Rights Commission Act, primarily through reference to those rights in the form in which they were defined and enshrined in that International Covenant. The International Covenant, as Senator Tate said earlier, has been ratified by the United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand, France, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Japan-in just about all of the Western industrialised countries.

Senator Missen said in his contribution that it was colossally stupid to suggest, as have some speakers in this debate, that the United Kingdom and the United States of America had rejected the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. They have not rejected it in the past and they do not now. It is true that there are parties to that Covenant who do not in practice respect the rights it contains. But to say that because those countries we do not like are parties to it-they are in some instances, hypocritically party to it-we should refuse to implement the Covenant is to be guilty of the most blatant irrationality. It is true that many countries other than those I have mentioned have domestic documents which they choose to call Bills of Rights. Some of them deserve the name; in many other cases that is not the case. But it trivialises and tarnishes this debate to focus attention on so-called Bills of Rights that have been erected for purely cosmetic reasons in countries which have no intention of honouring them and to ignore the reality that the Bill of Rights concept is, as I have argued, very well and honourably established in very many countries that we would unequivocally respect and admire.

Let me deal with that other familiar chestnut that has recurred, predictably, throughout this debate. It is, of course, true that the existence of a Bill of Rights in a country is no guarantee in itself that rights will be respected. In a country that is inherently unstable or authoritarian, where the conditions for liberal democracy simply do not exist, the most elaborately and tightly drawn Bill of Rights cannot possibly prevent the emergence or continuance of dictatorships, any more than any other institutional arrangement can. What a Bill of Rights can do in a society like our own in which, by and large, the pre-conditions of liberal democracy do exist is make a good society better. It can make a significant contribution to removing those injustices which do exist and to override, remove and overcome those abuses of power against citizens which even the best run governments in the best run countries sometimes engage in through error, inattention or, in some cases, through individual or collective malice.

The significance of the Bill of Rights is not that it can solve problems in itself but it can make a basically democratic society better. In response to the much quoted sally of Chief Justice Gibbs in this respect, I acknowledge that if a society is not tolerant and rational, it is the case that no Bill of Rights will preserve it. But I simply cannot acknowledge, and do not accept the force of his corollary argument, that if a society is by and large tolerant and rational a Bill of Rights is unnecessary. I will come to that point in a moment.

Let me first quickly mention the point in the same context that was made by Senator Lewis, the claim that advocates of the Bill of Rights argue that it is a universal panacea; that once one has a Bill of Rights it will be the answer to the resolution of all the difficult and delicate civil liberties problems such as abortion, euthanasia and all of these other problems that can and do arise. But it is, of course, the case that no such claim has ever been made for any Bill of Rights, nor this Bill of Rights in particular. One needs not just a single set of overriding standards, binding on legislatures and enforceable through the courts though they may be but rather a whole network of guarantees and protections. We do need separate, piecemeal race discrimination and sex discrimination laws. We do need separate privacy protection laws. We do need separate electoral laws guaranteeing in detail free, fair, equal and universal suffrage. We do need separate laws governing the protection of property in the way in which the compulsory acquisition laws of this country traditionally have. We do need separate and detailed criminal investigation laws. Notwithstanding the need for supporting structures and legislation of that kind, it is tremendously important and tremendously useful to have a Bill of Rights as well, not only for its legal touchstone role but also its standard-setting role, its moral and educative force, and for the commitment it also represents to the upholding of basic rights and freedoms with which we would all agree.

Let me now turn to what in substance, I guess, the opponents of this legislation are saying. It can probably be reduced to two basic themes. On the one hand, notwithstanding the kind of generalised points I have just made, a Bill of Rights is unnecessary. It is simply not needed to do the kind of job that I have said this Bill and Bills of Rights elsewhere are trying to do. The other theme that one constantly comes up against, particularly in terms of the Opposition in the course of this debate, is that the Bill is not only unnecessary but undesirable; indeed, bordering on the dangerous in terms of its effect and implications.

First, as to the claim that the Bill of Rights is unnecessary, the main argument that one constantly comes up against is that the common law is our best guarantor; that this is the only guarantee of the rights and liberties we need; that all we have to do is leave it to the courts and to the judges to honour and continue that great Anglo-Saxon common law tradition. But the essential emptiness of that proposition has been amply and, indeed, extremely well demonstrated by a number of Opposition speakers. The argument was succinctly and very effectively put, not only by Senator Haines for the Australian Democrats, but also in particular by Senator Missen and, more particularly still by Senator Puplick who in his contribution to this debate on 14 February reported at page 392 of Hansard-and it is worth reading-said that he was singularly unimpresseed as a non-lawyer by the argument that the common law protects the rights of all citizens. Clearly, he said, it does not. He instanced as examples the failure of the common law to protect the principle of equality of voting. He instanced the failure of the common law to offer the right of protection of private property-a common and recurring theme in this debate. He instanced the failure of the common law to respect and protect jury trial, to respect freedom of religion and the right to privacy-and he gave other examples as well. It was a compelling demonstration of the inadequacy of this argument that is so often heard.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of the Westpac Bank decision to increase interest rates to record levels on Bankcard, Mastercard and personal loans, a decision which is attributed by the bank to Government policy, and given the likely flow on to other lenders, how much longer does this Government intend to maintain its policy of jacking up interest rates to protect the currency? I ask the Minister: Will the Government now concede that the head of the Federal Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, was correct last week when he said that, as an instrument of economic policy interest rates had had their day?
—All sorts of thing can be said to have had their day, even Senator Chaney and myself.
—You are generous with your inclusion.

—I was being very charitable about that, Mr President. I need not have included myself; it was only out of charity that I did so in the sense that we are all terminal politicians in a long term sense. The first part of the question relates to how long the Government-to use Senator Chaney's inelegant expression-will pursue a policy to jack up interest rates to protect the dollar. The answer is that the Government will go on doing that so long as it thinks it is necessary, having regard to a number of factors which the Government, of course, has to take into account, including the current level of interest rates.
—That is a circuitous answer.
—That is a roundabout--
—It is not really, if I can explain to the two troglodytic interjectors, what I meant by that is that the Government has to be concerned about the current level of interest rates. We are.
—That is cool comfort though.

—Of course it is. We understand that. We have expressed our concern about that and at an appropriate time the Government will make a decision about these matters which will be communicated to senators in this chamber and everybody else. I think what Mr Bernie Fraser had to say about this matter is not inconsistent with the Government's view, but again in time a decision will be made about that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's reply. In light of his response that the Government will go on jacking up interest rates as long as it is necessary, I ask him: Does he agree that it will be necessary until other policies of the Government are changed, including its fiscal and wages policy.

—I do not agree with all that. First of all, I did not say that in the terms in which Senator Chaney purports. A whole range of policy issues have to be taken into account in considering any of these matters. They cannot be singled out in isolation from general economic management issues. At the appropriate time we will take all those matters into account.

—I direct a question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I refer to comments made on radio today by Mr Ian Cameron, the National Party member for Maranoa, that the Government should run public relations programs to encourage women to stay at home and look after their household chores. I refer also to this same person's comment that he wished women would stay at home and make their kitchens look tidier. Is the Minister aware whether this appalling attitude is held by all National Party members in this Parliament and the women whom they represent? Would the Minister agree that outrageous comments such as these confirm the need for the Government's affirmative action legislation?

—I do not know how many kitchens of Australian women Mr Cameron has had the opportunity to inspect but, speaking on behalf of all Australian women and being an owner of a kitchen myself, I rather resent his implication that we cannot manage to do jobs and look after our kitchens as well. Perhaps Senator Colston's question really should have been directed to the female representative of the National Party in this place, Senator Bjelke-Petersen. She is not here. I hesitate to suggest that she might be at home tidying up her kitchen. Of course she may not need to do that because she has a partner and I am sure in an enlightened household where both partners engage in full time employment, such as the Bjelke- Petersen household, there are properly shared responsibilities for the kitchen. It is really very unfortunate that certain spokespeople for the National Party continue to adopt this demeaning and insulting attitude towards Australian women.
—It's probably a plot to keep her home.

—My colleague Senator Walsh has interjected that perhaps it is a plot to ensure Senator Bjelke-Petersen's return to her kitchen, but I will not make any comment on that. It is unfortunate that the National Party shows itself so out of step with the attitudes of contemporary Australian women.
—I bet you can't make the pumpkin scones that she can.

—Perhaps Senator Walters will find herself more at home in the National Party with its attitudes. I would not be so provocative as to inquire into the state of Senator Walters's kitchen. But the National Party is clearly out of step in its pronouncements about Australian women. It is quite clear that contemporary Australian women, while not resiling from their domestic responsibilities, are prepared to, in many cases are qualified to, and wish to participate fully in the economy, in the work force and in community organisations. In order to enable contemporary Australian women to fulfil these aspirations our Government has instituted a number of programs and has introduced legislation, the most recent of which will be introduced very shortly in the other place by the Prime Minister to ensure that Australian women can take their place in our society and in our work force on a completely equal basis to men. The sooner the National Party realises that this is what Australian women want, the sooner it will be more than a tiny rump in parliaments around this country.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether his attention has been drawn to an article in the Age this week headed: `Interest Rates Curbing Investment'. This article referred to a survey by the National Australia Bank and the Australian Chamber of Commerce which showed a big drop in expected new capital investment and new employment by big business during this year compared with last year. Does the Minister accept that continuing high interest rates are now seriously jeopardising the prospects of long term economic recovery and will inevitably lead to higher unemployment?

—I certainly accept the proposition that a continuance of high interest rates for a long period would jeopardise the economy very seriously and jeopardise investment in particular. As I understand it that is not the question with which I have to be concerned. It is more relevant to Senator Chaney's question. I have not seen the survey in the Age article to which Senator Jessop referred. All I can say is that up to the December quarter investment figures were standing up very well. Honourable senators will appreciate that there is always a lag in these matters. Investment in manufacturing in particular was very encouraging this quarter compared with the similar quarter last year. I appreciate that the longer high interest rates continue the more that performance is likely to be affected. I would hazard a guess at what is happening though; that is that large companies in particular having enjoyed record profits are making substantial investments out of profits.
—Before the investment allowance is withdrawn.

—No. I was not referring to the period of the withdrawal of the investment allowance which of course terminated for these purposes on 30 June last year, Senator; I was referring to the performance of the quarter since. It is quite clear that the investment patterns are not a cause of great satisfaction, but they are quite reasonable in all the circumstances. The record profitability of many companies has enabled them to invest out of profits and they are continuing to do so. The effect of interest rates is more likely to be borne unequally between large companies and smaller companies in the event of a long term continuance of high interest rates.
—I have a supplementary question. I ask whether the Minister believes that this could lead to unemployment.

—A lot of things can lead to unemployment. It is difficult to weigh the respective factors which may influence that. As Senator Jessop knows, employment is holding up very well. Last month's figures show that this is the fourth month in which unemployment has been below 8 per cent, at 7.8 per cent. The figures show an historically high participation rate and, in spite of that, unemployment has been reduced over a steady period. One of the basic factors which would lead to unemployment is a substantial reduction in the growth rate which this Government has sustained over its period in office. It is undoubted that at some point interest rates would affect that, but that is the fundamental thing that has sustained the increase in employment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has Mr Harkins prepared a report on Aboriginal legal aid services? If so, has that report been delivered to the Minister? If so, when was it so delivered? If a report has been prepared and delivered, is it proposed that any, and if so what, action be taken on the contents of the report? If so, when?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, has provided me with the following information regarding the Harkins report. Mr Harkins reported to the Minister on the Inquiry into Aboriginal Legal Aid in October 1985, following over two years of investigations. The report is a massive document of over 1,300 pages. Mr Holding is at present considering his recommendations before making a decision on the future of the report, but in view of the substantial printing costs that would be involved, Mr Holding does not propose to table the report.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware that changes to the National Health Act in May 1985, requiring the registration of health benefit organisations, have disadvantaged friendly societies offering ancillary benefits only? Does the Minister recall my raising the matter-he probably does not because he was not in the chair at the time-during the second reading debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill on 30 May 1985? I am still awaiting a satisfactory reply to the question of the effect on friendly societies of that change in legislation. Will the Minister indicate whether the Government is prepared to return to friendly societies their previous capacity to offer ancillary benefits without operating a basic private hospital table, provided they give an undertaking to adhere to the community rating principle which was behind the change made to that section of the Act in 1985?

—Senator Haines is right, in that I do remember that matter being raised as I was not here at the time. I certainly agree with her that she should have had an answer-whether or not it is a satisfactory one is a matter for her to judge-by now. I will seek that information from the Minister for Health. I find it difficult, thinking on my feet, to understand how any organisation can provide insurance for ancillary benefits and still apply the community rating to its benefits, but I dare say that is something which Dr Blewett and his colleagues will work out for me and perhaps will enlighten both of us. I will seek that information from the Minister for Health as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister for Community Services aware that some privately-owned child care centres have raised their fees this year by as much as 50 per cent and have claimed that this rise was made necessary by changes to Federal Government guidelines? Is there any truth in such a claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is no. In New South Wales several private for profit child care centres have raised their fees by in excess of 50 per cent and have informed people sending children to those centres that this was the result of actions taken by the Government and by me. In Victoria there have been some increases of up to 50 per cent. Unfortunately some subsidised child care centres also have put up their fees and have said that it was due to the actions of the Government and me as the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts are that the Federal Government has no control in any way over private for profit child care centres in this country. Most States have licensing regulations which ensure that certain standards are maintained in these child care centres. I know of no State in which any change has been made in recent times to the regulations that are necessary. Therefore, as far as I know, no actions by State governments should have resulted in such an increase in fees. Undoubtedly what has happened in this area is that people operating private for profit child care centres have decided that they want to increase those profits and have decided, during the time of the present controversy over small changes to funded child care centres, that they will cash in on this and blame the Government for their actions.

I can only assure people who send their children to such centres that the Government has done nothing which would countenance an increase of 50 per cent, or even 25 per cent or 20 per cent, in the fees of private for profit child care centres. Anyone who claims to the parents who send their children to these centres, that this is so, is lying and should be exposed as such. I might add also that the Government has done nothing in regard to subsidised child care centres and that no changes will be made until 1 April. So any subsidised child care centres, such as the well known one in Hobart, Tasmania, which has put up its fees and blamed the Federal Minister, are also indulging in lies and misrepresentations and they ought to be exposed for that also.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister agree with the Minister for Primary Industry, who said yesterday that the biggest problem facing Australian farmers is high interest rates? What hope can the Government offer the farmers-the sorts of people whom the Prime Minister met in his public relations visit to the bush for the Sunday television program-that relief is in sight from the crippling impact of this Government's high interest rate policy?
—I did not see any statement attributed to Mr Kerin that the main problem facing farmers was high interest rates, although I concede that that may well be an accurate description of the problem.
—The BAE says it is.

—I am talking about Mr Kerin; I do not need any help from the honourable senator. I concede that that may be the main problem. Certainly it is an immensely important problem for farmers although there are a number of others which the Government will be addressing in the very near future. Apart from that, I have nothing to add to what I have said in answer to previous questions-that the Government is concerned about high interest rates. We have to be concerned, and as soon as we can do something about it, we will.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Given the recent attacks by the Opposition on the Commonwealth Government's administration of the Australian Capital Territory, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what is the position of the Australian Capital Territory economy in 1986? Secondly, has there been a deterioration or improvement in the Australian Capital Territory economy since the election of the Hawke Labor Government:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many statements have been made about the economy in the Australian Capital Territory, most of which are obviously ill-informed and inadequate as well as inaccurate. I thank the honourable senator for the opportunity to respond on behalf of the Government and the Minister for Territories. There is no doubt that, as a result of the positive economic policies being pursued by the Government, there has been a remarkable turnaround in the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. For example, when we came to office, the level of unemployment in Canberra and the immediate environs was nearly 7 per cent. It is now down to less than 5 per cent, which is less than the national average.

ANSWER.PARA: During the last 12 months of the Fraser Government's administration the provision of serviced land was deliberately curtailed. The consequence of that, of course, was an inflationary spiral in regard to accommodation and the cost of land generally rose rather significantly in that period. Our Government recognised the need to do something about this as an important priority and took steps to make available sufficient serviced land. We hope that this will have the effect of improving the general problem of accommodation in the Australian Capital Territory. Prior to March 1983 private sector investment in Canberra was stagnant. Under this Government private sector investment has risen fourfold to nearly $90m.

I am surprised by some of the statements that have been made by Senator Lewis. It seems to me that in his desire to make an impact-the Leader of the Opposition requires all shadow Ministers to perform-he has taken the stage on more than one occasion and made statements which, I am sure, will be shown when properly analysed to be completely inaccurate. The honourable senator said that sufficient attention has not been paid to the problems associated with the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade. This may have been a throwaway line. However, it would be very interesting to see any policy that the Opposition came up with for privatising the fire brigade in the Australian Capital Territory. How would this service be paid for? Would the Opposition pay the wages of firemen by charging the people who use the services of the fire brigade?

I conclude by saying that the Government aims to achieve a more even spread in Canberra, which has always been recognised as being a public sector city. To that extent, we have achieved a more even spread of the economy. I am advised currently that the public and private sector breakup for the Australian Capital Territory is 57 per cent public and 43 per cent private. I think that speaks volumes for the policies being pursued by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the Minister agree that the most recent level of oil prices now indicates that Australian motorists should receive a price reduction of 11c a litre if the import parity pricing formula is fully applied from 1 March?

—A lot depends on how precisely one calculates what an appropriate reflection of the former marker of Arab light is now that that crude is no longer being traded. If it is the case that the United States dollar price for Arab light is down to, I suppose, below $17, that particular inference could be drawn as to the price at the pump. What precisely is the appropriate price of Arab light is something that is still a matter for argument. I do not think it is appropriate at this stage to identify any particular price drop as flowing from any particular United States dollar price. We are monitoring the situation closely. We are still wrestling with different aspects of an appropriate formula to reflect the world price in Australian comparable terms. We will be making a decision on all these matters early next week.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Trade seen reports of the Japanese Government's decision to reduce to one per cent tariffs on imports of aluminium ingots? What benefits, if any, will accrue to Australia from this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a very detailed answer on this matter which temporarily eludes me. For some time the Japanese Government has been looking at the question of reducing tariffs and other protective devices. There is no need for Senator Watson to look concerned about that. That has been going on since Prime Minister Nakasone visited Australia and the United States of America last year. The fact of the matter is that in some areas important to Australia adjustments have been made to the Japanese tariff system. The most important long term adjustment that we have seen to date relates to tariffs on aluminium and aluminium products. That tariff reduction is broadly from a level of 9 per cent to one per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is an important producer of aluminium and that decision will assist Australian companies in the longer term in the Japanese market. I think the decision by the Japanese Government also reflects a restructuring of the Japanese economy away from highly energy intensive smokestack industries and towards more high technology industries and intellectually related industries, which is a positive shift that the Japanese economy is undergoing. Australia will benefit in respect of raw materials and processed raw materials from some of that shift. I think definite opportunities will be available to Australia as a result of the Japanese Government's decision. I have no doubt that aluminium producers in Australia which have been operating in world markets for a number of years and which are very competitive in world terms will take advantage of the change which has been made by the Japanese Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to the 60 per cent increase in oil exports to $1.8 billion in the 7 months to January and the fall in imports to $1.3 billion, so producing Australia's first ever net oil surplus of $500m so far this financial year. I ask the Minister: How many export cargoes of oil has he approved so far in 1986 and how many does he expect to approve during the remaining months of this financial year? How many of his approvals have not resulted in cargoes being shipped because of a lack of buyers, resulting in applications to him for deferments to later months? If the Minister takes the national interest into account in approving such exports, is it in the national interest for Australia to be a net exporter at current low spot prices while our imports are largely at higher contract prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there has, in recent times, been a substantial increase in crude oil exports from Australia, reflecting higher production rates and the introduction by Senator Walsh, when Minister, of a partial allocation system enabling crude to be sold, after certain conditions were satisfied, both on the domestic free market and externally. I do not have immediately to hand the number of export cargoes that have been approved both by myself and, more specifically, by the Minister for Trade, whose formal responsibility this is. However, it is the case that export shipments have been maintained at a reasonable level up, I think, until just about right now. Now it is the case that some of those shipments are being called into question. A difficult policy issue with which we as a government have to contend is whether shipments should be allowed, in effect, at any price and sold on a net back basis in the same way as the Saudis are selling so much oil around the world today, that being one of the few bases on which refiner-distributors are interested in buying oil.

ANSWER.PARA: The implications of the net back pricing system are, of course, that there would be a significant drop in the return that one could otherwise expect. The implications of that have to be taken into account-implications for balance of payments and everything else, including the rate at which Bass Strait oil reserves are depleted, which is another difficult interrelated policy issue. The position the Government has basically taken on this is one that is deregulatory and implies a standing back from the market-place and allowing the participants in the market-place to make their own commercial decisions. There is a disincentive to Bass Strait sellers selling oil on the export market to the extent that they have to pay high fixed crude oil excise on it and cannot guarantee a profit return. The situation, as with everything else in the oil market, is delicately balanced at the moment. It all depends on what happens to world oil prices. They in turn are in a volatile condition. I do not think that as a result it is appropriate to draw any longer term conclusions from this present scenario until it has settled down more and we can get a better idea right across the board of what the implications are of further developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that very full answer. Even though he cannot quantify the number of approvals and the number of deferments, I wonder whether he is prepared to give some indication of his expectations about the volume of oil exports for the remainder of this financial year.

—Quite frankly, it is premature to make a judgment about what the flow of further exports is going to be. It depends on so many contingencies that are jumping about at the moment that I do not think anyone can make a confident prediction. I certainly expect some export sales will be made, but whether they are at the same volume and at anything like the same price, as they have been recently, is a proper matter for conjecture.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BREATH TESTING OF PILOTS AND CREW

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. What provisions under legislation already exist to deal with instances in which pilots and air crew are intoxicated whilst on duty? Has the possibility of random breath testing of crew prior to flight, or any other measures of a similar kind, been considered?

—I am aware, as Senator Foreman has suggested, that some statements have been made that the Department of Aviation will shortly introduce widespread random breath testing of pilots allegedly to overcome the extensive problem of pilots flying whilst under the influence of alcohol. I am advised that the Department has no knowledge of any extensive problem in this area and the statistics of the Bureau of Air Safety show that the vast majority of pilots in this country approach the task of flying in a very professional and mature manner, and that the number of alcohol related incidents that may from time to time occur, is very small. However, the air navigation regulation 247 is able to be applied when circumstances warrant it. In the majority of these cases, which are very rare, the courts have not been able to admit the blood alcohol content as evidence because the existing legislation makes no mention of it. However, as there have been some allegations made in this area the Department has taken on to its work schedule a review of the air navigation regulations which relates to the consumption of alcohol by flight crew, cabin attendants, passengers and air traffic services staff. It has not yet been able to complete its investigation of the matter. In view of the very small number of complaints that have been lodged they are not recorded as anything other than a routine priority. Specifically, it is not planned to introduce either random or pre-flight breath testing for pilots. However, the matter is under review and if it is essential at any stage to take action in this area, the Department will approach it with a judicious, reasonable and mature approach. We do not believe the matter is one of any major public concern.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the guidelines for superannuation schemes announced by the Government on 16 December last which, inter alia, suggested that public sector superannuation schemes could be enhanced by applying the 3 per cent productivity claim to improved vesting conditions for fund members. Does the Minister agree that it is likely that these improvements will lead to considerably increased membership of public sector schemes by attracting many of the close to one million employees who are currently not members of such schemes? Has the Federal Government considered the potential cost to it, State governments and their statutory authorities, and thus ultimately the taxpayer, of a sudden increase in membership? Does the Minister agree that this could amount to several hundred million dollars in extra contributions by public sector employers?

—Within the Commonwealth Public Service, permanent employees must be members of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, as I am sure Senator Messner knows. On the other matters, I have actually been involved in that quite directly because of my responsibility with the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. No decisions have yet been made on the precise details of the way in which the CSS, and statutory authority employees who are members of the CSS, will be dealt with in the context of the productivity case under the guidelines announced by Mr Keating and Mr Willis last December. A number of propositions are under consideration. If the policy decisions that are finally made increase the cost, including the emerging cost, to the Budget of the people covered by the CSS, I would expect a commensurate change in the contributions made by statutory authorities.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Just so that the Minister understands the point of my question, I am also speaking of State government employees and their statutory authorities which will, of course, have contributions made by their employers to the superannuation funds and I am applying the same principle to them. How would the Minister cope with that problem?
—I have not been involved in that. I do not regard that as part of my responsibility or of the Federal Government's responsibility. That is something for the States to sort out.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS REPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In view of comments made in a recent report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs can the Minister inform the Senate what procedures the Government intends to follow to ensure that all Australians have equal voting rights?

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. There are no recommendations in that report whatsoever. I ask you to rule the question out of order. There are no recommendations in the Senate exposure report, none whatsoever.
—On the point of order: I refer to comments rather than recommendations.
—The honourable senator referred to the Constitutional Committee. I am wondering whether he meant the Constitutional Committee or the Electoral Reform Committee.
—Order! If I am assured by the honourable senator that certain comments in respect of that report were made, I will allow the question. I call the Minister representing the Attorney-General.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken Senator Black to be referring to the exposure report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which exposes itself to the extent of indicating that on balance it had a preference for an approach to human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the delicacy and sensitivity of this from Senator Missen, Senator Puplick and Senator Hill who have been engaged in the most spectacular frenetic gymnastics this chamber has witnessed for some years in explaining why it is they are opposed to the Bill of Rights, although they are prepared to sign their name to an exposure report, the balance of argument in which pointed overwhelmingly in the direction of a particular approach. Be that as it may. Let me take the opportunity of this question to indicate formally for the record, on behalf of the Attorney-General, what his and the Government's response is to what people have construed as the conclusions of the Senate Standing Committee report so far as the application of a Bill of Rights to the States is concerned and in particular so far as the desirability of guarantees of fair electoral practice being incorporated in such overriding Commonwealth legislation is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: The short point is this: The Government's position is that it will not revise its present attitude as to the appropriate content of a Commonwealth Bill of Rights in the light of that report-however Senator Missen likes to describe it-although it would be acknowledged in some quarters, including opposite, that there are a number of attractive features of that report. Apart from some minor Government amendment, the Government position is that the Bill should be passed in substantially the form in which it was passed by the House of Representatives in November Last year. The main point of Senator Black's question was: What would we be prepared to do so far as Queensland electoral laws are concerned?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. This is dealing with a matter that is before the Senate. I would have thought it would have been more appropriate for the Minister to answer these matters in the course of his reply in the debate.

—Order! I agree that it is getting very close to a matter that is before the Senate. The honourable senator has been asked a question in relation to comments appearing in a Senate Committee report and to that extent the question is in order. How the Minister so chooses to answer it is a matter for him. I call the Minister.

—The Attorney-General has made it clear that the Commonwealth does not accept undemocratic State electoral laws, in whichever State they appear, and this matter will be the subject of an early reference to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which will replace, when the legislation is passed by this Parliament, the present part time, and to that extent perhaps less effective than it might have been, Human Rights Commission appointed by the Fraser Government. Depending upon the report of that new Commission finding State laws to be in conflict with the guarantees in the Bill of Rights, which may not be a totally unlikely outcome, the Commonwealth will give the States an opportunity to bring their laws into compliance. If such legislative action is not forthcoming the Commonwealth will then enact overriding legislation to ensure electoral justice. Such legislation will be separate to and additional to the Bill of Rights under a provisional timetable drawn up by the Attorney-General. The expected time for the introduction of this legislation would be in the Budget sittings. With this undertaking from the Attorney-General and the Government we would, of course, expect that the Bill of Rights and associated legislation will be speedily passed by the Senate as it is imperative that the new Commission be set up as soon as possible.

—Will the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that the Treasurer is proposing a 6.5c a litre reduction in the price of petrol? How has this amount been calculated? Why does it appear to be based on an arbitrary one percentage point cut to the general inflation rate rather than the much greater reduction in the underlying cost of oil which would imply, as we noted earlier in Question Time, an 11c a litre cut in the price of petrol? Also I ask: Does the Treasurer's proposal mean a $700m increase in the deficit and, in this light, how does the Government explain its repeated commitment to the promised tax cuts?
—The answer to the first part of the question is no, and all the other parts are therefore redundant.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen the statement in today's Age newspaper that the Government of the Republic of Korea, which is implacably opposed to constitutional amendment, has responded to moves calling for reform by threatening to gaol all signatories of petitions for constitutional reform for terms of up to seven years and the detention of leading Opposition figures? Does this statement represent the views of the Republic of Korea? If so, what is the attitude of our Government to such views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The brief I have from the Minister for Foreign Affairs is in the following terms: The Australian Government is aware of the difference of opinion between the Government and Opposition in the Republic of Korea on this subject. The Opposition wishes to have the current electoral college presidential system replaced by a direct election. This view is not supported by the ROK Government. The Australian Government has made representations to the ROK Government expressing regret at the measures adopted last week against the Opposition's signatory campaign. We regret the arrests of members of the Opposition and hope that they will be speedily released.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hayden said in his statement of 26 November last year that he hoped the political liberalisation to which the Republic of Korea was committed would be achieved by 1988. The Australian Government hopes that the ROK Government will restate its political liberalisation program that has been interrupted in recent months by measures taken against students, journalists and Opposition politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government intend to make any overtures to the South Korean Government regarding the arrest of these leaders?

—I have indicated that we have already made representations last week expressing regret at the measures taken against the Opposition signatory campaign. I have now indicated publicly on behalf of the Government that we regret the arrests of members of the Opposition. I will refer Senator McIntosh's question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he thinks any further action of the kind the honourable senator suggests is appropriate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS: TELEVISION AND RADIO SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the report of the Task Force on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting and Communications, which was tabled in October 1984 and which recognised the desperate need for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to control radio and television, and to the Government's response in November 1985 endorsing the urgency of that framework. I ask: Why was the meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Minister for Communications and senior representatives of the Island Co-ordinating Council planned for this Friday cancelled? Secondly, why were the Aboriginal people and the Torres Strait Islanders on the islands in the north of Queensland not given the opportunity to involve themselves in the inquiries into the commercial television licence issue, as were the Aboriginal people in Alice Springs?
—I will have to refer that question to the Minister and get a reply for Senator Macklin as soon as possible.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health comment on the recently released list of charges issued by the Australian Association of Surgeons? Can he say whether the claim by Dr Aroney that the fees of general surgeons in Australia are much lower than in any other Western country is true? To what extent will these proposed increased charges be passed on to patients? What is the Government's response to the list of increased charges as recommended by the surgeons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the suggested list by the Australian Association of Surgeons, which obviously Senator Crowley has, too. The first matter I saw raised was the matter that Dr Aroney raised when he claimed that Australian surgeons were paid less than surgeons in equivalent Western countries. That is clearly not true. In fact, the proportion of surgeons in full time employment who receive less remuneration than Australian surgeons is in general higher in most other comparable countries. Certainly, in some sections of the United States surgeons receive considerably higher incomes than they do in Australia, but they are gross incomes. If one takes into account the costs that they have to pay there, particularly insurance costs, one sees that their incomes are comparable. Obviously any increase in fees of this type will be passed on to the patients. Fees of some of the levels suggested would not be covered by any private medical insurance in this country; therefore the fees would be passed on. That would not affect those on high incomes but would have a considerable effect on low income people.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that surgeons have contacted me declaring that they think the action of the Australian Association of Surgeons is irresponsible, appalling and does nothing to assist the debate on health insurance and delivery in this country. If this sort of activity increases, if some surgeons-and only some surgeons-are to charge the sorts of fees that they are charging and if they are likely to take the actions that the orthopaedic surgeons in the Australian Capital Territory are threatening to take, whereby they will not treat any public patients at all, both the Federal and State governments will need to consider the actions they will take.

In the case of the orthopaedic surgeons in this country, they are not only in a monopoly in their own profession but also have a monopoly over the training of those who come into that profession. In fact, they severely limit the number of people they will allow to enter the profession of orthopaedic surgery and I might add that they are very vicious about any woman who might want to enter it. I think it is time that we did what other Western countries do-and apparently Dr Aroney wants us to copy other Western countries-and take the training and, effectively, the accreditation of orthopaedic surgeons out of the hands of that small group of orthopaedic surgeons who are taking advantage of their position and creating the biggest and strictest closed shop in this community. In fact they have created a situation in which patients, governments, medical administrators and everyone else have no say in the delivery of their services. I believe that the time is coming when we will have to take action if some surgeons, particularly orthopaedic surgeons, continue to act in this irresponsible way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Whilst acknowledging the Government's support of the building industry in the Australian Capital Territory and elsewhere in resisting the unlawful pursuit of the 3.8 per cent national wage case flow-on by the Builders Labourers Federation, I ask the Minister about statements made by the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council suggesting violence, and the President of the Trades and Labour Council and Secretary of the BLF, Mr O'Dea, who was reported in today's Canberra Times, when he quoted Henry Lawson saying:

QUESTION.PARA: They needn't say the fault is ours, if blood should stain the wattle.
In the light of House statements, what action is the Government taking to protect the community and individual union members from violence and property from vandalism?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know about the Opposition-it seems to want to have it all ways. We were being urged to deal with the Builders Labourers Federation last year-that was the flavour of the month with the Opposition. It was often alleged that we were not dealing with the union strongly enough. Now that the Government and the respective State governments have taken very firm action, including action which is discriminatory in a sense against contractors who do deals with the BLF, Senator Reid asks me what we are going to do about the consequences of that action, as if those consequences had not been foreseen. I make it quite clear that right from the beginning it was envisaged that there would be difficulties in dealing with the BLF's position, particularly on building sites in New South Wales and, perhaps to a lesser extent, in the Australian Capital Territory. I am not knowledgable of or, indeed, particularly interested in what the two people said who were quoted in the Canberra Times this morning. These things are inevitable and it was likely that they would say those sorts of things. Having said all that, I am sure that appropriate action has been taken to prevent as far as possible violence from occurring on building sites arising from the decisions which have been taken. Finally, I should point out that Senator Reid's question is appropriately a matter for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, not me-but my answer is all right, of course!

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer him to suggestions, often vague and imprecise, made by the privatisation freaks of the Liberal Party and floated from time to time by right wing think tanks, that there should be provisions that allow for opting out of the existing industrial relations system. Can the Minister say whether these opting out proposals would achieve the objectives their advocates claim? Is there any further information on what effects an opting out provision would have on the economy and on industrial relations, given the Australian political, economic and institutional setting?

—On a point of order, Mr President: That is an extremely broad question asking the Minister simply to canvass policies which are quite imprecisely defined. I suggest that there is no way in which the Minister could address that, other than to debate very broad issues of policy. I suggest that the question is out of order.

—Order! The Minister is entitled to give a response as far as his responsibilities as a Minister in this direction are concerned. However, I advise him of the consequences of stepping outside standing order 100 as far as debate is concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware, as I expect everyone would be aware, that the possibility of a radical new industrial relations policy under which anybody who wanted to could opt out of the prices and incomes accord has been pushed with some zeal for a very considerable time, in particular by the Leader of the Opposition. However, I notice that in what I believe is his most recent comment on the subject-it was published in the Australian Financial Review last Monday-as part of an interview with Greg Hywood, Mr Howard was asked a question about the opting out proposal. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: A lot of them would want it so that they can make sensible arrangements on hours, holiday loadings and penalties and that kind of thing and just adjust it. I mean, I have given the example of the firm in Marrickville, whose work force of almost all married women and who have young children at school, and they petitioned to the management to start half an hour earlier and have half an hour for lunch so they can pick their children up from school.

So we have now progressed from a radical alternative wage fixing policy which was to apply across the board to anybody who wanted to completely opt out of the centralised wage fixing system to one which apparently leaves the centralised wage fixing system in place. What started out as a revolutionary wages policy has degenerated to the point where it becomes a policy about changing the lunch hour. That is typical of the attitude which the Opposition has adopted on this question and indeed, on a number of other questions. It is also typical of the policy direction-principally of back-tracking-which the Opposition has followed in the five months that it has had its present Leader. In other words, the Liberal Party elected, perhaps by accident, to its leadership an ideologue who very quickly went to water.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is now clearly getting into the realms of debate. I ask him to return to a definite response to the question.
—Certainly, Mr President. I guess this explains why the wets, the dries and the pragmatists are all fed up with the Leader of the Opposition because--
—Order! The Minister is clearly ignoring my directive.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following the answer given to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle yesterday relating to the productivity claim currently before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, does the Government's support take account of industries, such as farming, where there is no productivity increase and where in fact there has been a considerable profitability decline? What will the Government's attitude to the Commission be in these cases?
—I do not understand the question. Senator Archer alleges that there has been no productivity increase in the farm sector. I would doubt that.
—He said `profitability'.

—I beg your pardon: He said `productivity' and, in the last part of the questions, he said `profitability'. I agree with that. But he began by saying `productivity'. He said that there had been no increase in productivity in the farm sector. I do not think that is correct. But, for the sake of a hypothetical answer to a hypothetical question based on falsehood, let me say that I believe consideration has been taken in respect of small employers, who have announced their intention of advancing a collective position to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the course of the productivity case. If my recollection is correct, they were specifically placed in a different category from large employers. I will have the question directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, whose responsibility it is, and provide an answer as soon as possible.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT
