TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Vanstone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's obsession with its public image which has led to a cynical betrayal of Australia's youth and a policy failure in Priority One.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some pleasure but some regret that I propose the following matter as a matter of public importance for discussion today:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's obsession with its public image which has led to a cynical betrayal of Australia's youth and a policy failure in Priority One.

The coalition is gravely concerned for the future of young Australians. It is appalled at the Australian Labor Party's brutal determination to sell the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and to ensure its own re-election rather than to assist young Australians constructively with their problems. In August 1985 the Prime Minister announced that Australia's youth were the Government's No. 1 priority. He launched the Priority One: Young Australia scheme and, symbolically, promised that in the coming year 10,000 traineeships would be made available. The reality is that the Prime Minister, having spent over $1.4m on a phone-in alone and over $2m across the board advertising himself and his Government, has yet again left the youth of Australia in the lurch.

Investigations I have made have revealed that, despite the number of agreements for traineeships which this Government talks about, there are fewer than 600 trainees in place today, half way through the year. We are half way through the year and we were promised that there would be 10,000 traineeships. A 6 per cent achievement rate is lousy. It is a total failure. I am well aware that Priority One is a scheme that involves much more than traineeships. However, all Australians have been invited by the publicity and by the Prime Minister's symbolic promise to concentrate on the traineeships. They are the main plank of the Priority One program. In implementing the main plank of that program the Government has failed. The Opposition is very concerned about that. To be sure there is a political point to be made. It is a delight for an opposition when a government fails in implementing a policy. At the same time, it is very depressing to make the point that young Australians yet again have been left in the lurch. I take it from comments in Hansard that the Australian Democrats agree with us that Priority One is a failure. In October, Senator Siddons said in this chamber:
There has been a lot of talk. There has been virtually no action and there is still, as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, no positive solution to this problem.

Let no one think that it is just the Opposition beating up a drama. The facts are there; the Government has failed. We say the Government has failed. I take it from Hansard that the Democrats agree that the Government has failed. As an opposition and as individuals we care because we represent the full spectrum of people in Australia. We have friends, sons and daughters, nieces and nephews in the dole queue. Their desperation, disillusionment and frustration is our desperation, disillusionment and frustration. It should be the Government's.

We hope that we will hear in this debate acknowledgment of the problems with Priority One. We hope we will hear constructive comments indicating that the Government is taking steps to remedy the problems and taking steps to remedy this public relations disaster. We hope that we will hear real details of actual achievements for young unemployed people, either being in on the job training or being in off the job training. We have raised this matter today because we care about young Australians and we hope to see some improvement. Regrettably, we expect to hear, as we did the last time we raised this matter for debate, a tired litany about what was wrong with the Fraser Government and we will hear a tired litany of employment statistics for that period. The Government will go back to the past. We will also be presented with statistics which the Government would have us believe show that the unemployment situation has drastically improved. These statistics will not show us that Priority One is a success. We expect to hear a tired litany of the past. What we want to hear is what the Government is going to do today about today's problems. Honourable senators opposite are in government. They hold the reins. They are going the wrong way.

We do not expect to hear in the statistics, which hopefully the Government will provide, that there suddenly has been a flourish of private sector traineeships. We do not expect to hear the Government still clinging vainly to its target of 10,000 traineeships in 1985-86. Nor, of course, do we expect to hear the current facts about youth unemployment or employment in general. The Government, of course, will not tell us that the average duration of unemployment has increased from 39.9 weeks when it first came to government to almost 52 weeks in July 1985. The Government will not tell us about that. Nor, I suppose, will the Government tell us about the latest unemployment figures for the youth of Australia, which have increased from 20.8 per cent to 21.4 per cent.

No doubt the Government will not tell us that there are 1,800 more women looking for work this year than were looking for work last year. No doubt the Government also will not tell us that there are 8,400 more Australians looking for part time work this year than were looking for part time work last year. I include some of these figures because I have a vain hope that in this debate the Government will resist the opportunity which it took last time to refer to the period of the Fraser Government and cite statistics from that time. I cited those statistics previously to show the Government that it is not doing as well as it believes. We can also cite statistics, but that will get us nowhere. We are hoping that the Government will address the problem.

The announcement of Priority One was made with enormous fanfare. The Prime Minister took television time. I say it was to advertise himself; he says it was to advertise Priority One. An enormous amount of money was spent on the announcement of that program.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is priority one.

—As my colleague said, the Prime Minister considers himself a No. 1 priority, but not the youth of Australia, and how right he is when he says that. The Government has spent an enormous amount on publicity. In addition to the television program which was developed and which was then shown in the cinemas around Australia so that young Australians could watch it when they went to the movies during their holidays, the Prime Minister has spoken to the Press and he has spoken on radio. He has been in Sydney, he has been in Melbourne and he has been in Adelaide, but he has not been in the dole queue where the young people are. If my colleagues and I have our way, that is exactly where he will end up.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand from another of my colleagues that the Government is now investing in painting big signs on the walls of delicatessens and newsagencies saying: `Priority One-what a terrific scheme'. None of these signs have a contact number for a young unemployed person to find out where that person can participate in this Priority One scheme. Senator Cook said in the last debate on this subject that this was a positive, aggressive and inspired campaign. It is a positive, aggressive and inspired campaign to advertise the Prime Minister.

The very few traineeships that have developed lack a diversified base. They are mostly in the clerical area. Senator Cook said that they would be in the retail, finance, tourism and hospitality areas. I do not think that he has spoken to the Australian Bankers Association or to a very wide group of business people, who say that they will not go along with these schemes and that they will not work. The honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Ros Kelly, said that the Priority One program was a three-pronged attack on the problems of youth in Australia. I say that it is a very blunt prong. It is a recycling of programs rather than the initiating of innovative solutions. It is an absolute disaster. To indicate that, we should note some of the skills that young Australians are going to acquire if they take up a traineeship in the Public Service. They are going to acquire transferable skills such as communication, numeracy and literacy, and practical and manual skills. I would have thought that they learned all those things at school and would be well under way in that regard.

As I have endeavoured to point out, the Prime Minister is very much concerned with himself as a No. 1 priority. A couple of weeks ago, he went along to a Youth Affairs Council of Australia conference. Having promised the conference to stay for the morning, he stayed for 50 minutes. He spoke at them. He delivered a preprepared speech and then he left. The youth present were so annoyed that they had a little meeting on the following day to express their dissatisfaction to the people who organised the conference that the Prime Minister had been allowed to use the youth affairs conference and to use the youth of Australia to push his own position. At no stage when he was there did he ask for questions or invite comments. I understand that he spoke to one young person and, roughly, what he said was: `Would you like to turn around and have your picture taken with me at this conference?'. That is a disgrace. I refer honourable senators to the newspaper headlines such as: `Hawke on the hot-line; outside a few heated words'. What do the young people of Australia say? This is what one of them said:
He's really arrogant, giving the whole image thing to the media, but nothing to us . . . When he just drove off it reflected his whole attitude to the young.

That is where the Prime Minister stands and that is where this Government stands. We could also ask ourselves what has happened to the results of the phone-in? Is it true, as some sources say, that one-third of the people who phoned in made complaints? Will we be told that or will it all be hidden from us? Why, when the Youth Affairs Council offered to monitor the phone-in, did the Government refuse the offer? I say that the Government refused because it wanted to keep the results to itself. They would be too embarrassing for it.

Some of us may wonder why the Government proceeded with this program when there were many doubts about it in the very beginning, and those doubts have not been put to rest. One needs only to flip through the newspapers-Mr Hawke does not even have to leave his office-to read of the doubts in the community. I refer to headlines such as: `Call for agreement on youth policy' and `Youth scheme's planner now doubts its success'-that must have been pleasant reading for Mr Hawke. What about other headlines entitled: `TAFE now ``dumping ground'' for jobless'; `Doubts over youth training scheme'; `TAFE warns on job scheme'; and `Youth training collapse denied'. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, with a promise of 10,000 traineeships and the delivery of under 600, how can one possibly say that this scheme has not collapsed?

Another headline is entitled `Bungling will destroy youth plan, says union'. That leads me to the next point I want to make. The Government has said all along that it believes in consensus. It believes in tripartite negotiations. Mr Hawke would say: `Only that way can we go forward as a unified Australia'. He wants consultation between the Government, unions and big business. The trouble in the case of Australia's No. 1 priority is that the unions were left out. The Government thought it had the Australian Council of Trade Unions under control. The Prime Minister advertised the scheme as a goer, without having the unions' consent. That was just disgraceful.

When someone in my office made an off the cuff inquiry as to how things were going with respect to one plank of the traineeships, a member of the Public Service said: `Things are looking like we are getting ready to roll'. Six months after the Government has spent all that money and six months after the Prime Minister said that the trainee scheme was the Government's No.1 priority, we were told that things were looking like they were getting ready to roll. The Government would not want to tell me that it is getting on with the unions now because it has brought the Federated Clerks Union on side. All it would be met with is a long list of unions that it has not brought on side. That was a fatal mistake for the Government to make in a scheme that is meant to have at its heart and as its major concern the youth of Australia.

Let me give honourable senators some more examples of what the Prime Minister could read in the papers. If he is not prepared to consult with the unions, let him look at the headlines in the paper such as: `Bungling will destroy youth plan, says union'; `Discord threatens ACT traineeships'; and `Unions reject ``cock-eyed'' youth job scheme'. How clearly do we have to spell it out to this man that he does not have the unions on side? He does not have consensus and that is why the real No. 1 priority is not working. I refer to another headline: `Union concern on traineeship plans', and on they go.

As I indicated, Mr Hawke promised in this year-we may as well use the scale that he has given us as the scale to judge him by-10,000 traineeships. I estimate that 600, perhaps 700 at the most, have been taken on as trainees. To be generous I will give the Government 1,000 and say that there are some positions available in the pipeline of which the Canberra Public Service is not yet aware. That estimate makes the Prime Minister's promise worth 10c in the dollar. That is a very bad bankruptcy. Young Australians through the polls have invested in Mr Hawke. They have invested their confidence and their hopes and they have been very badly let down. Let us go into a bit more detail. We were told in a debate in this chamber in August last year that 20 per cent of these schemes would be taken up by the private sector. Yet we find that nearly all the traineeships that are now on the go have been taken up by the public sector-not 20 per cent, but nearly all of them. Where is the private sector involvement? I can tell honourable senators what we have been able to find with regard to the private sector involvement. a joint private sector-State involvement with 19 trainees is in place in Western Australia. Nineteen of the nearly 600 traineeships are in the private sector. The rest are desperate attempts to suck the unemployed in Australia into the Public Service to make this scheme look good. It is an absolute disgrace.

Some comment has been made that Mr Hawke conceded that his program would not make the grade and that may be the number of traineeships would not get to 10,000. I can assure honourable senators that when he spoke to the YACA conference-I have to say that the speech that he was going to give has the words `check against delivery' on it so I do not know whether he said exactly what he was planning to say-he said:
I am glad to say, we have already made a solid start.
Six hundred lousy traineeships are in place out of 10,000, and he says it is a solid start. He is absolutely kidding himself. He went on to say:
At the same time, the Government accepts that it may have set an over-ambitious target for itself in aiming to create 10,000 traineeships by July of this year.
But did he plan to back off? No. Ever confident, he intended to go on. He stated:
However, we remain optimistic that both this target and the long term goal of 75,000 traineeships by 1988-89 can be achieved.
I cannot see how a man who must know that the program had only achieved 600 out of the 10,000 could possibly say he is optimistic about reaching the figure of 10,000 by July.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is deception.

—It is absolute deception. The Government has given in a little. It appointed a task force to oversee the implementation of this program. It has brought in from the cold the critics, put them on the task force and made them responsible for advising the government about what it should do. The ironic thing is that it was told in the report of the Kirby Committee into Labour Market Programs that it should have set up this task force, but it did not want to take that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that I accept that the traineeships are only part of the Priority One program, that there are other elements. There is a rationalisation of welfare payments to young people. But the Government should turn its mind to the gap it has created in welfare payments to young people since it came to office. It has more than doubled the difference between the unemployment benefit and the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance since it came to office. It has widened the gap and them-big deal-in Priority One it promised to close the gap. But it does not say anything about a change in means testing those benefits. So while it says `We will close the gap and have an equality of benefits', it leaves the means testing as it is. That does not provide a true equality of benefit.

I have tried today, as simply and as clearly as I can, to spell out to the Government that the Opposition does not regard it as acceptable for it to tell the nation that the youth of Australia are its number one priority when the Prime Minister and its re-election is its number one priority. We do not regard 6c in the dollar as a fair return on promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has labelled Priority One as a cynical exercise. I wonder how it defines `cynical'. I have sat in this chamber and have seen the Liberal Party reverse its position on a constitutional matter on two occasions. I do not refer to when I first came here, but in 1974 the Government proposed a referendum on the same principle, and the Liberals opposed it. In 1977 when they were in government the same proposal was put forward, but it was beaten. In 1984 they were back in opposition and, lo and behold, they were opposing the same proposal. That may be a good definition of `cynical' for us to begin with. I am always reminded of the great Labor politician of the 1920s and 1930s, Frank Anstey, who described the old conservative Prime Minister Bruce in these terms: He promised the masses everything and then delighted the bosses by giving them nothing. Nothing better sums up the Liberal Party's attitude than that great saying by Frank Anstey.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone has lectured us and anticipated the debate today by saying that she bets that all the Government speakers will talk about the Fraser years. I would hate to disappoint her. The disgraceful attitude of members of the Liberal Party, the things that they did during that period, have been catalogued in this place time and again. We have lifted our voices time and again to criticise them and to point out what they have done in regard to youth unemployment. We do not have to catalogue those criticisms today. The record speaks for itself. One catalogues them only for one reason. If people who are critical today are to have any credibility, surely one of the measures of credibility is past record. Where was Senator Vanstone during the Fraser years? Did she get up at meetings of the State Council of the Liberal Party and attack the Fraser Government over youth unemployment? Of course, she did not. She did not say anything. She is an establishment person and that is why she is here today. She never once opened her mouth to attack the Fraser Government or any other Liberal government. She accuses us of cynicism. The previous Government in particular contributed grossly to youth unemployment in this country. What did the previous Government do about it? It introduced the community youth support scheme and then, through Mr Brown, it tried to renege on it. It did absolutely nothing.

The interesting thing about the debate today is that we have heard 20 minutes of criticism. I accept that that is the role of the Opposition. But it would have been interesting just once to hear one policy suggestion from the Opposition. It did not put forward one policy suggestion as to how it would deal with youth unemployment. All it can do is nitpick at the scheme we have developed. Let me turn to another point. I imagine that if Senator Vanstone had been in charge of the United States space program in the late 1950s and one or two little problems had occurred, she would have cancelled it. The program would not have sent a rocket to the moon 10 years later. If one rocket had blown up she would have cancelled the program on the spot because she could not have taken one little setback. That is her approach to this scheme. We promised in 1983 to create 500,000 jobs. Honourable senators opposite scoffed at our aim of creating 500,000 jobs. They said it cannot be done and that we were misleading the public. We have already created over 600,000 jobs and we have not even been in government for three years. The Opposition has not mentioned that point. Of course, it will not mention it.

We do place a high priority on the youth of this country. It is interesting that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has addressed the nation once. Fraser used to do so every few months, but the Prime Minister has done so once. The one issue about which he was so concerned that he addressed the country was youth unemployment. That was the one question that was raised. Priority One, of course, is not just about traineeships. If one listened to Senator Vanstone, one would think it was just about traineeships. She has never taken the time to look at the totality of the program. She just criticises the aspect of traineeships. But it is a long term approach. The Opposition expects miracle results in six months when it had seven years of failure. It is an absolutely hypocritical approach to expect miracle results. The program was announced in August, but the Opposition expects miracle results by February, even though every time it approached the economy it bungled it. We have put in place clear macro-economic policies that highlight the fact that what this country needs is economic growth and improved employment prospects. We know that unemployment is down. We know that 600,000 jobs have been created. We know that the participation rate has been rising. The one weak area, according to any statistics, is youth unemployment. I point out that it is not necessarily only a problem that Australia faces. Every other country in the world has had a similar problem.

We are aiming to put in place a total package-not just traineeships-so that every person in the youth area will have some function, some particular role to play. There is a whole range of elements. As I have said before, we will introduce a new traineeship system for the young. We will introduce a new integrated wage subsidy program called Job Start. We are providing additional student places in higher education. We are reviewing the Commonwealth's role in technical and further education. We are rationalising income arrangements for young people.

I would like to refer to some of the current achievements of this government in this area. The most recent figures I have, for December 1985, show that, in regard to the 540,000 jobs that have been created since we came to office, 100,000 have been taken up by young people. I do not even need to contrast what happened in the previous two years of the Liberal Government. The unemployment rate for 15-to-19-year-olds had fallen, at that stage, from 22.7 per cent to 20.7 per cent. Senator Vanstone says that it has gone up slightly since then. Obviously, she has never heard of school leavers. That shows how she is in contact with youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone up and you know it.

—The honourable senator should return to pre-season training. They will be missing her. In addition, substantial progress has been made towards achieving other elements of the Priority One strategy. Let us look at one of the key measures-retention rates in schools. In 1982 retention rates were at 36.3 per cent. Currently the figure is 45 per cent, a massive increase over the figures that the previous Government was able to achieve. As well, there has been an 11 per cent increase in the last two years in post-compulsory education. The Opposition tried to be critical of our trying to find out the needs of youth.

SPEECH.PARA: I imagine the Liberal policy in this area would be to make up a policy and implement it. We sought, very clearly, to go out and survey the needs of youth. One of the ways we did that was though the phone in; another was through the youth assembly scheme. A lot of different factors emerged and a lot of analysis was useful. But clearly the first priority of youth today is the search for work and the dignity associated with that particular area. The second concern which emerged was, primarily, with the role, definition and processes of the education system, whether the youth thought they got a satisfactory education and whether they thought they could relate to that educational process. There are naturally other issues such as the concern for the environment; worry about nuclear war and the use and abuse of drugs. These all came through as major issues. I think it was a very valuable process to go through to attempt to find out the needs of the youth.

I will now turn to the traineeship scheme. Whilst I said it is not the only element of Priority One, it is clearly the centrepiece. We set ourselves an enormous task-75,000 traineeships between 1987 and 1988. That is twice the annual intake of apprentices. It is an enormous task for any reforming government to undertake. I pointed out before that when we undertook to create 500,000 jobs all those opposite took a very cynical attitude to it. The moment we achieved that target and exceeded it by 100,000, there was not one bleat, not one mention of that target from the Opposition. Why not? Because, as we all know, oppositions like economic doom because that is related to their own political success. While talking about political success, we have just seen how successful the Liberal Party has been in South Australia, where another Labor Government has been endorsed.

The system of traineeships is, principally, directed to school leavers and involves a minimum of one year's training, including 13 weeks off the job. The Commonwealth is providing $1,000 to employers and $2,000 to disadvantaged trainees. We have already had talks in the small business area, but for traineeships to succeed it is clear that we need co-operation among unions, employers, and the States. No one can walk into this chamber and say that it is easy to get co-operation, not even a Labor politician. The height of the success story would be to come in here and say it is easy to get co-operation among trade unions, employers and the States with all their conflicting interests. It does take time to develop these particular schemes to make them successful. If we are not on track in the first few months, what should we do? We have not heard the Liberal Party say what we should do; it has said what we should not do. What should we do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Admit failure.
—Admit failure for what, Senator Vanstone?
—You promised 10,000. You are not going to get it.

—When the time comes, Senator Vanstone, we will assess that and see how far on track we are. When we look at the credibility of those opposite and ask them to develop policies in almost any area, at the moment they say: `Oh, well, we will produce them later just before the election, but we don't want to know about the previous Government'. Those opposite have suffered political amnesia. They know nothing. They do not know that those years exist. It is like a missing six years or eight years that never occurred. It is a bit like me remembering Collingwood Football Club defeats. I do not remember them any more, they just disappear because it is too painful. Those opposite are in exactly the same position. It does affect their credibility to enter debates today and say: `You are not good enough'. We are entitled to question their credentials. Their political credentials in this country are that they have reduced this country to its knees. Unemployment and inflation have skyrocketed. We had a negative rate of economic growth in this country under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Our macroeconomic policies are working and that has got those opposite scared. They are already talking about the next election because they are scared of what will happen at the next election, and with due cause and reason. In the two major States recently, where there have not been that many local issues where the Liberals have been put to the test and have tried to run on Federal issues, they have been annihilated, and so they should.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring it on. Bring on an election. We would love it.

—Senator Peter Baume invites us to bring on an election and take the two Houses out of kilter again-typical Menzies response from Senator Peter Baume. However, I have no doubt the honourable senator will make the offer any time. We will check with No. 3 and No. 4 on his ticket and see how happy they are. The honourable senator has so much ability that he is bound to be No. 1 or No. 2 and he will not have to worry. We might try the weaker links in the Liberal Party in New South Wales and see if they want a double dissolution and an election right now. If they do, the drycleaners would do a great business, that is all I can say.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to the traineeship scheme, Senator Vanstone has asked whether there are any problems. Yes, there have been administrative problems associated with this particular scheme. I notice that Senator Puplick has revived from his faint about an early election and is contributing again. We admit there have been some problems in implementing this scheme, but we had problems in implementing the Medibank and Medicare scheme. No scheme comes in without some bureaucratic bungles.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the bureaucrats' fault, is it?

—No, it is not the bureaucrats' fault. What I am saying is that any scheme introduced by any government can run into bureaucratic problems. It is inevitable that it will run into problems. The scheme has been off and running for five or six months and those opposite are trying to cut its throat. They do not really want it to work. We know that, for political reasons. Those opposite are trying to cut its throat. What I am saying is that a lot of those problems are being ironed out at present. We have had a history and this particular Government, unlike the previous Government, is meeting these particular targets.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, if we are to have successful debates in this chamber it would be very nice to have two sides and two policies. I know it is the role of an Opposition to be critical. I went through this myself for 18 to 20 months. Anything the Government did we got up and knocked. I understand that; that is the role of the Opposition. If those opposite are not doing that, they should not pick up their pay packet. But at the same time I remember going to interminable committee meetings and interminable policy launches where we put forward an alternative as to what we would do. What have we heard today? We have not heard one alternative. How would those opposite deal with youth unemployment? The only thing I have ever heard from the Liberal Party in the last three years is that we should cut the wages, slash the wages in half. They think that suddenly the problem of youth unemployment will go away.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is not on our policies, mate.

—But to have the slightest shred of credibility, surely an alternative has got to be put forward; or is the honourable senator so pessimistic and such a sad case that she knows she is condemned to that side of the House for the next 15 years? Is the honourable senator telling us that if those opposite put a major effort into developing a policy it will become outdated in three years time and they only have to go and do the whole thing again? Of course not. I am sure somewhere, maybe not in the Senate, maybe in the deeper recesses of the House of Representatives, someone will be working on solutions to youth unemployment. Surely when honourable senators opposite go on the interminable trips that leave this Parliament and tour around the countryside into Europe and elsewhere they are looking at youth guarantee schemes and how they are working. Surely someone opposite, even Senator Peter Baume, who is a very humanitarian person, is thinking about youth unemployment and coming up with a solution. Those opposite have not come up with a solution today. They have contributed absolutely nothing to the debate but have been merely nitpicking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Priority One scheme is a scheme of great vision; it is a scheme that has had a degree of difficulties. Senator Vanstone goes off on a great diatribe about the Prime Minister. I know what that is like. We used to feel the same about Menzies. We used to admire him and we used to hate him-both things at the one time. I suspect that has happened to Senator Vanstone and that came through in the bile of her remarks today. All I can say in ending about the Prime Minister is: `Eat your heart out'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by thanking Senator Vanstone for the advertisement she gave the Australian Democrats at the beginning of this debate. Her perception is accurate-the Australian Democrats believe that the Priority One: Young Australia employment scheme is a failure, for reasons which I will describe later in this speech. The failure of the program is a classic demonstration of the fact that pious hopes and a smooth public relations operation which ignore the real issues of unemployment are not good enough. With all respect to the gentlemen concerned, I doubt whether the high level task force which has been appointed this month to try to bail it out will be able to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear.

SPEECH.PARA: A major Democrats' concern with Priority One is that it makes the same mistake the Government has perpetuated for some years; it provides for training but not permanent jobs. I have discussed this point with many social workers and others concerned with young people and there is no doubt at all to my mind that the experience of having a job for a short time, then not having a job, is probably more shattering to a young person than never having had one at all. The Government is not doing its duty by the unemployed, especially the young unemployed, by allowing that situation to continue. It ought to address that situation directly, but it is not doing so. The ideal corollary to Priority One-one might even say a necessary corollary-would be an economic situation where jobs were available for the young people trained under the scheme. If that does not happen, the scheme has no point.

One could say that if Priority One has any good point at all, it is the intention to provide 15 per cent of the scholarships available to Aborigines and other disadvantaged people, such as people with disabilities and non-English speaking migrants. It could be argued that that figure of 15 per cent in the category is too low, but at least it is a good start for one of the most serious unemployment problems. In the strong competition for available jobs it is the disadvantaged and the weak who suffer most. The points I made about the necessity for follow-on employment for trainees have a special force in that area. Even if one assumes that some of the trainees in the general scheme will get work at the end of their period of subsidised employment-and there is no guarantee whatsoever of that-this is not likely to extend to disadvantaged groups.

The next point that needs to be raised is that most of the traineeships under Priority One, as Senator Vanstone said, are in the Federal or State Public Services. Simply increasing the size of the Public Service will not solve the problem. One of the most unfortunate aspects of Priority One is that it has been perceived by the Government as solving the problem, when it simply cannot do so. The Melbourne Age noted last month than only one non-Public Service trainee scheme had been announced so far, and that is for 300 jobs with Ansett Airlines of Australia over the next two years. I understand that there are some schemes in the travel industry and elsewhere in Western Australia, although these are only in very small numbers. The same article in the Melbourne Age noted that about 700 clerical traineeships in the Public Service are offered nation-wide and another 100 are being prepared in the Public Service. The fact that the traineeships offered are for clerical work is something to which I will return later, because it is an appalling development.

The Democrats want a closer tying of unemployment schemes to the community and to business. It is now a year since the Democrats' community services initiative scheme was submitted to the Government. We put that up in February last year and we have had no response of any kind as far as action is concerned, yet the scheme would have been a very useful one and still could be. Basically we asked the Government to allow an increase in the permissible income of unemployed people and pensioners, from the present $20 to $60 a week, so that there can be an incentive for them to help meet the mounting need for human services in our local communities. These services could include minor home and garden maintenance; shopping, reading, transport, et cetera, for elderly or disabled people; respite services, where a family is caring for a sick or disabled person; assistance to voluntary organisations or self-help groups; child care centres; and things of that kind. There is a widely perceived need in the community for this sort of work to be done and I would have thought that there would be an incentive and a desire for many unemployed people to do the work if they were not debarred from it financially by this ridiculous situation of limitation which the Government has continued to impose. Current low levels of additional permissible income for unemployed people-only $20 a week- severely limit the amount of service fee which could be paid and make it virtually not worthwhile to try to get that sort of scheme off the ground.

A further point, which the Government seems never to have taken into account, is that this limitation also hits very hard at the business sector generally, particularly small business, because it savagely reduces the spending power in the hands of hundreds of thousands of people who would go to the local shop and buy more things if they had the extra money; but the Government prevents them from doing that. Nothing is achieved by that harsh limitation on additional income.

From time to time I seek the views of my electorate in New South Wales by sending out survey forms to voters taken at random from the electoral rolls. I find that most valuable. My electorate gives me a very high response rate in every case, although I do not give them stamped, addressed envelopes, and I am delighted at the degree of response I get to these surveys. I would have thought that it would be a good thing if more of us consulted the electorate on what it thinks.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unsolicited junk mail and they have to pay for it.
—You said then that that was unsolicited junk mail and they have to pay for it. That is your view as a senator in this place.
—That is right.

—That is your view of whether or not you should consult the electorate. All I can say, Senator Puplick, is that as you get a little older you may become a little less arrogant and that would benefit both this place and yourself. In any case, the current survey concerns unemployment. Although at this stage only 100 responses have come in, they are already showing a very interesting indication of community attitudes. I mention them at this early stage of this debate because I think they are relevant. There is special interest in the idea that there should be some form of work alternative to the dole. The figures are so high in support of that as to be highly significant. To the question `Should the dole be paid only to those prepared to carry out work on behalf of the community?' 85 per cent answered yes and 12 per cent answered no, the rest having not made up their minds. The response was almost identical to a similar question: `Should there be a work alternative to the dole which will offer a higher payment than the dole but still not as high as award wages?' Eighty-four per cent said yes to that question and 16 per cent said no.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those who believe that this issue of a work alternative must be faced, although I can see the problems it has for a Labor Government. It would argue-I suppose it is a respectable argument-that this would serve only to create a sort of sub-class of workers who are not entitled to the wages and conditions which have been won by the unions through the years. With this in mind, I put in the survey the additional question: `Should the work alternative provide jobs only in fields of work which would not otherwise be done by unionists?' The community was more divided on that proposition, but 62 per cent said yes and 38 per cent said no. The survey sought to cover a wide sector of views, so we asked the general question: `Should the dole be abolished?' This was supported, interestingly enough, by only 17 per cent, with 83 per cent of respondents feeling that unemployment benefits should be maintained. There was a close vote on whether the present dole payment was high enough; 54 per cent felt that it was and 46 per cent felt that it was not.

I return to the question of a work alternative, because I believe that it is one of the major issues in the minds of the public and it should not be ignored. It is conventional wisdom that paying an unemployment benefit free of any obligation to work for it is an enlightened and useful course of action and the one offering the most dignity, personal freedom and assistance to the recipient, especially in conditions of long term unemployment. That is the conventional wisdom. I believe that the time has come for that conventional wisdom to be questioned. In my experience, many young people see the dole system as dismissive and rejective and as a put down of their position by society. This is especially the case with young people who have never worked. They see the dole, which is provided to them without any real chance of work, as virtually a statement by society along these lines: `We have nothing for you. You are basically of no value to us, but because it would be less than decent to allow you to starve or go unclothed, here is an amount of money just sufficient to avoid those indecencies'.

While there are without doubt a few people who are happy enough to go on living on the dole-so-called dole bludgers-my experience, from having been in many drop-in centres and unemployment centres and talked with young people over the past eight years, is that the vast majority of unemployed people want work. They would take work if they could get it, not only for economic reasons but also because their self-respect and level of prestige in our society are dependent on it. They perceive that as one of their major problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —How far do you think your proposals would go towards alleviating the problem?

—I think they would alleviate it considerably. Let me put it this way: I have asked this question of all the young people in drop-in centres. I have described the scheme to them. It has been a deeply traumatic experience for me. Some 90 per cent said that they would jump at such a scheme if it were offered. They have said to me something which really goes to my heart. They ask: `Senator, how quickly can you introduce it?' Of course, I cannot introduce it. Only the Government can do that. The fact is that the Government has ideological hang-ups which prevent it from doing so. In the course of that it is damaging the children of its supporters-the children of unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of this situation, I think we should start looking now at having a two-tier system of unemployment benefits, with a higher benefit being paid to the unemployed who are prepared to undertake some form of useful work, who are in the majority, and a lesser benefit being paid to those who are not prepared to do that. I resist strongly the idea that work should be compulsory for unemployed people to be given at least the minimal means of support. To take that step would be virtually to introduce a form of slavery-a compulsion on people to work in areas which they may, for some reason, find repugnant. I know there are many people who take a contrary view and who say that all the unemployed should do work to qualify for the dole. However, I believe we are not justified in taking that step now. The saying has it that you can lead a horse to water but you cannot make it drink. Compelling people to work in certain areas is not going to achieve any useful result.

The second point is that when work programs are organised which would permit all those who wished to work to do so, such programs ought to offer a wide variety of choice of occupation and should have a strong training element. There is no doubt in my mind that the work alternative is the necessary next step in dealing with unemployment, and it must be a continuing policy while unemployment is long term. There are, of course, obstacles to this. I repeat that the basic one is the trade union movement, which says that such a move would create a sub-class of workers on lower pay scales than awards provide. The fallacy of this union thinking is, of course, that the only alternative must be for people to rot away mentally and physically on the dole; often enough the unionists' own children. Of course there are answers to that union objection. These could include guarantees that work undertaken as part of the work alternative would not be work which would otherwise be done by unionists, the provision of a strong training or educational element, and strong influence, if not virtual control of the program, by the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

To proceed as we are doing now is cruel and inhuman in that it permits the continuance of thousands of personal tragedies which could otherwise be avoided. The evidence is steadily mounting that suicides, ill-health, drug addiction and criminal activity are strongly associated with long periods of unemployment. If the trade union movement opposes the introduction of effective work alternative programs for those who want them, it is contributing to those problems and must bear the guilt for them directly. I cannot believe that most trade unionists would want that. I think the real need now is for the union movement to think carefully about this whole area and it ought to be possible for a Labor government to enter into some dialogue about it.

It is evident to me that the Priority One scheme is a sort of faint attempt by the Government to meet community feelings over unemployment. However, it is woefully inadequate because of the Government's ideological hang-ups. These hang-ups extend to another area of concern. A very important change which must take place is that governments, unions and employers must accept the concepts of permanent part time work, job sharing and voluntary early retirement. In answer to a question I asked in September 1983, nearly three years ago, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, said that the introduction of more flexible methods of work organisation was part of Australian Labor Party policy and would be implemented following discussions with the parties concerned. One small part of the answer he gave nearly three years ago reads:

There is little doubt that greater sharing of employment opportunities through job splitting, greater facilitation of part time work, and other measures, could expand the number of people engaged in employment. Indeed, in a number of countries, government programs have been introduced to encourage the development of such alternative work arrangements. There is, however, some uncertainty about the long term effects of such programs, and considerable discussion as to whether part time work is an acceptable alternative to full time employment.

It is just not good enough that almost three years later the Government still has not come to grips with this obvious and necessary area of action. Plainly, it has been put in the too hard basket, and that is bad news for the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it today the following matter of public importance that was introduced and cogently argued for by my colleague Senator Vanstone from South Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's obsession with its public image which has led to a cynical betrayal of Australia's youth and a policy failure in Priority One.

Under any circumstances the betrayal of the nation's youth-for that is what this Government has done-would be a tragedy. However, what makes it a scandal is that in this case Australia's youth is being sacrificed for no better reason than to save the face of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and polish his ever more tarnished public image. The whole Priority One: Young Australia fiasco was conceived to help Mr Hawke save face and to soothe his battered pride and ego. Richard Farmer, one of the better known Labor apologists who writes in the media, discussed this in an article in the Bulletin on 27 August 1985. When writing about the results of the last Federal election, he said:
. . . Hawke had not expected the desertion of the young voters . . .
Within days of the blow to his pride that young voters had helped deliver, Hawke had decided to put youth matters under his own control.

The responsibility for this failure is to be sheeted home directly to the Prime Minister because since that day Mr Hawke's face saving efforts have continued unabated and unrewarded. His, indeed, is truly the face that launched 10,000 hopes and which has shattered and betrayed every one of them along the way.

I want to turn my attention to a number of matters, particularly those regarding the tertiary and further education sector. I am glad that Senator Ryan is in the chamber at the moment. She is, I might add, the only member of the Australian Labor Party in the chamber at the moment. This is presumably because she is the Minister on duty, not because she has any particular concern about young Australians. Quite clearly, none of her political colleagues has any concern about young Australians.

Before I deal with TAFE, let me deal with a couple of matters referred to by the distinguished Senator Robert Ray. Senator Ray, in attempting to defend the Government's record in this matter, had a number of things to say, most of which were drawn from the past. He gave anecdotes about the Constitution and anecdotes about Prime Minister Bruce. His obsession with the past is quite clear because, in terms of Priority One and in terms of youth policy, he is ashamed to face the present and, indeed, afraid to think about the future. However, Senator Ray is a well known political operator. In the Australian newspaper of 21 December 1985 there appeared a fairly lengthy article under the heading `Robert Ray: the ``big fella'' who guards Hawke'. Indeed, we have heard from the Prime Minister's heavyweight minder in the course of this debate. One of the things that interested me was Senator Ray's comment in the article when he said:
The right wing of the Labour Party are great fang men. . . .

Indeed, nobody could more illustrate the virtue of being a great fang man than Senator Robert Ray. The great tragedy is that at the moment the Australian Labor Party has got its fangs into the kids of Australia, and it is not about to get them out and it is not about to do anything for them. All Senator Robert Ray could do was moan about the bureaucrats who were responsible for the scheme's not working and to reflect upon the multitude of defeats suffered by the Collingwood football team. It is no wonder he is obsessed with Collingwood's successive defeats because that is what is being imposed on young Australians at the moment.

If one goes back to the Hansard report of the valedictory speeches that were given on 12 June 1981 one will find that Senator Grimes, speaking in relation to former Senator Jean Melzer, said that it was an absolute tragedy that a senator who was really concerned about human beings should be replaced in this chamber by a senator such as Robert Ray. I commend Senator Grimes's words to honourable senators who want to look them up in Hansard.

Nothing illustrates more clearly the failure of the Government in relation to young people than its failure to address the issues arising in the technical and further education sector in this country. Most honourable senators will have received representations during last year in regard to the continued cutbacks being made, particularly in capital expenditure in the TAFE sector, by Senator Ryan and the Australian Labor Party. Their action has prompted a number of comments, even from the Technical and Further Education Teachers Association, which wrote to honourable senators indicating that it is `concerned that this decision'-that is, the capital works cutback imposed by Senator Ryan in pursuit of her own ideological prejudices against excellence, achievement and young Australia-`will reduce TAFE's capacity to respond to Australia's vocational needs and, in particular, to provide new training opportunities for young people'. The Association goes on to say that it believes:
. . . the Government's decision to reduce TAFE capital works funding was short-sighted, especially given the Government's youth policy objectives.

Senator Vanstone has rightly quoted from Press reports of Mr Trevor Prescott, the National Training Council Deputy Chairman who laments that TAFE is being used by the Government as a dumping ground for the jobless; and of the South Australian Director of Technical and Further Education, Mr Fricker, who says that the Australian traineeship scheme could reverse the current trend of young people staying at school for a longer period. The scheme could be seen as a quick fix training exercise, lacking the care needed to transform experience into genuine vocational education. If one looks at the report entitled `Tertiary Education Report' published by the Higher Education Round Table one will see there criticisms of the Government that in 1984, 60,000 applicants were not able to be offered places in TAFE colleges in Australia. The reason they are not able to get those places can be sheeted home directly to the policies pursued by the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, and all those who go along with her. The Government has tried to say that one of the ways in which it was going to address this matter was to look at the gap that existed between the unemployment benefit level and the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance. What is the record that Senator Ryan proudly presides over? The unemployment benefit prior to November 1983 was $68.65; the TEAS living at home allowance was $38.55; and the living away from home allowance was calculated at $59.46. In other words, the gap under the Fraser Government between the unemployment benefit and the TEAS away from home allowance was $30.10. Senator Ryan has managed to increase it to $43.69. The gap between the unemployment benefit and the living away from home TEAS allowance was $9.19. Senator Ryan has worked as hard as she possibly can to increase that gap to $19.53 to make it doubly more unattractive to be in technical and further education than to be on the dole. Once again, the Higher Education Round Table has indicated in its report that the TEAS allowance under the Labor Government is, in its words, `unacceptably low and acts as a positive disincentive to study, especially for the disadvantaged'. The Government has, in fact, doubled that positive disincentive in its period of office. It is, therefore, no wonder that Don Smart and his colleagues in their paper `The Hawke Government and Education' given to the Australasian Political Studies Association in August last year, concluded with these words:
As a result, the legacy of the Hawke Government may well be a set of educational policies which are destined on balance to increase rather than reduce inequalities in our society.

We have sought to address-Senator Robert Ray was concerned about alternatives-one of the particular issues with which I will deal briefly, namely, the level of junior wage rates. The Westpac Banking Corporation in its review in September 1985 drew attention to the fact that countries which have been more successful in providing youth employment are countries which have more flexible wage fixing procedures and in which youth-adult wage relativities have not been compressed as in Australia. In those countries they have been more successful in reducing or containing youth unemployment. Stanley Siebert of the University of Birmingham writing in the journal Economic Affairs in the middle of last year, again pointed to precisely that. Mr Hawke, in his address to the nation dealing with this matter, said:
We're not going to achieve this--
that is more employment for young people-
by taking the backward step of cutting youth wages.

He would rather have Australian kids without jobs than upset his bosses in the trade union movement by providing them with the opportunity to have jobs at more realistic wage levels. That is why the record of the Hawke Government, in terms of the employment of young people, is such that if one looks at the rate of unemployment among young people one will see that in the last month alone it increased from 20.8 per cent to 21.4 per cent, and that it has increased since the Fraser period when it was 16.6 per cent to 18.2 per cent. In other words there has been a significant rise in the level of youth unemployment under the stewardship of the Hawke Government. One can even look at its attempt to use the Public Service in this regard and one will see in the Public Service Board annual report for 1984-85 that the percentage of young people being taken into the Public Service has declined from 35.8 per cent in the period of the Fraser Administration to 29.1 per cent under the Labor Party. Even where it has its own ability to control the intake of jobs available to young people it has miserably and disastrously failed. We know the reason it failed is that it has not been prepared to take on its bosses in the unions. It has not been able to take on the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, the Federated Clerks Union of Australia and the Australian Public Service Association. John Macbean and his mates in the Australian Bank Employees Union have all indicated that they will not co-operate with the Government in attempts to provide jobs for young people at more realistic rates.

Senator Robert Ray talked about the wonderful phone-in and said that one of the things that had been identified as a problem of young people was their attention to and their worry about the drug problem. I refer Senator Ray, Senator Reynolds and Senator Giles who are going to take part in this debate to the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 2 April 1985 which commented on the Labor Government's failure to address the drug problem. It said:
If Mr Hawke wants to be taken seriously, then, he must point out to Mr Wran that the institutional corruption that exists in New South Wales is a cornerstone of the illegal drug industry.

How dare Mr Hawke come into this Parliament and say that he has a concern for young Australians when the person he ought to be talking to about it is none other than the Federal President of the Labor Party itself. Senator Vanstone has drawn attention to the extent to which Mr Peter Kirby, who suggested that scheme in the first place, has condemned it as a failure, and has demonstrated the way in which the Labor Party has walked away from its responsibilities in this area. We know that the Government is not prepared to do the sorts of things that are important like taking on the unions in order to provide jobs for kids. One sees that only at the end of last year in Western Australia the Trades and Labor Council Assistant Secretary, Mr Rob Meecham, said:
Sabotaging McDonald's efforts to provide extra jobs at below award rates was as important to the trade union movement as the Mudginberri dispute.

In other words, the deliberate attempt to sabotage the provision of jobs for kids in an establishment that kids want to work in was as important to the Labor Party and to Mr Hawke as getting Mudginberri off the hook. I conclude by saying once again what an abject failure the Government has been in relation to young people. Its policy and promises to young Australians have been a farrago of falsehoods and a litany of lies. It has lied to young Australians about what it would do for them. It has lied to young Australians about how it cares for them. It has lied to young Australians about what its real priority is because its priority is not young Australians. Its priority is the face and the public image of the Prime Minister-nothing more than that, nothing less than that. It has sufficient an obsession with its public relations exercises that it is prepared to sacrifice anybody, anything and any group in society in order to achieve the personal promotion of the most disastrous Prime Minister ever to be visited upon young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see that members of the Opposition are really stirred up this afternoon. A few more have come back into the chamber and they are determined to make as much noise as they can. They are trying to cover up for something that has come across my desk today which I find very interesting. They are trying to cover up for the latest Morgan gallup poll which says that there has been a dramatic 22 per cent decline in support for Federal Opposition Leader, John Howard. Honourable senators opposite do not like to hear about it.
—You don't want to talk about Priority One.

—It is very relevant to Priority One: Young Australia. I will be turning my attention to Priority One. The very reason that members of the Opposition cannot talk about their policies is that they do not have a leader who has support out there in the community. So how can they talk about policies and priorities for Australia's young people? This afternoon's matter of public importance is a sham. It is like so many shams that occur in this place because the Opposition is trying to distract attention away from the failure within its own Party. As has been pointed out very clearly earlier by my colleague Senator Ray, the Opposition has no policies; it has no alternatives.
—You are a failure.

—Senator Vanstone has nothing to do but to gripe and misrepresent the policies of the Australian Government. She is not prepared to look back to the Fraser years-frankly I do not blame her-because there was so little commitment during the Fraser years. She cannot look forward because she has nothing to look forward to in terms of a leader who has the support of even his party, let alone his normal party supporters. So members of the Opposition are in a position of just being constant, carping knockers. Senator Puplick might notice that my last statement-`constant, carping knockers'-is almost as alliterative as some of his comments. He obviously knows more about alliteration than he knows about developing youth policies and programs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what Senator Vanstone had to say. She whinged on and on for the entire period of her speech about the problems that have been experienced with traineeships. I argue that it is far better to have something in place and to keep aiming for a goal that we have been prepared to set. The Opposition is not prepared to set any goals in terms of youth unemployment; unemployed youth are to sit around being negative and constantly critical. I suggest that Senator Vanstone get out there in the real world. Does she visit community youth support schemes like I have done over the last three years and before? Does she go and talk on university campuses? Does she visit schools? She should get out there among the young people. I wonder how many young people visit her office each week. Does she get a steady flow of young people and their parents coming into her office to collect the kind of information that we have in our office giving all the details of Priority One? No, she is not even acting as a good resource person because she would rather be continually negative.

I would now like to talk about what Senator Mason said. I must say that on occasions I do agree with Senator Mason, but I cannot let his remark that there was no future in traineeships pass. If there is no future in traineeships there is no future in the education system and, therefore, we all might as well forget about developing skills in our young people. It is quite ridiculous to say that there is no future in traineeships. The future in developing skills is obvious from the success of the community employment program. Senator Vanstone probably does not know that 46 per cent of people who have been employed under the community employment program are still employed in permanent work six months after their community employment program period finishes. That indicates to Senator Mason and to others around this chamber that there is benefit in short term employment schemes and the traineeships which we propose.

I will now come to some of the facts about traineeships as outlined in the Government's Priority One program. I am afraid that one can rely only on the Australian Government to talk about facts in this place. One cannot rely on the Opposition because it is too busy covering up for the failure of its present Leader. Traineeships will combine formal off the job training with work experience in a related occupation. The Government accepts that it may have set an ambitious target for itself in aiming to create 10,000 traineeships. We are ambitious. We do not apologise for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you should apologise for your failure.

—We have not failed. If Senator Vanstone listens she will gain some wisdom in this area. The Government will be looking at outcomes of current negotiations and at early take-up rates following them to make a judgment about the target. We continue to remain optimistic, unlike the poor Opposition-I can understand why it is so pessimistic; I would be if I were in its position- that both this target and the long term goal of 75,000 traineeships by 1988-89 can be achieved. To achieve our long term target we are determined to establish sound ground rules and a high quality training system and then introduce the system progressively.

SPEECH.PARA: A national task force has been established to promote, co-ordinate and advise the Federal Government on the development of the Australian traineeship scheme. The task force is chaired by George Polites with Mr Cliff Dolan as deputy chair. Talks between the Government and small businesses over the Australian traineeship scheme--

TALK.START.PARA: —That will make sure that nothing happens with the unions nobbling it.

—Opposition senators do not like the facts. The Federal President of the Australian Small Business Association Ltd, Mr Peter Boyle, has indicated that small businesses are now willing to help with the Australian traineeship scheme. The feasibility of the scheme and its emphasis on skills acquisition have helped overcome initial small business reluctance to participate.
—Why not just have your speech incorporated.

—Senator Archer would like me to have my speech incorporated. He is concerned that there is no policy, that it is a failure; yet as soon as I come forward with the facts he does not want to hear them. The traineeship scheme is only one element of the Government's Priority One strategy for young people. However, despite the criticism that has come forward this afternoon, over 2,000 traineeships have already been announced and 284 trainees are presently in employment. I know that the Opposition will jump up and down and say that that is not good enough, but surely to have even one person in a training program is better than what it had to offer during its seven years in government when it did so little for young people and so little for people in terms of employment in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Other elements in the Priority One strategy include: The introduction of a new integrated wage subsidy program; provision of additional student places in higher education; reviewing the Commonwealth's role in tertiary and further education; rationalising income support arrangements for young people, including a move to an age related system of allowances from 1987 and, over the next three years, equating corresponding rates of education allowances and unemployment benefit for people under 21; establishment of a youth services development program; upgrading Commonwealth Employment Service services for young people; improving the community youth support scheme; and establishing a group volunteer community service scheme for young people. Remember which government it was that talked of dismantling the community youth support scheme. I will say no more about that at the moment.

In the few minutes remaining I move on to comments that have been made about the phone-in of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We have here today a matter of public importance that says that the Government has some sort of obsession with its public image. I wish to read from the 1979-80 annual report of the former Department of Employment and Youth Affairs when the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs announced on 13 June 1980 an upgrading of his office to do a number of things. One of the things he wanted to do, would you believe, was to improve its image and effectiveness. Yet we have Senator Vanstone coming into this place and suggesting that anything to do with image is somehow a negative factor.

Let us move on to action taken during the Fraser years. I know that Opposition senators do not like to look back or forward, but I am afraid that they will have to listen to some of this in the few minutes that remain to me. The national youth conference which was opened by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was held in Canberra from 3 to 5 October 1979-here is a little bit of positive work that Mr Fraser actually did-to provide a national forum for 133 participants to discuss issues of concern to young people. There were about 80 participants who were nominated by youth organisations and organisations representing particular interests in Australian society. The remainder of the participants were selected through a national youth line phone-in, held on 15 September 1979 with the co-operation of 40 commercial radio stations and the ABC Radio regional network. At that time when a national phone-in was conducted, I do not remember there being any criticism of the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. There was no criticism then of the Prime Minister, who wanted to consult young people and who contacted them by phone. He might have even got their names and addresses-shock, horror! He might even have used that information in a future election campaign. After all, how could he possibly have had a phone-in to get young people to participate in this conference, which in its own small way was a start, I suppose? So let us not have any of this rubbish that has come across this chamber this afternoon about our Prime Minister's phone-in when it was an idea that had already been floated in the Fraser years. The difference is that although Mr Fraser had a national youth conference, he did nothing about the resolutions. The resolutions are here in the annual report, but very little came from his conference. On the other hand, I will speak very quickly of some of the commitments made by the Prime Minister in a recent address describing exactly the kind of follow-up from his phone-in.

TALK.START.PARA: —From when?

—Oh, here we go. Senator Vanstone asks from when. The Prime Minister has said that from early analysis of the phone calls some major themes are already apparent. Opposition senators seem to be interested in the phone-in now. They have done another about turn. I quote the Prime Minister's remarks. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Some specific proposals for policy development and implementation are emerging. I wish to talk about some of these themes now, although the overall report on the phone-in by the Office of Youth Affairs within my Department is still being finalised.

We take these views of young people seriously. We do not ignore them, as Malcolm Fraser did. We are taking them seriously. The findings are being analysed in a full report which will be available for senators to read just as soon as it is tabled in Parliament.

In perhaps the most basic terms those who called in to the phone-in were saying something about their identity and their search for a place in our nation. This theme manifested itself in so many of the issues that they raised, from the search for work and dignity, which remains the central concern of young Australians, to the desire to give and be given more information about the responsibility for all facets of local and national life to allow young people to better take their part in our community. The vexing problems of age related rights and privileges, the content and purpose of education, the protection of the environment, relationships with other nations, income support and the use and abuse of drugs were all matters of concern. The Prime Minister was prepared to talk with young people of this country and that was very much appreciated by more than 25,000 young people. Mr Hawke himself spoke to a large number of young people and wherever I have travelled since the phone-in, I have heard nothing but praise for it. I just feel sorry for Opposition senators. They are so negative; they have nothing to look back on and apparently they have nothing to put forward for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have heard from the Government this afternoon-or more particularly what we have not heard-is amazing. Two Government senators have stood up and said absolutely nothing; in fact, for most of the time while the first three speakers were speaking in this debate there was only Senator Ryan in the chamber. Is that not incredible on such an important issue as Priority One? The last 15 minutes of Senator Reynolds's speech were difficult to follow, but she did say that the Government remained optimistic about the future of Priority One. All I can say is that the Government will jolly well need to remain optimistic about Priority One because it is an absolute disaster and optimism is about all that it has got going for it at the moment. Senator Reynolds has absolutely amazed everyone in this chamber this afternoon by making accusations about not being able to distribute information on Priority One or on youth programs. I will let the people of Australia know that the Government does not make adequate information available to Opposition senators and it is very rare that we get information from the Government. At the time of the Budget a brief issue of Priority One information was granted to Opposition senators in the form of two kits. Opposition senators then had to go back and beg and plead for more in order to try to get information about this fraud. If Senator Reynolds thinks that Opposition senators are not doing a good job, perhaps that is because the Government's distribution needs to be looked at. That distribution in itself is appalling.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the Priority One scheme was hastily organised and over-inflated for political reasons. It is not so much a case of socialist `bread and circuses', but of one big circus and very little bread for the unemployed. As early as November the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, began to admit that there were problems. Yet Government senators are saying today that there are no problems and that we can remain optimistic. On 31 January Peter Kirby called on the Government to abandon its 10,000 target and concentrate on making the scheme work. But no, the Government will not concentrate on making the scheme work. It knows that the scheme is a disaster; it knows that six months down the track it is facing the biggest problem with youth unemployment that it could possibly face. At the same time in January it was reported that the Minister and his Department wanted a more realistic target of 5,000 traineeships for 1985-86, but that he had been overridden by the Prime Minister for political reasons. The Prime Minister had already indulged in the most massive campaign to promote himself, so how could he back off then? Of course Peter Steedman, former Labor member of the House of Representatives, certainly ensured that Priority One received maximum publicity. I might add that it failed to get him the pre-selection for Scullin, but he had a wonderful time doing all the advertising for Priority One and for the Prime Minister. How many times day after day did we pick up the news- paper and see the Prime Minister's photograph splashed around with stories about Priority One. However, these stories did not give the young people of Australia any more information.

According to Senator Reynolds-and I am glad that she was at least honest about this because she cited the figure-about 284 traineeships were in place. That is, in place, and that was what Senator Reynolds cited, not the flimsy agreements which may or may not be kept. Government senators can talk about agreements and we can all talk about the traineeships that are actually in place, but there is a vast difference. I might add that most of those traineeships that are in place happen to be in the public sector, when originally it was aimed that only 20 per cent would be in that sector. A total of $1m has been spent on this advertising campaign and the promotion of the Prime Minister who, I guess, we could all say is the new era rock concert host because he indulged in a little of that as well, but the expenditure of $1.4m on the phone-in is the biggest fraud that we could wish to imagine. The Government will not say what it achieved because it does not know. But there are a lot of people who do know what it achieved for the Government and that is not the nicest part of the whole story. The Government benefitted in that it got 22,552 names of people, their addresses, ages and telephone numbers.
