As was written in the Sydney Morning Herald, that is a very handy list to have in the lead-up to an election; it enables the Government to mail out more and more propaganda to young people around Australia. If this Priority One program is not a snow job of blizzard proportions, what is? It is a snow job of the young people of Australia. In December there was still 20 per cent unemployment among 15 to 19-year-olds. That equated to 114,000 people. Youth unemployment in 1980 was running at 16.6 per cent. The Government which today believes that it has done such a wonderful job had a level of youth unemployment in 1985 of 18.2 per cent. Youth unemployment still is running at 3 1/2 times the unemployment rate of those 20 years and older.

We have also seen trade union objection to the Priority One scheme. We know that with this Government, big business and big unions leapt into bed together, but the strongest critic of the scheme has been Jim Maher of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association. On 7 November he described the scheme as totally impractical and ill-conceived. He said it copied the United Kingdom scheme that was an abject failure and will be a failure here. At the same time John Maynes of the Federated Clerks Union of Australia warned that gimmickry and bureaucratic bungling would destroy Priority One, a comment that stands despite recent claims of FCU agreement to the scheme.

Apart from outright hostility to the scheme, unions appear to be making it unworkable by imposing conditions which employers cannot meet. John Hogg, Secretary of the SDA in Queensland, on 10 December last year insisted that trainees must be additional workers, must get permanent jobs, must be paid the award and must be unionised. How much more regulation has to be put in place? In particular, the last two conditions that trainees must be paid the award and must be unionised would be unacceptable to employers. Phil Naylor of the Queensland Retailers Association noted that these conditions could not be met. Demands for compulsory unionism of trainees by unions in the hospitality industry ruled out participation by employers.

This also represents a heavying of the trainees themselves. I do not think anyone should be encouraging that. It is a case of big brother looking over one's shoulder yet again. Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions expressed reservations about any lowering of the trainee wage below junior employee rates. On 13 November, Senator Button admitted in the Senate that the unions had misgivings in regard to Priority One. In Canberra, Bob Allen of the Australian Capital Territory Further Education Office admitted that a target of 120 local traineeships could not be met. Of course, what we have here is the Government not wanting to back off, not wanting to admit that the scheme is a disaster, and the unions pushing and pushing that they have their case to answer to their union members. Who are the victims of the scheme which has gone wrong? The young people of Australia are suffering. We owe more to the young people of Australia than this fraud.

I ask honourable senators to instance the employer reaction. The Committee for the Development of Youth Employment noted on 30 January the need for wage flexibility, the essence of the problem of youth unemployment. David Nolan of the Confederation of Australian Industry noted on 2 February this year the inflexibility of the unions. He said that the refusal to agree to trainees being paid lower hourly rates than full time junior workers was a denial of economic facts. Ian Spicer of the CAI noted in November that there had been a failure to negotiate a wage for trainees that was acceptable to employer and employee and that the scheme could simply result in a redistribution of jobs for 16 and 17-year-olds. In practical terms, trainees working a limited number of hours and needing supervision are not going to be of great benefit to employers. We have seen this fraud go on for a little too long. When we have looked at the issues which have been raised by Opposition speakers we can then start to look at more specific situations, for example, the situation in Western Australia. On 16 October 1985 Senator Giles said:
By 25 September agreement had already been reached with Western Australia for a proposal involving 500 trainees.

That has not been so in the delivery. Ads placed in the second last week of November for traineeships involving Public Service clerical work, computer information and conservation management resulted in 280 trainees being placed. Ads placed over the Christmas-New Year period for traineeships for the joint private sector-State Tourist Bureau project resulted in 500 to 600 applicants. Surprise, surprise! Some 19 trainees were placed. I guess Senator Giles really has a problem with her figures. The same situation applies right across Australia. Senator Giles also said that by 16 October there were already 36 group proposals before the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

We are just waiting to see the delivery of the goods. The goods are not being delivered. We are concerned. It is about time that this Government realised that there is major concern from many people. The majority of the traineeships established, as I mentioned before, were in the Public Service. They were youth traineeships in the Public Service of a clerical nature. The pamphlet distributed regarding Priority One says that a typical Public Service trainee will be required to keep records on the movement of files and cheques, sort, open and deliver mail and answer inquiries about records and documents. I put it to honourable senators that there is no shortage of unemployed Australians already equipped to do such simple clerical work. Records and file management is, in any case, rapidly becoming computerised. The need for employees to do such work is declining rather than growing. Yet here we have a government saying that this is the most wonderful scheme it has ever come up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—I cannot agree more with Senator Vanstone. This is the pin on which the Government is placing its whole program. It is nothing short of a disaster. I shall finish by mentioning again some of those reasons why the scheme has been such an abject failure. The ambitious target set in the first place to make the scheme and this Government look so good has made the scheme a failure. Consultations were not adequately undertaken prior to the announcement. Lack of prior consultation led to unions not being on side. The scheme was not sufficiently canvassed with private employers and, therefore, not suited to employers' needs. An administrative nightmare makes it difficult to implement and unattractive to employers. Being unattractive to private employers means that most trainee agreements are with the Public Service. I remind honourable senators again that only 20 per cent of the traineeships were planned to be with the Public Service. However, we are seeing virtually the whole lot, nearly 100 per cent of the traineeships, in the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Government is not prepared to address the problems of youth unemployment in a far more serious manner, by the time the coalition is returned to government there will be a massive backlog. I think that this is a responsibility of this Government. Honourable senators on the Government side have asked us what we would do and why we have not done something. I remind them that they are in government. It is their responsibility. It is not our responsibility. We have clear policy directions. Time does not permit me to go into those policy directions. The next speaker, Senator Giles, probably will say: `Senator Knowles said that they have no policies'. I state quite clearly that our policies are available to the people of Australia and that they will be better than the fraud we have seen in Priority One.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, the Senate is debating the following matter of public importance proposed by the Opposition in the name of Senator Vanstone:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's obsession with its public image which has led to a cynical betrayal of Australia's youth and a policy failure in Priority One.

I find some quite remarkable features in the wording of the matter of public importance. I shall deal with the first part of it, namely, the Government's obsession with its public image, before going to what is intended to be the substance of a very flimsy claim. The repugnance that flows through that statement leaves me completely amazed.

I grew up in South Australia in the years when we had a conservative Federal Government and a conservative State Government. I was part of a generation which was actively discouraged from any sort of community awareness and from any knowledge of the political system. There was no intelligent public discussion of politics. There was no education in the school on civics or anything remotely resembling any sort of political science. My political education as a schoolgirl was confined entirely to a visit to Parliament House in South Australia, as a result of which visit I managed to win a prize for writing an essay. I believe that was the beginning and end of my `schooling' in politics, as a result of those years of conservatism and, as I said, active discouragement of any intelligent interest in political systems. The effects of those years on that generation have been very clearly demonstrated in this chamber over the last few days while we have been debating the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. It is abundantly clear that very many people in this nation-I am not referring to honourable senators, of course-can be very easily misled. Politically, they are naive and uneducated and easily manipulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because they have a contrary view to you, they are misled?

—On the contrary, I have every sympathy for those people who, simply because of their lack of knowledge, lack of understanding and lack of access to information over all those years, are not in a position to be able to see a progressive measure when it is offered to them. On this occasion we have used modern media. We have made effective and reasonable use of communications in a real attempt to consult the electorate. That was quite unheard of with past conservative governments, although I was glad to be reminded this afternoon that it was a very reasonable tactic used by the Fraser Government, but, unfortunately not followed through.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not making the mistake of believing that young people are a homogeneous group all amenable to the same formula. The phone-ins have given us an opportunity for that diversity of needs and objectives to be articulated, recorded, recognised and accommodated. Traineeships, even at their most ambitious, cater for a relatively small proportion of that age group, but a relatively large proportion of that age group that is in need of extra assistance. The immediate concerns of young people are not only for training and employment, and we have been able to discover this quite clearly as a result of our having the intelligence actually to consult these people. It is something quite scandalous, if we were to believe what we have been hearing from honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, actually to consult young adults about their aspirations, objectives, disappointments, desires and needs.

We have discovered very clearly that in addition to training and employment they need housing designed for their needs. Their health needs in adolescence are clearly unique. Their legal needs so far have been largely unaddressed and so have their education needs, as more and more of them look towards completing a secondary education and going on to tertiary education in a way that is really quite new in this community. I take honourable senators back again to those conservative years during which the retention rate of young people in Australia was at the same level as that in Portugal and in Spain-countries with a far lower gross national product than that of this wealthy nation.

We know that the young people in Australia are desperately in need of income support and our system of age-related allowances that will be introduced at the beginning of next year will remove the differences between unemployment and education allowances and will eliminate those disincentives and distortions which have made it more appealing, superficially at least, for young people to qualify for unemployment benefit rather than continue with their education.

Previous speakers in this debate have enumerated the measures that are being put in place. We believe that it is perfectly justifiable to take a little time in order to get things right. I say to Senator Knowles that we are concentrating on making the scheme work, unlike previous schemes in Australia over the last 10 years, which, at enormous cost, trained nobody at all. Hundreds of millions of dollars have gone into the special youth unemployment training program scheme over the last years and nobody was trained except perhaps by accident.

We do not despair of early difficulties in negotiating with the trade union movement. There are difficulties and they are being overcome. But award conditions and wages are worth fighting for. I am amongst those people in this House and all over the nation who believe that if one is doing a job one should be paid a proper rate for it and that a job that is being done by a young person is not necessarily inferior to a job that is being done by a person twice or three times that young person's age.

Some doubts have been cast on the possibility of this scheme actually getting into gear and showing what can be done. I do not believe it is illogical for public services to take up initially the scheme and show the private sector how it can be done. This is not particularly novel. It has happened before. On this occasion I am delighted to report that the Western Australian Government is well ahead. I believe that the number of jobs that has been quoted on several occasions this afternoon should be updated. Three hundred and sixty-nine traineeships have now been introduced and our target of 500, to which I referred in November, will shortly be met. Four projects have been funded already, and they were the first to be announced in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a good day. It was 260 a moment ago.
—Oh, really? If we have another 10 speakers it will go up to 10,000.

—If Senator Knowles is interested in unemployment, I suggest she listen. These projects have been targeted in areas where unemployment is highest. There is a scheme in Albany, there is one in Fremantle, there is one in Rockingham and there is another in the south-west metropolitan area of Perth-all in Senator Knowles's electorate.
—The Department did not give us those figures yesterday.

—Senator Knowles may not know which department to ask. These are today's figures. Income support has been in place from 1 January and $115,000 has already been spent on the program. The State Government is co-operating in pilot programs under the youth services development program. Five youth access centres are being developed as part of the Commonwealth Employment Service involvement with young people. In the training and employment area an attempt is being made to amalgamate all community-based training schemes. If some criticism were to be aimed at the training of youth in Australia, surely it should be directed to the plethora of schemes that have been introduced over the last 10 years on an extremely ad hoc basis. Those schemes have eaten up enormous sums of money-I referred before to the SYETP scheme-with very little in the way of carefully planned education and training and very little in the way of future prospects for the people who went through those schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst those already employed in the Western Australian scheme, there are 100 trainees in the Department of Computing and Information Technology; 100 in the Department of Conservation and Land Management; 135 with the Public Service Board; and, in the private sector, which is coming along in the background but will be catching up soon I am sure, 19 have been employed in the tourist industry and 15 in credit unions. The very interesting thing about the little list of positions that I have just read to honourable senators is that on my reckoning those positions would be covered by at least five different trade unions. Agreement has obviously been reached in Western Australia in order to safeguard the working conditions of the people involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all absolute rubbish.

—I suggest that if Senator Knowles believes it is such rubbish she should talk to one or two of those 369 people who are already employed under this traineeship scheme and see whether they think it is absolute rubbish. It seems to me, my colleagues, and, I believe, to most people in the Australian community, perfectly sensible to consult young people to find out what it is they need, and to find out how they want to be involved.

I conclude by returning to the point on which I commenced-that of involvement. Unlike the people who grew up during the 1930s, 1940s, 1950s or 1960s, young people of the 1980s want to be involved in the decisions that will affect their life chances. It is clear from those figures that youth employment in the Public Service has fallen to an all-time low. The Public Service Board figures project that it will fall below 6 per cent. That is a direct reflection, of course, upon the Government which says that youth is its priority one. If youth is its priority one why does it not give them employment in the Public Service? Why does it not give them their fair share of jobs in the Public Service?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Senator Mason opposes, though.

—I am not saying that more jobs should be created. I am saying that they should be given their fair chance. It is clear from an analysis of the Public Service Board figures that they have been denied that fair chance by the recruitment policies of the Board. Youth and their parents in Australia are entitled to ask: Why does the Government not practise what it has preached in the area that it controls, namely, the Commonwealth Public Service? So people ought to be very careful about using that argument about youth wages.

SPEECH.PARA: The missing factor in this debate, of course, is that with all the training schemes, with all the encouragement for youth to stay at school, will they find jobs at the end of it? That is the question. What is the real problem facing Australia when it comes to unemployment? The simple problem is that there are more people seeking paid work than there are jobs available. At the same time new jobs, in the old sense, are being slashed by the introduction-sometimes a haphazard introduction-of automation and technological change. So the youth unemployment problem has a social as well as an economic character. Of course, it is important to try to get the economy right, but there is a social aspect as well.

Faced with that, if one were part of a sensible government, would one force people who had a better reason to be out of the paid work force to stay there in order to make ends meet? Of course one would not. One would encourage people who decide to leave the paid work force to leave it and leave the way open for youth. But that is not being done. That question is not even being addressed. It is about time that it was addressed. Thousands upon thousands of persons in a certain age bracket would dearly love to retire-they desire to retire-but cannot do so because it would cause a substantial fall in their standard of living. Many thousands of families are forced to have both mother and father working to the detriment of their own health. This places increasing burdens on the family. Why is that so? Because of the actions of successive governments in failing to give taxation justice to the one income family and thus forcing many hundreds of thousands of people into the paid work force many of whom desire to retire.

The figures in the recent Budget and the proposed tax budget will further exacerbate the problem faced by one-income families in Australia today. Since 1976 the one-income family on average weekly earnings has had imposed upon it a massive 435.7 per cent increase in taxation. At the same time average weekly earnings have risen by only 135.4 per cent. The worker whose family is existing on one income and who is receiving the weighted average weekly award has had imposed upon him even a greater percentage increase in taxation.

The Government's taxation package will further exacerbate the problem of the one-income family compared with the two-income family. On present tax scales the one-income family on average weekly earnings is paying $785 more in direct taxation than the two income family. After 1986 this will go up to $809. In addition, the 1985 Budget of this Government failed to restore the value of family allowances which have been eroded by almost 50 per cent in 1976. This means that a mother with four children is now $55.35 a month worse off in real terms than she was in 1976 on that issue alone. Add to that the failure of the spouse rebate to be increased and an enormous pressure is brought to bear on families who cannot make ends meet and are forced to have two people out in the work force. This, of course, places emphasis on youth unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It has not been possible for me to peruse the particular treaties, but I rise because of the importance of the treaty-making power in terms of the Commonwealth Constitution. During the debate on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill it has been made clear that the external affairs power of the Commonwealth Constitution as determined by our founding fathers has now been interpreted, not only to embrace the making of treaties but also to use those treaties and the nature of those treaties as the head of power for the implementation of legislation. The effect has been far reaching. The High Court of Australia held, by a majority of 4:3, that we could use a treaty to reach into a State in terms of its ability, or otherwise, to construct a dam.

A former Labor Senate leader in this place looked towards a treaty on migratory birds to see whether industrial exploitation on Taren Point of Botany Bay could be prevented because swallows that come from Russia or Japan migrate and land on Taren Point. This is a significant development in terms of treaty-making powers. No one would have thought in the making of treaties that such an extension could exist. I say this not in any sense of exaggeration but to point out where this country is going if we persist in a belief that a treaty can be made overseas of whatever nature and generalisation and then used and construed as a head of power to reach into law making not only in the Commonwealth but interstate and in local government.

I rise on this matter for the specific reason that recently a quaint body has been set up, a constitutional commission, to look at reforms of the Constitution. It seems to me fundamental that this is setting about the problem in the wrong way. Surely we need to look at 1986 and beyond and at what ought to be the compact between the Commonwealth and States. We should look at what ought to be the nature of institutionalised federalism so that we are not constantly playing a game of trying to pierce the ceiling of the Commonwealth Constitution to find more powers for this Parliament and, therefore, weakening the fabric of the Federation. I believe fervently in federalism, but am not a States-righter in that sense at all. I believe we should achieve a balance between the Commonwealth and the States and I believe that there ought to be a modern and clear definition of where the power should lie. Indeed, it is necessary now to make sure that any re-writing of the Commonwealth Constitution does, in fact, put it in the situation of being fixed and limited and that the States have residual powers. Whilst we rest on this treaty-making we no longer have a situation of a fixed, rigid and written Commonwealth Constitution. We have an open-ended Constitution and no person can decide which way the decisions will go.

I make a plea that this country in the future should look at some kind of a study to give a compact between the Commonwealth and the States to redefine and, above all, to make sure that we do not have this open-ended action that the treaty-making power and the present decisions allow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —These treaties are before the chamber because the Federal Parliament has the duty through its Ministers to look after the external affairs of this country. That is sometimes forgotten. As Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out quite correctly, the Constitution makes provision for Parliament to have certain powers. One of the powers with which this Federal Parliament deals is that of external affairs. It is sometimes argued these days that in some way or other that power allows laws to be made surreptitiously. The Franklin Dam case is the classic instance of that.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this Constitution, which was written by the founding fathers and in which so much respect lies, has set up the situation in which that happens. It is strange for people to argue, therefore, that in some way the very terms of the Constitution violate the Constitution itself. That is not so. The external affairs power has been there since the Constitution was written and the High Court of Australia, which has the duty of interpreting the Constitution, is the body which can decide, according to the Constitution, what should happen under it. It is well to remember in a debate such as this that the Federal Parliament, in acting in the way it does-in passing laws which may affect States and to which the States may object-is acting within the Constitution, as the High Court has said that it is.

Senator Sanders has said that very important things arise under treaties, and that is so. As Senator Messner suggested to him, perhaps he ought to make debate on treaties an order of the day so that further and more lengthy debate can take place. If one looks at the treaties in this package, one sees the wide variety of subjects that are dealt with and the wide range of countries involved. The countries which appear as parties to these treaties with Australia include Italy, the People's Republic of China, Singapore, United States of America and Thailand. The treaties deal with all sorts of matters, including telecommunications, torture, cruel and inhuman punishment and double taxation. They are illustrations of how closely Australia is related to the rest of the world. It is strange that one sees in that list the questions of torture and cruel and inhuman punishment. Fortunately those questions are not as applicable to Australia as they are elsewhere, but Australia, as a member of the international community, has an obligation to enter into treaties and to help other countries which are parties to the treaties. In other words, Australia cannot simply stand apart from the rest of the world and enjoy treaties that give it benefits without conferring benefits on others.

In the context of what has been said both in letters and in the debate on the Bill of Rights it is well to remember, when things are introduced on the basis of international covenants, that Australia's interests are not the only ones that should be considered, but that the interests of other countries that Australia may help are also relevant. Australia has an obligation to contribute as well as a right to gain from these treaties. It is important to look at this bundle of treaties to see how true that statement is. The number of countries with which Australia has made treaties and the sorts of objects in the treaties are illustrations of that. In order to improve our own quality of life, to expand and develop our own culture and to enhance our own spiritual values, as well as advancing our own economic interests, we must have proper relations with other countries. Those proper relations include an obligation to help them, whether or not they are as well off as Australia, in terms of the human rights they may or may not have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too express some air of caution and concern about the way the treaty business seems to have changed in the last few years. Treaties used to be treaties, and we used to be not too concerned about the spin-offs that came from signing treaties, but I regret very much that this no longer appears to be so. Governments are now in a position, as a result of court decisions, to push all sorts of aspects, depending on the area in which we may have a treaty of some sort. In the past, established practice was accepted by the courts, so that the Constitution meant exactly what it said, but this is no longer the case. It is now being used to attack the powers and Constitutions of the States and clearly this is totally contrary to any intention that ever existed.

I object very much to any prospect of treaty powers being used as a constitutional bypass. I would like to see us adopt a different mechanism so that we may have greater opportunity to see what is involved in the treaties and to see that we take some action to ensure that the treaty mechanism is not used for purposes other than the actual treaties themselves.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform I support the Chairman, Senator Robert Ray, in moving the adoption of the report. The basis of this report arises from a reference to the Committee last year. The reference is in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of fixed formulae for determining the number of Senators and Members of the House of Representatives to which the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and other Territories are entitled.

This arose basically because when the Select Committee in an earlier Parliament brought in a very wide-ranging report of its references in 1983, Mr Ian Wilson of another place moved an amendment to seek to incorporate provisions regarding the representation of Territories. The Government then indicated that, whilst it would not accept that amendment then, it would make that reference.

The reference itself is a most interesting one. It points to the fact that a number of High Court of Australia judgments have shown that the Commonwealth Constitution in its present form leaves wide open the capacity of a Parliament to make representation for Territories. Until the High Court decisions in 1973, and particularly the decision in the McKellar case, nobody in this place or elsewhere fully realised the nature of that open window. The Senate will surely know that the Constitution is very explicit regarding the nature of the Senate. It makes it clear that there must be an equal representation of the originating States. The Senate has itself made the method of election by proportional representation. In another place in section 24 of the Constitution it provides:

The House of Representatives shall be composed of members directly chosen by the people of the Commonwealth, and the number of such members shall be, as nearly as practicable, twice the number of the senators.

I repeat that when the number of senators is fixed, based on equal representation in the States, there will be a formula that the House of Representatives numbers are fixed as being as nearly as practicable twice the number of senators. It will be noted from the Constitution that the House of Representatives shall be composed of members directly chosen by the people of the Commonwealth. It was not realised at the time that the decision of the High Court in relation to section 122 of the Commonwealth Consti- tution created some very interesting situations. For example, under that decision it became clear that members of the lower House or the Senate from the Territories need not be elected directly by the people. In other words, there need not be a popular franchise. I think that we are out of time in 1986 to envisage that the people of Australia would accept any kind of formula other than direct franchise. It became necessary to point to that fact and to recommend that something be done about it.

It became equally patently clear that not only could the Parliament determine a formula for indirect representation but also any individual member could have as many votes as the Parliament decided. Those of us who espouse the idea of one man, one vote would not, of course, have conceived the idea that a parliament would have given to a representative of the Territories, senator or lower House member, more than one vote. Yet that is possible.

It goes further. No relationship at all is prescribed by the Constitution at this moment to link the number of senators in terms of the number of lower House members. In fact, section 122 of the Constitution would allow a parliament to make as many representatives as the parliament so determined for the representation of the Territory in either the lower place or the Senate. Quite clearly, that is a worrying situation. One does not look with grave alarm at this because, in the ordinary sense of things, good and sensible things would be done. But it is possible for a parliament, a government, with a majority in the two places to so make alterations by way of legislation and not by way of referendum which could stack the Territories. I make no reflection on governments of either colour in this regard. It is quite possible to do what was known to be done in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries in other countries; that is, to simply stack it and, therefore, give a massive representation to a particular party of the day.

It became very desirable for this Parliament to have before it recommendations as to how Territories should be represented and then to consider how to go about some entrenchment of that representation. The Committee itself has worked out a formula based on, but not totally in parallel with, the Constitution. The Constitution says that we must first determine the number of senators and then double it for the number of people in the lower House. In effect, the Committee has said: First determine the population of a Territory, find out how many lower House people it is entitled to have and then have one senator to every two seats in the lower House, consistent with the guarantee of the minimum representations that now apply to the two Territories-that is, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

The Committee has said it would desire that this be put to the people in a referendum, but there were some difficulties in timing referenda and indeed in succeeding in a referendum. It would be a desirable thing, in the mind of the Committee, that this be put into legislative form and, therefore, passed as an Act in this Parliament so that the desirable formula is before the government of the day. It is likely, therefore, that the government of the day would not move away from it and, in due course, at a suitable time, by way of a referendum, entrench it. The Committee so recommended.

The Committee also looked at the question of new States. The question of new States may be one which will emerge in the future as perhaps the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory, in larger form, could move away, as the Northern Territory is now, from a community to a full State. The Committee has brought down a recommendation in a similar way. What has happened is that the recommendations have come following upon submissions by the major political parties and particularly by Mr Ian Wilson. I believe I am right in saying that the recommendations of the Committee are in parallel not only with Mr Wilson's formula but also with the submissions brought to the Committee by both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia. So there is a wide consensus of view. I believe I am right in saying that the National Party of Australia supports this principle. I think that it is a worthwhile development. I think that it is a common-sense situation. This Parliament and this Committee have done good work in trying to develop more and more a basic consensus in electoral reform. I believe this is a contribution to it and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the words of wisdom of Senator Ray, the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, and Senator Sir John Carrick, the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, regarding the findings of the Committee. I commend the Committee for the work that it has done. The Committee's report refers to the various Territories. I will speak briefly on the Northern Territory, as I see it now. The report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which was tabled in this chamber on Monday, has far-reaching implications for the people of the Northern Territory. The report, which deals with the entitlement of Federal Territories and new States to representation in the Commonwealth Parliament, is particularly relevant at this time, when the Territory is moving towards statehood. Before I address myself specifically to the electoral reforms proposed and how they relate to statehood, I take a few moments to give some details on the reasons for the statehood movement, which is gaining momentum in the Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The Territory has been self-governing for over seven years. Until last March the financial arrangement between the Territory and the Commonwealth had worked very well for the Territory. The present Northern Territory Government has, as a priority, provided much needed infrastructure to allow a formerly neglected Territory to commence the long march to economic self-sufficiency. As a result, over the last seven years much of the Territory Budget has been devoted to capital works such as roads, bridges, schools, houses, wharves and other necessities.

The Territory's growth rate is nearly four times the national average and 80 per cent of the Territory's people are less than 40 years of age. It is a young and dynamic region. Annual production increases in key areas since self-government have been impressive. The increases are: Mining, 25 per cent per annum; primary production, 30 per cent per annum, manufacturing, 25 per cent per annum; retailing, 25 per cent per annum; construction, 8 per cent per annum; and tourism expenditure, 10 per cent per annum. Those are very envious statistics. Employment has increased by 7 per cent per annum since self-government compared with the Australian average of 1.5 per cent.

However, the economy remains narrow in base and dependent on the public sector, in spite of its excellent record so far. The private sector continues to show confidence in the future of the top end, and last year private sector employment grew by a staggering 18 per cent. In the southern part of the Territory-the Alice Springs area-I would have thought that the figure would be at least that, with the developments taking place there. The Territory has great plans, and realistic plans, for the future. The railway from Alice Springs to Darwin will be an essential element in the land bridge linking Australia to the huge markets immediately to our north. Darwin will be Australia's front door to the region. It is now, but it needs much more of a boost. The Territory's agricultural and fishing industries, now in their infancies, will be contributing to its economy in a major way. However, in spite of these optimistic forecasts, a cloud has recently appeared on the horizon.

I referred earlier to the fact that until March last year our financial relationship with the Commonwealth had worked well for the Territory. That is no longer the case. The Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) has foreshadowed that from 1988 the Territory would be treated as a State financially. From 1988 the Territory will no longer receive special funding as compensation for its lack of power in the areas of uranium mining, national parks, Aboriginal land rights and off-shore royalties. Yet these are powers that rest with the States everywhere else in the Commonwealth except in the Territory. So the Territory will be asked to stand on its own two feet financially, just as if it were a State with full revenue raising power, yet it will remain deprived of that power.

The expectation by the Commonwealth that the Territory pay its way as a State, but be deprived of State-like revenue raising means, has been a catalyst for getting the statehood debate back on the boil. Many Territorians are seeing only one option-to go for statehood-statehood which returns control to Territorians over their own land, mining and off-shore royalties, statehood which puts the new State of the Northern Territory on an equal administrative footing to the other States.

There is a recognition in the Territory that the constitutional consideration of the whole statehood question will need to be debated extensively and there is no doubt that the Territory may hold differing views on the level of Federal representation which should be provided for the new State. That is where this report becomes very relevant. This report basically comes down in favour of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory retaining the levels of Federal representation-in both chambers-that they presently enjoy. It further adds that the Electoral Act, and eventually the Australian Constitution should be amended to enshrine a formula to provide for levels of Territory and new State representation based on population considerations. The report states specifically that the Committee was unimpressed by the Terri- tory's arguments in favour of greater House of Representatives representation than its population warrants. The Committee was also concerned by suggestions that that Territory should obtain equal Senate representation with the original States and could see no justification whatsoever for a proposal which would result in a gross over-representation of the Northern Territory.

I think that we are able to glean from these comments what the Federal Government's likely reaction to a Territory stance of requiring equal Senate representation will be-the Federal Government will say that 12 senators is just not on. But before we dismiss this possibility out of hand I think that we should look at the fundamental role of the Senate when it was originally set up at Federation-as a States House, to ensure the equality of the States. It will be a serious step to take the setting up of a second class State-one which is less equal than its partners. I am not advocating 12 senators outright for any new State. I am merely making the point that this is going to be one of the arguments which will arise in the context of the debate on statehood for the Northern Territory and I think that this report should not necessarily dictate the conditions-at present at any rate-under which the Northern Territory achieves statehood.

I am not entirely sure that to enshrine in the Constitution the sort of changes which are proposed by the Committee's recommendations is the proper course at a time when the debate over statehood in what I believe will become Australia's seventh State, and the only State to join the Commonwealth since Federation, is only just beginning in earnest. I believe that at this crucial time, for the sake of the Commonwealth and future States, we should consider very carefully any constitutional change which will bind us in a manner which we could come to regret later. There are a number of ways in which the whole issue of Senate and lower House representation for a new State might be approached, and one of these would be to develop a formula which allows for an immediate increase in the present level of Federal representation accorded to the Territory, with further increases to be determined until parity is reached. Perhaps this is close to the view of the Committee. This is only one of a number of options but it should not be excluded at this very early stage in a critical constitutional debate.

I look forward to the debate that will take place in the near future. It is of considerable importance that the Northern Territory become a State. I believe that the development of the north can take place only through the Northern Territory becoming a State and achieving its adulthood. I believe also that in this early stage of the debate it will be of tremendous interest to have the various views put forward, in the way that Senator Ray and Senator Sir John Carrick have both put forward their views in this report. I would like to see a very full debate take place, not only in this Parliament but also in other parliaments and throughout the nation. The debate, which should be full and free and without any restrictions, should be permitted before any premature move is made which might limit discussions.

SPEECH.PARA: The report provides the thinking behind the proposals which have been put forward by the Committee and how these proposals were arrived at. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Preparation by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform of the report entitled `Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament', to which I have appended a dissenting report, involved the Committee in a very useful exercise. It was very useful for the Committee to look at a subject that has been floating around in the background of debate about the Territories and the possibility of the creation of new States for quite some time now. It is a subject which has appeared at least three times on the agenda of Constitutional Conventions which have been held in Australia periodically over the past few years. The particular item that I disagreed with is one that I disagreed with because I did not see in any of the material which came before us or hear in any of the debate among members of the committee a basis on which to make the type of judgment that was made. Paragraph 4.1 of the Committee's report states that the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is strongly of the view that the principles we have determined as appropriate to apply to the representation of territories in the Parliament should also apply upon the admission of new States to the Federation.

I agreed with the majority of the Committee members with regard to the recommendations relating to Territories. They seemed to me to follow the types of developments that had already taken place in Australia and there did not seem to me to be good reasons advanced by anybody as to why those developments should be altered in any way. They seem to have fulfilled the task they were set. They have had a fairly chequered history. Indeed, they were part of the historic double dissolution. I think the results have shown that the representation of the Territories in this chamber and in the other chamber has worked well and seems appropriate for the constitutional development of Australia into the foreseeable future.

The part of the report with which I disagree relates to new States. As honourable senators who have been here for some time would know, I have been a champion for the development of new States in Australia. It has always been my firm belief that federalism in Australia has been blighted by the fact that we got to the point of developing only the few States we have instead of developing along the lines of the United States whereby States have covered smaller areas and there has been closer identification with the State governments and a more harmonious and homogeneous development of that vast continent.

I believe Australia would be a much better developed country and a much more decentralised country now if there had been the development of more States. Hence, in my own State of Queensland I have been, probably sole amongst senators in this place, a strong supporter of the notion of a new State for North Queensland. It seems to me that if we are ever to use the section in our Constitution concerning the development of new States we would have to do one of two things. Either we would have to accept what the Committee has recommended in the report-that is, the majority of the Committee members-or we would have to accept the proposition I have put. I do not think there are any other viable political solutions to the problem of the admission of new States to the Federation.

The majority of the Committee members came down on the side of looking at the population in a State to determine the number of representatives in the Senate. I rejected that in my dissenting report. I believe that the representation of any new State should be on an identical basis to that of existing States. The reason I gave is that, as I understand the constitutional operation, the House of Representatives is meant to have an equality of representation of the people. That representation is based on population. That is rightly so. It is the House in which traditionally, although it is not in the Constitution, our Prime Minister resides. It is the House from which the majority of members of the Cabinet come. It is seen to be the premier House in that sense. For example, it introduces the Budget. The Senate has been seen-I use here the words of Sir Isaac Isaacs-as representing an equality of statehood. Therefore, Tasmania and New South Wales have identical numbers of representatives in this place while there is an enormous disparity in population between those two States.

There may have been many other ways in which one could organise the representation in this place or not even have the Senate at all. However, it so happens that the federal system has been organised on the basis of equality of representation in the House of Representatives and an equality of statehood in the Senate. I believe that is the only principle on which we have to go. I believe that has to be maintained if we are to admit new States to the Federation. My argument is that if we admit new States-there is no compulsion to do so-we should admit those new States on identical terms to the original States. Looking down the track, I do not believe it would do Australia's constitutional development any good if we had two sets of States-the original States, with certain types of representation, and the new States with other types of representation. I think that would be the situation that we would find down the track. After all, we have to look ahead. This is a far-sighted report, as are the Committee and its Chairman. In looking down the track we have to look at that type of subsequent development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every new State means more politicians.

—I think Senator Harradine has made a point. That was a point raised constantly with the Committee, as Senator Harradine knows. I do not believe that with regard to the representation in the Senate of new States there is any principle which can operate other than that of equality of statehood. It may be an argument to say that we should not have the Northern Territory as a State. However, if we do, I think the subsequent logic of the operation ought to be to admit such a State on terms identical to those of the original States. Such a new State would have 12 senators. If that is of great concern to the Senate, I am quite happy to go on record as saying that I do not think the Senate's numbers should have been increased. Indeed, I voted against that increase of 10 senators to 12 senators. In fact, I would be quite happy if we went back to our constitutional base of six senators for each State.

SPEECH.PARA: As the new States are introduced we should reduce the number of senators from each State. Basically, that would keep the number of senators the same and it would not require any development in terms of the House of Representatives. I am happy enough for us to do that. It seems to me that, whatever principle is used, there could be an argument for that type of operation. It will not happen, of course, because no party in government would be able to get sufficient senators on side to organise that type of thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor could you.

—I admit that; that is probably a valid interjection. On the same point, we have to be careful not to instil into any subsequent constitutional development-after all, that is what this report was talking about-anything other than a principle of proper representation. I go back to the words of Sir Isaac Isaacs, who said that the Senate represents equality of statehood. No other principle seems to me to come into the matter. As I said in my dissenting report to the Committee, I cannot see in any of the material that has been presented to us and in any of the discussions that we have had any other firm principle upon which we could stand. This chamber is not the House of Representatives. It has a different function. It has a different constitutional base. While we have that-I do not want to bring in the argument as to whether or not we should-it seems to me that it needs to retain that principal base of equality of statehood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a few moments to speak on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform on Determining the Entitlements of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament, because I believe that quite a large number of honourable senators wish to speak on other reports. First of all, I acknowledge the work that has been done by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Robert Ray and the Deputy Chairman, Senator Sir John Carrick. I also thank my colleagues, including Senator Macklin, who have worked quite hard on this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that too few people understand the workings of the Senate and its committees and the enormous amount of time that needs to go into studying the submissions that are made to each of the committees. I know that on the five or six committees of which I am a member, the amount of time spent studying for them is about double the time needed by me to study what comes before this chamber. To put it into perspective and to refer to what Senator Robertson said, I believe it is important for people to note that members of committees do give due consideration and weight to the evidence that is put forward and do spend a great deal of time considering that evidence before making certain recommendations. Of course, members of this committee are supported very ably by Mr Donald Nairn and his staff, as members are supported by the committee staff on other committees on which I work. I notice that Miss Anne Lynch is a clerk at the table. She is head of the committee system, and I acknowledge her work in this regard.

Very briefly I point out that we were faced with the possibility that some government in the future would use the opportunity of stacking the Parliament unless some recommendation were made by the Committee and ultimately incorporated in legislation. We believe that such a recommendation ought ultimately be incorporated in the Constitution. The point that was made by Senator Macklin is fair. If there are to be new States, why will they not have equality of representation in this chamber with existing States? Like him, I voted against the move by the government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say you voted against politicians like me?

—Did I say that? I voted with Senator Macklin and with the Liberal Party of Australia against the increase in the size of the Parliament. Unfortunately, the Labor Government, supported by the National Party of Australia, voted for an increase in the number of members of parliament.

—Unless they do not get any.
—Especially if they do not get any.
—We could take them back to ten.

—I agree with that, but to be quite frank, I think we could take the number back to six. As has been stated here, if we cut the number of State representatives in the Senate back to six, what will be done with the House of Representatives? I do not mind that happening, but I do not think we will get too many starters for that proposition amongst the members of the House of Representatives. In closing, I must say that we had to consider all of these questions. We had to come to a balanced decision. I think that in all of the circumstances the recommendation is a balanced one. As Senator Robertson said, and as I think Senator Kilgariff mentioned, it is only a recommendation, but it is a recommendation made after evidence has been considered and one which, no doubt, will be considered throughout the length and breadth of this country and, in particular, in the Northern Territory and in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform on Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament, I thank all senators who have spoken in the debate for their contribution. It has been a very rational debate, and I thank them for that. Of course, there has not been much reaction to this report. It is fairly esoteric in the extreme. There was one reaction, from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) in the other place. He put out a fairly inflammatory Press release attacking the Committee and accusing some of the Committee members of his own political persuasion of being traitors.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a little disappointed in Mr Everingham's actions because I note that when the report was tabled in the House of Representatives he did not even bother to debate it there in the chamber, where matters are normally open to response and there is the to and fro of debate. Instead, he sent a Press release back to the Northern Territory. So extravagant are his claims that I really doubt whether he has ever read the report. I would have thought with his being reduced to the back bench from the front bench by Mr Howard that he would have a lot more time on his hands. I suppose, if one represents the Northern Territory and lives in Brisbane one would be pretty busy, and he probably has not had time to read this report. But such inflammatory remarks do this debate no good. I suggest to Mr Everingham that he should follow the example of his colleague Senator Kilgariff, who made a very constructive contribution this afternoon.

It will come as no surprise to the Senate that I do not support Senator Macklin's minority report. His claim that quality of representation in some way derives from the Constitution is, in my view, baseless. Section 121, which deals with this matter, provides that:

The Parliament may admit to the Commonwealth or establish new States, and . . . make and impose such terms and conditions, including the extent of representation in either House of the Parliament, as it thinks fit.

It is quite clear from the Convention debates that the founding fathers had the absolute view that new States, new territories or whatever else, was negotiable. Otherwise they would have entrenched it in the Constitution at the time. I am backed up in this view by one of the best sources on the Constitution by Quick and Garran, which states:

Under the Constitution of the Commonwealth the Federal Parliament has a free hand in deciding the terms and conditions under which a new member may be admitted into the Federal family system. It will be at liberty to impose such stipulations as it thinks fit, unhampered by considerations of equality of Original States.

I think the Northern Territory is far more likely to become a State if 12 senators are not admitted. If that is the condition of their admission, I think senators from other States would be very much opposed to its being granted statehood.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they recognise that.

—I think many do. What we have said has entrenched this in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. When we come to negotiate a compact on admitting a new State, there is nothing to stop a change to its having two senators. That is negotiable and that can be entrenched in the Constitution. What we are worried about are the very points that Senator Sir John Carrick stressed. This Constitution is wide open to stacking and rorting by a malevolent government. There is no sign in the past or the future that that government will emerge but, if it does, let us protect ourselves. I suggest to those who argue for 12 senators in the Northern Territory that I know population is not really a consideration, but common sense is. Having one senator for every 5,000 electors seems to me to be ridiculous in the extreme. New South Wales has one senator for every 250,000 electors.

SPEECH.PARA: I am, of course, very cross with Senator Harradine. He has let the cat out of the bag. I was not going to mention it today, but he rightly pointed out that if 12 new senators and statehood are awarded to the Northern Territory, there will be 24 new members of the House of Representatives. My good friend Senator Boswell smiles because both he and I have been strong supporters of the expansion of the Parliament. But I doubt whether he or I at this moment want another 24 members of the House of Representatives. But I am cross with Senator Harradine because when a few of the members representing marginal seats who are my friends hear of this, they will scuttle to my office, asking for statehood for the Northern Territory, a redistribution, a safe seat for them and a pension. So Senator Harradine has done us a disservice today. This will bring a big conflict for the Australian Democrats' philosophical position. It is not good enough to say that we will go back to the position of old, prior to 1949, of having six senators. The tide will not turn. That is not politically realistic. Therefore, any increase in the size of the Senate caused by the creation of a new State would really involve 24 new House of Representatives politicians which, I am sure, the Democrats oppose and we at this stage regard as unnecessary.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Natural Resources of the Australian Antarctic Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 February, on motion by Senator Zakharov:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I managed to speak for three minutes last week and it looks as though I will get the same amount of time today.
—Senator, you will have a full 10 minutes tonight.

—Good. I will try not to take up the entire time because I know that others wish to speak. When the debate was adjourned last week I was explaining that my tabling speech had already been incorporated in Hansard in the last week of the previous session. Today I will not be attempting an overview of the Committee's report, but want to concentrate on a few aspects which might not otherwise get attention. First, I would like to thank the Committee staff, particularly those who worked on the final report, Peter Roberts, Judy Ryan and Jane Fallick. The report was unanimous and this result was achieved only after a great deal of discussion and redrafting, which meant a lot of extra work for those staff members. I also thank those members of the Committee who participated in that final process, for their willingness to discuss and to listen was in the best tradition of Senate committees. I also thank past members of the Committee and particularly two past chairmen, Senator Robertson and Senator Primmer.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that this was a unanimous report, a report which does not put an ambit claim in any direction or area, but seeks to ensure that Australia's interests and the interests of the world community are served, while preserving a unique environment. At the same time the Committee recognised the realities of the Antarctic Treaty and its limitations-indeed, the limitations inherent in the implementation and enforcement of any agreement in such a remote area.

The inquiry was prolonged because we reached a point in 1984 when we believed that at least some members of the Committee should have direct knowledge of conditions at Antarctic stations, to verify what we had been told by witnesses and to try to sort out some of the conflicting evidence. Accordingly, Senator Crichton-Browne and I, together with the Committee secretary, visited Casey station in the Australian Antarctic Territory in the summer of 1984-85. We travelled on the Icebird then on its maiden voyage under charter to the Australian Government, spending one week at Casey and two weeks at sea. Thus we were able to get some insight into conditions and work at Antarctic stations through observations, numerous discussions with expeditioners and other division staff at the station and during the voyage. I believe we were the first Australian parliamentarians to spend that length of time at an Antarctic station and to take some active part in its work, such as unloading supplies and collecting rubbish for return to Australia.

The charter of the Icebird, now extended for a further five years, has made significant differences to the pace and volume of work possible in the Australian Antarctic Territory, even given the appalling weather conditions of this summer. That charter has expanded available space for passengers and cargo, thus spending the rebuilding program; it has lengthened the time of access to the Territory through its ice navigation capacity; and has enabled the backloading of rubbish accumulated at our stations since the beginning of our involvement in Antarctica. Speaking of rubbish, the Committee has noted with approval the plans for future disposal in ways which will not affect the environment, including the return to Australia of non-disposable wastes, such as fuel drums. But recent reports in newspapers about the prevalence of rubbish at Casey make me wonder whether a special effort was made for us last summer. The reports certainly require follow-up.

I have had an interest in Antarctica since school days and have read widely on Antarctic expeditions and research. Even so, I found that my perceptions of the Antarctic continent and its surrounding ocean were a very pale image of reality. I am very pleased that Australians, thanks mainly to television programs, are now beginning to understand more about our Australian Antarctic Territory and appreciate its value in environmental terms. For example, few Australians are aware that Australia's claim covers over 40 per cent of the Antarctic continent, equivalent in area to 78 per cent of Australia. Antarctica is the world's driest continent. The precipitation rate in the Casey area is about two inches per annum. Thus the snow melts in summer to reveal dust underneath. The vegetation is confined to mosses and lichens; the wild life on shore to seals and birds. The result is a very fragile environment indeed which means that environmental damage even if not irreversible takes years to regenerate. Yet it is only recently that the same sort of environmental safeguards have been instituted there as are enforced in most states of Australia, such as environmental management plans at the stations.

I draw attention to recommendations 22 and 23 of the report which call for the incorporation of further environmental control measures in the Antarctic treaty system. In recommendation 15 we seek the protection of the Antarctic environment, at the same level as is afforded to its flora and fauna. It is no good protecting flora and fauna if they have no habitat. As a psychologist as well as a senator, I draw attention to recommendation 26, which reads:
the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee should as soon as possible determine priority areas for Australia's Antarctic science program including the need for research in the social sciences.
Similarly, I draw attention to recommendation 28 which states:
an external agency review the adequacy of the Antarctic Division's expeditioner selection and training procedures.

Selection procedures, I believe, need to be oriented to seeking those who are able to adapt to life in Antarctica rather than the emphasis given in the past to technical competence alone. People in Antarctica work and live under conditions of great physical stress, particularly in winter, and that has been investigated by medical science; but they also work in a very small community almost totally isolated from the rest of the world and in constant, inescapable contact with others whom they did not choose. Until the rebuilding program is finished, the people at Casey will continue to sleep in small areas separated only by curtains, the only alternative areas in winter being work rooms and a small recreational area. These pressures had, on some, obvious psychological and behavioural effects which make life difficult for that individual and for his or her companions and also lessens efficiency. On the question of training I will quote briefly from our report. It states:

From the observations of the Committee members who travelled to Casey on the Icebird during the 1984-85 summer, it was obvious that in a number of important areas training is inadequate. These areas are:
- small boat and cargo handling (including Army LARCs)
there have been reports again this summer of that deficiency-
- adherence to safety procedures
- environmental protection measures.

I repeat that these inadequacies were directly observed. The other recommendation to which I want to draw attention is the one concerning icebergs as a freshwater source. On the surface this may seem fanciful, but there has been a lot of international research on the feasibility of harvesting icebergs with no damage to the environment. I believe it may be the future answer to the freshwater needs of a city such as Adelaide. Obviously I have commented on only a few of the 28 recommendations in this report. I have not addressed in the brief time available the more complex questions, for example, of Australia's sovereignty. I hope honourable senators and all Australians interested in the future of Antarctica will read the full report. I look forward to an early response from the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the Senate Standing Committee on Natural Resources on its report. It shows an awareness of the Antarctic which I hope will be shared by the Government. Recommendation 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: the Australian Government continue to support the Antarctic treaty. It also recommends that Australia encourage the adaptation of the Antarctic Treaty system to meet changing circumstances, such as the increasing emphasis on environmental protection and the need for greater participation in Antarctic decision-making processes, without prejudice to Australia's sovereignty claim.

At the moment the Antarctic is seen in two lights-some see it as the last great wilderness on earth and some see it as the last great open pit mine. In fact, I lean to the former view-it is the last great wilderness. In the late twentieth century we should realise that we have an obligation to preserve this wilderness. We have reduced the others to mere scraps, mere remnants of what they once were and the Antarctic is our chance to show that we, as human beings, have the recognition, the education and the foresight to preserve an area which is still relatively unaffected. I say `relatively unaffected' because Australia is rapidly polluting the Antarctic environment. I bring to the Senate's attention an article which appeared in the Hobart Mercury of 12 February 1986. I normally do not give much credence to what appears in the Mercury, or the Mockery as we call it in Hobart, but this does appear to have an imprint of truth. I will bring it to the Senate's attention. The article deals with the mess which surrounds our Antarctic bases. The headline reads `Antarctic bases a mess: scientist'. The article states:

A leading British Antarctic scientist has called on Australia to carry out a massive clean-up of Casey and Wilkes stations, in Antarctica, after witnessing a string of examples of `appalling' environmental neglect there during the summer.

In a stinging attack, Dr Ron Lewis-Smith cites the neglect as evidence that Australia is not abiding by the Antarctic Treaty and is more concerned with securing its territorial claims with `grandiose' station developments than with scientific research.
He backs this up with his own observations. The article continues:

He notes that Australia is doing little science at Casey (only one scientist will spend the 1986 winter there) and no program has been considered which would justify the major rebuilding program-and its attendant environmental desecration-going on there.
