DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this debate was interrupted I had identified the two basic themes which seemed to have run through the opposition to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill at least so far as the contributions in this chamber are concerned. The first theme was that the Bill is unnecessary and, secondly, that it is undesirable, indeed undesirable in some people's minds to the point of being dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the first point, the alleged lack of necessity in this legislation, I had begun by dealing with the argument that the common law was the great protector of individual rights and was, indeed, a sufficient protector of rights beyond which we needed no support of the kind embodied in this Bill. I called in aid an admirable contribution to the debate from Senator Puplick in which he demonstrated comprehensively and precisely just how that argument could not be sustained. The reality of the matter is that there are a number of rights and freedoms matters where there is a vacuum in the law and which the common law has at the moment absolutely nothing to say. The reality also is that there are a number of other areas where reality also is that there are a number of other areas where the legislatures have filled the vacuums, but in an unacceptable way, again leaving in a different fashion the courts with nothing to say-nothing to say because there is no hook on which they, the judges, or the litigants before them, can hand an argument advanced for the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms.

The reality is that rights and freedoms cannot be left to be secured by default; they do require active care and attention by legislatures around the country. They require active care and attention both in the form of individual measures in specific areas such as race and sex discrimination legislation; property protection legislation; criminal investigation; law protection legislation and all the other piecemeal areas with which we have become familiar. They also need protection by the kinds of overarching, overriding, standard setting, guarantee-producing legislation of the kind involved in this Bill of Rights. It is necessary that our human rights performance in this country be better than it has been in the past, whatever the standards of comparison that might properly be made between us and many other countries in the world with worse human rights records. We have done well in the past but we can do a lot better. The judges and courts could do with the extra reinforcement and weaponry in the interests of rights and liberties which this Bill will give them.

Let me turn to the group of arguments which says that this Bill of Rights is positively undesirable and dangerous. So many statements which have been made here and outside the Parliament have been so wildly and grotesquely astray that they have been difficult to take seriously. Let me at least try to deal quickly with some of the more extravagant claims that have been made. A lot of more detailed points, I guess, can be made during the Committee stage of this debate, which I do not think will be short.

Firstly, we have had the constantly reiterated and dogmatically asserted argument that this is a Bill which takes away rights, that fewer rights will be enjoyed in the community than before the Bill of Rights was ever dreamed of. The basic argument which seems to prevail when people run this line is that a number of rights around the place which are recognised as important or in some cases fundamental are not specifically addressed in this Bill. The right to own property and not to have it acquired unjustly or compulsorily is often repeated as being in this category. As I said earlier in this speech, and no doubt will be saying again a dozen times before this debate is out, this Bill of Rights contains a very central and important Article which protects absolutely, unequivocally and clearly those rights which may exist but which are not set out in the list in this Bill. I am referring to Article 2 of the Bill of Rights, which makes it absolutely clear that any right which is not set out in the Bill of Rights, but which may otherwise exist, is not to be regarded as diminished in any way by not appearing in this otherwise fairly comprehensive list.

A second claim that is made about the alleged dangers of the Bill goes to the suggestion that it gives protection to certain alleged rights around the place, or claims of right, which, if protected, would undermine the fabric of society. Thus, it is suggested that the Bill would operate to legalise abortion, to encourage and legalise homosexual adoption, to authorise the confiscation of private property, and half a dozen extravagant claims of this kind. I can assert absolutely, without fear of rational contradiction, that claims of this kind are absolutely false and without foundation.

I give just one example of a claim which has been made and which featured as recently as Senator Lewis's contribution to this debate late this afternoon; that is, the extravagant claim that this Bill, at least in its original form, would have operated so as to legalise homosexual marriage. How on earth could anyone read into any of the provisions of this Bill that it could legalise homosexual marriage? A lot of people have chosen to read that in because of the language of the first draft of this Bill of Rights, which simply said:
All persons have the right to marry. Every man and woman of marriageable age shall have the right to marry.

So we had the lunatic argument that `all persons' meant, construed literally, that men could marry men and women could marry women. All I say in relation to that is that I do not think it is seriously advanced by any of the people around this place that the Pope is in favour of homosexual marriage. Yet we have a document, the Charter of the Rights of the Family, presented a little while ago by the Holy See, in which we find in Article 1, as the pre-eminent right of the family, the proposition, not qualified in any way by reference to `opposite sex' or language of this kind, which states:
All persons have the right . . . to marry . . . every man and every woman, having reached marriage age . . . has the right to marry . . .

That is the kind of distortion we get. Nobody would remotely think that language of that kind could be construed as an invitation to, encouragement of or justification for homosexual marriage, yet such is the perverse, twisted and distorted-sometimes deliberately so-mentality that people have taken to the Bill of Rights that they have asserted that language like this, which appears in a document from the Holy See, is capable of that construction when it appears in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. It is a nonsensical chain of argument, one which we have heard ad nauseum and about which we have been driven to distraction.

Then we have the alleged dangers involved in leaving the interpretation of rights to unelected judges, as distinct from distinguished parliamentarians and self-restrained legislators of the kind who have acted in civil liberties matters in the past. There are several answers to that claim. This is a theme which again can be picked up in more detail at the Committee stage. The first is that it underestimates dramatically the extent to which judges are already involved in determining sensitive issues in their administration of the common law; in particular, in a system such as ours with a written Constitution, in adjudicating on disputes that arise under that Constitution. Judges have a sensitive and delicate task already involving the exercise of judgment, which they exercise very well, and it is nonsense to suggest that they will be exercising some fundamentally new role in any potentially dangerous way as a result of this legislation being passed. I quote from one of the most distinguished law lords in British judicial history, Lord Scarman, who, in a lecture in 1980, said:

We can, therefore, dismiss as completely unsound such objections as those which, frequently heard in the United Kingdom, are variations on the theme that judges must not be brought into the political arena. They are there already-as umpires, not gladiators or competitors. They have always been there: and there they will remain. There is nothing inappropriate in requiring judges to decide justiciable issues arising in a political struggle: and no reason for judges not to be trusted to act judicially and according to law, though the case raises political as well as legal questions.

There is a comprehensive and very effective rebuttal of that particular line of argument. One can expect Australian judges to find the interpretation of the Bill of Rights an unfamiliar task, but we can reasonably expect them to cope very well with that task, just as their brethren in Canada have. I had the pleasure of talking about just this issue with the Canadian Chief Justice, Sir Brian Dickson, very recently. He made just that point; that a Bill of Rights, although initially unfamiliar, had become part of the judicial landscape and the courts are responding to it constructively and effectively.

Finally, the answer to the concern about the role of an unelected judiciary is that under this kind of legislation, and designedly so, Parliament has the last word. If the judgment of the courts goes astray, in the opinion of this Parliament, we will retain the capacity to legislate an appropriate amendment accordingly. Among this litany of complaints about the dangers associated with the Bill of Rights, a number of suggestions are made about the dangerous powers being vested in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It is extraordinary that so much should be made of this and so little regard should be had to the character of this institution that is being created, or very largely recreated out of the existing Human Rights Commission, because it is an institution which exercises investigative, conciliatory and reporting functions in exactly the same way as scores of other similar institutions now enshrined in statute law at both Commonwealth and State levels with powers that are not in any significant way different from the powers exercised by dozens of other similar institutions.

The Government is prepared and willing to listen carefully to arguments that may be made in the Committee stage on this question. It may be that different views can reasonably be held on the scale of penalties or the need for self-incrimination provisions of the kind that appear in some 90 other statutes. The argument may be made, which we will listen to, about the need for compulsory conferences and so on, but I simply do not accept the validity of the root and branch attack that has been made. I particularly do not accept it when I have regard, as I hope other honourable senators will, to the very clear precedent which exists in the Human Rights Commission, which now exists as a result of legislation enacted by the Fraser Government. The element of hypocrisy and humbug in the attack on the proposed Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission model, when one compares what is involved in the proposal here with what exists at the moment, is really quite breathtaking.

Let me finish by saying this: None of the criticism that has been made of the Bill has in any way destroyed its credibility as the most far-reaching and far-sighted attempt in our history to secure the protection of fundamental rights and liberties. As such, this Bill deserves the support of every fair-minded Australian. I think it would be a tragedy if the vagaries of party politics and the feeling in some quarters, which I understand, that the Bill does not go far enough in its application should result in this Bill being relegated to the scrapheap of history where so many other proposals to increase and improve the condition of human rights and liberties in Australia have ended before it. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

Some 20 or 30 senators have spoken on this legislation. No doubt Senator Evans would be gratified if he were allowed to speak again on the legislation. If he is allowed to do that he ought to speak on the other points which were raised by other honourable senators and which he has not answered.

SPEECH.PARA: The point raised by Senator Harradine about the right of freedom of association will be debated very vigorously in the course of the Committee stage debate. The Opposition has no objection whatever to the provision that there should be a freedom of association. However, the point at issue is whether there should be a right not to join a union. The Opposition will certainly be strongly advocating such a provision, as will the Australian Democrats, who have foreshadowed amendments. TALK.START.PARA: —If only in order to forestall Senator Harradine exercising his right of reply, I might indicate that, firstly, I admire his ingenuity and, secondly, I agree with Senator Durack that it is ingenuity better directed towards a debate at the Committee stage. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Constitutional Commission: Membership-Newspaper Article: Sydney Morning Herald-Tasmania: Woodchip Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under Sessional Order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the noise has died down I point out to the Senate that I am the first of three to speak in the adjournment debate and the longer honourable senators prolong the agony the longer it is going to be. I draw to the attention of the Senate and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who is on duty, a comment that was made in the House of Representatives on 28 November 1985 in which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government takes the view that women are entitled to have a say on all subjects, in all decision-making forums of Government, and not just decisions on so-called `womens issues'.
He went on to say:
We are determined to improve our already substantial record in the numbers of women appointed to government boards and authorities . . .

One would have thought that that was a reasonably definite statement from the man who, in fact, heads this Government with regard to his attitude and the Australian Labor Party's attitude to the role women should play in the community and in particular the role they should play in and on bodies and authorities which help governments formulate policies and put them into effect, as well as those sorts of organisations that make recommendations to governments, and in doing so one would hope influence their thinking.

Today we had a piece of legislation brought down which aims also to improve the role of women in the community, to encourage them, and to encourage employers in the community to regard merit as the primary criterion for employment and not somebody's marital status, age, or sex. This requires, of course, some encouragement for people to change long-held attitudes. This is to be commended, notwithstanding the fact that the legislation contains no enforcement provisions and no sanctions against any of the organisations that are to be covered by the legislation if they choose not to comply.

Having made those statements and drawn the attention of honourable senators and in particular Ministers, to those alleged initiatives of the Labor Party, I turn to the terms of reference of the new Constitutional Commission that was brought forward by the Prime Minister on 31 January this year. They state:
To inquire into and report on or before 30 June 1988, on the revision of the Australian Constitution to:
(a) adequately reflect Australia's status as an independent nation and a Federal Parliamentary democracy;
(b) provide the most suitable framework for the economic, social and political development of Australia as a federation;
(c) recognise an appropriate division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth, the States, self-governing Territories and local government; and
(d) ensure that democratic rights are guaranteed.

The important one of those for the purposes of my comments tonight is the second term of reference; namely, the one in which the people on the Commission are to inquire into a revision of the Australian Constitution in order to provide the most suitable framework for the economic, social and political development of Australia as a Federation. In his speech bringing down the details of the Commission, the Prime Minister said:

The wide range of community interests and talent that is represented in the Commission and its advisory committees should ensure that proposals are examined from a variety of perspectives that are of concern to Australians.
He continued:

In this way the efforts of this group of active and articulate Australians may serve to demystify the constitutional processes and encourage thoughtful consideration by ordinary Australians of the shape of our Constitution.

I do not know whether by that he meant that one member of the Commission, namely Peter Garrett, was going to set the Constitution to music or turn some of the clauses into song form. Anyway, the aim is to demystify the constitutional processes and encourage thoughtful consideration by ordinary Australians of the shape of our Constitution. Nobody in this chamber, I would have thought, would have questioned that, particularly given the fact that in the recent debate on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Australian Bill of Rights Bill there has been a clear indication that very few people indeed know what is in our Constitution and how the various levels of constitutional processes work. Mr Hawke went on to say:

The Government has consciously sought to set up the Commission and advisory committees on a non-partisan basis and is hopeful that this will contribute to the fostering of an agreed view among those in Australian politics who give leadership on such matters to the Australian people.
Finally, he said:
We owe it to ourselves and to future Australians to do our very best to ensure that our constitutional framework is effective and well adapted to modern needs and circumstances.

He then announced the membership of the Commission and of its advisory committees. It is that list of people, eminent though they may be, that throws up the inherent contradiction between what the Australian Labor Party in government, and its Prime Minister in particular, says and what it does in effect, because this Constitutional Commission-the Commission which has as one of its main terms of reference to provide the most suitable framework for the economic, social and political development of Australia as a Federation-has two women on it. I do not have any doubt at all that a large number of the people who are on the Constitutional Commission are eminent jurists and eminent people in other fields. Who could indeed quibble at the presence of Sir Zelman Cowen on that advisory committee and who could argue with the presence of a number of the other people on the Commission, including the Chairman, Sir Maurice Byers, Q.C? I was amused, however, to note that in the list that was issued officially of people on the committees one of the only two women on the Constitutional Commission as a whole is Philippa Smith who appears on this list as Phillip Smith, which gives some indication of the fact that governments are all too unused to having women on committees and cannot get their names right when they do.

This has prompted considerable concern among groups in the community which believe that the Constitution certainly does need updating, that perhaps one of the best ways of doing it is to take it outside of the political arena where the old constitutional conventions belonged, and to give it to eminent people. One of the organisations that keeps a weather-eye on governments, bureaucracies and organisations with regard to protecting the interests of women-that is, the Women's Electoral Lobby-said:

How does the Government justify appointing only two women to the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees when its stated policy as per the National Agenda for Women is to provide fair representation for women on government boards and authorities?

While not in any way questioning the capacity of most-I am by no means enthusiastic about all-of the members of the Commission, I wonder whether the Government can tell us whether it considered in any way at all some of the extremely eminent and capable women who are both jurists and employed in other areas in the community whose talents, experience and expertise would no doubt have contributed greatly to the Commission and the advisory committees.

I refer to people such as Justice Elizabeth Evatt; Mary Gaudron; Wendy McCarthy; Mary Owen, now that she has time on her hands; Professor Bettina Cass; Kath Walker-if one is looking to combining two spheres of interest perhaps and getting value for money in doing so-Professor Dame Leonie Kramer, whose expertise and capabilities are well known around the country; Susan Armstrong, who I have known for many years and is currently Sub-Dean of the New South Wales Law Faculty; Dr Jocelyn Scutt, who is well known for her research work and is currently Deputy Chair of the Victorian Law Reform Commission; Regina Greycar; and Pat O'Shane. Perhaps-although not now that she is so free of the New South Wales Parliament, as I understand that she is heading overseas-the Government could have considered somebody of the calibre of Rosemary Foot. Perhaps the Government could have considered women such as Eve Mahlab, a lawyer and businesswoman who is outspoken, capable and aware of what is going on and what is needed in the community; Anne Deveson; Carol Baker; Pam O'Neil; indeed, Dame Roma Mitchell; Marcia Neave, who is currently responsible for a number of inquiries into various things to do with women; and Quentin Bryce from Queensland, a lawyer, who was involved with the National Women's Advisory Council and is extremely competent, articulate and intelligent. The list goes on. Yet apparently either the Government did not consider any of these women or for some reason that we do not know about approached all of them and, for all I know many others, and was turned down.

I think that it is incumbent on the Government, in view of the comments that it has made on the national agenda for women and its assertions about the need for affirmative action, sex discrimination legislation and so on, to give us some answers to a few questions. I am not the only one who requires this information. Nor is it just an issue for groups such as the Women's Electoral Lobby to get concerned about. Senator Peter Baume, to his very great credit, put out some Press releases some days ago again condemning the Government along the same lines that I have done this evening. I think that the Government needs to answer the sorts of questions that Senator Baume, the Women's Electoral Lobby and other groups in the community have raised with regard to the membership of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees.

We could start by asking the Minister why only two women were appointed to the 39-member Commission and its advisory committees. We could go on to ask whether the appointment of only two women reflects the Government's opinion that none of the names of the women I have mentioned, or any others for example, are suitable for appointment. We could ask the Minister whether he could explain how the Government reconciles this gross under-representation of women on the Constitutional Commission with its stated commitment to the fair representation of women in all decision-making forms of government in the National Agenda for Women. We could finish by asking the Minister to consider the fact that women comprise more than 50 per cent of the population of this country and in doing so to consider giving an assurance that the Government will review the composition of the Constitutional Commission to ensure equal representation for women. It will not be sufficient for him to say `Ah, but the people on the Commission will consider the views, needs and concerns of women'. Too often in history it has been shown that often with the best will in the world men are not in a position to understand the concerns of women-either those in the home or those in the work force. Indeed, they do not consider women who live alone or women who have children whom they have to support. These are women who have needs which must be met and which, perhaps, the men have not experienced. There is not necessarily malice involved, but people like Senator Walters, Senator Vanstone and me are in this chamber only because women realised that women had a role to play in this place. They agitated at the turn of the century and before in many countries throughout the world to give us the right not only to vote but also to be elected to this Parliament and other parliaments in order to put the views of women.

There is no requirement that we should all agree on everything. Nor should there be. Similarly there should not be a requirement that all men should agree on everything. While Senator Walters and I agree on some things, we disagree violently on others; and I am sure that applies to us all. Nevertheless, we have a perspective and a set of experiences which differ from those of our male colleagues, however much in sympathy with us they may be. Therefore, I put the proposition seriously this evening that the Prime Minister and the Government should consider how disparate are their comments about the need to take account of the views and concerns of women and their actions in establishing bodies like the new Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the election is over in my State, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, is reneging on an agreement undertaken between him and the Premier of my State, Mr Robin Gray, on the woodchipping industry. That is of great concern to me. Honourable senators will remember the dreadful fuss last November when the radical conservatives and the Australian Democrats in this Senate attempted to stop woodchipping throughout the whole of Tasmania. Honourable senators will remember the matter of public importance that was raised in this place and the accusations that were flying back and forth. They will also remember that eventual agreement between Mr Kerin and the Premier was reached; and I believe that that agreement was amicable.

SPEECH.PARA: That agreement covered the following things: The duration of the licences-and that was for 15 years-and the quantities of timber involved; the environmental procedures to be adopted on forest operations from which pulp wood for woodchip exports was to be obtained, and I stress that that was for woodchip exports over which the Commonwealth Government has power; research work related to the forest management of these operations; the process for reporting progress of these operations to the Commonwealth; and procedures for dealing with operations in the areas listed on the register of the National Estate wherein the State would take into account the views of the Commonwealth. Those were all the matters raised by Mr Kerin. Mr Gray and Mr Kerin came to an agreement. That agreement was signed by Mr Gray on 9 January this year. It was forwarded to the Government for Mr Kerin's signature. While we in Tasmania were waiting patiently for that signature we were completely unsuspecting of the fact that the Minister would go back on his agreement. It is of great concern that we hear now that Mr Kerin is claiming that the Federal Government now requires control over timber taken for domestic use from those areas registered in the National Estate and mentioned in the agreement.

I will explain first what is happening in our State in regard to woodchipping. We have just had an election in which Bob Brown and Dr Bates have been elected-one for Denison and the other for Franklin-purely on the conservation issue. I believe this matter has been handled in a most dishonest fashion. What we have mentioned, and very glibly mentioned, are the words `National Estate' and `World Heritage areas'. Nobody in Tasmania really understands the difference. The World Heritage areas are areas which already have been set aside by Tasmania as wilderness areas. There are national parks and there are wilderness areas. The World Heritage areas are areas in which the State does not conduct any woodchipping or forestry at all. The National Estate areas can be nominated by anyone. Any honourable senator opposite could nominate such an area, just as I could. The World Heritage Commission can put that area on the register.

Mr Brown talks glibly about the National Estate areas. He talks about them as though they are World Heritage areas. The people get confused and really believe that we are conducting forestry operations in the World Heritage areas, which we are not doing at all. We are conducting, as we always have conducted, forestry operations in National Estate areas. Indeed, forestry was operating in these areas long before they were National Estate areas. They were declared National Estate areas after they had already been granted to many of our companies to use in most responsible and appropriate manner for forestry operations in our State. Part of those operations involved woodchipping.

As we all know, the Federal Government has complete control over forestry exports. However, it does not have control over the domestic use of the timber taken from those areas. The agreement signed by Mr Gray and spoken of by Mr Kerin and, indeed, the report put out by the Commonwealth made it very clear that the Commonwealth had powers only over the export side of the industry-that is, the woodchip side because that is the area of export. I would like to quote from the statement which the Premier made at a media conference. He said:

I met with Mr Kerin in Canberra on 20 November 1985 and indicated that the State would be prepared to agree to certain matters. On 9 January 1986 I signed an agreement covering these matters and forwarded it to Mr Kerin for his signature.
These were the matters which I spoke of and listed a little earlier. Mr Gray continued:

These were all matters which Mr Kerin raised with me on 20 November. In fact at that meeting he made it quite clear that neither he nor the Commonwealth wished to become involved in domestic operations. He stated that he had no power to do so.

It is clear from the document which the Commonwealth brought out on the woodchip licence decision entitled `A balance of values', that the intention was simply to cover operations from which pulpwood for export would be taken and I quote:

`An important part of the agreement will be a Commonwealth-State consultation process to address, through forward planning protection of heritage values of areas listed on the register of the National Estate-
the National Estate, not the World Heritage area-
which may be subject to export logging operations.'
That is logging not for domestic use but for export. Mr Gray continued:
Subsequent to the Commonwealth's woodchip export licence decision on 16 December 1985 Mr Kerin has sought to extend the matters dealt with in the agreement to cover domestic operations.

Commonwealth involvement in this additional area of producing wood for purely domestic requirements is outside Federal constitutional powers, and is outside the matters discussed at officer level and on which general agreement was arrived at before 16 December.
The fact that these matters were proceeding satisfactorily is indicated in Mr Kerin's telex to me of 18 December.

By refusing to finalise the agreement, which I forwarded to him signed by me and awaiting his signature, on 9 January, Mr Kerin has placed in jeopardy the important negotiations between the companies and their Japanese customers.

This is referring to the fact that Mr Kerin will not sign the agreement on the woodchips. Mr Gray is saying that it is placing in jeopardy the important negotiations between those companies and their Japanese customers. Mr Gray continued:

The signing of the agreement is important to trade relationships between the companies and their customers, and the fact that it is not signed has placed them in an embarrassing and disadvantaged position in negotiations.
But the key point of principle is that the Federal Government is once again seeking to intrude in a domestic matter of State jurisdiction.

We have acted very responsibly to establish procedures and consultative mechanisms so that Commonwealth views can be taken into account with respect to logging operations in National Estate areas for the production of pulpwood for export as woodchips.

It is totally at odds with the Commonwealth's constitutional powers and all that has been understood and agreed between me and Mr Kerin and our officers, that the Commonwealth should now seek to interfere in domestic forestry operations in Tasmania.
That is what it boils down to; who controls domestic forestry operations in Tasmania. We are resolved that the State Government and the Forestry Commission should control Tasmania's forests.

It is now up to Mr Kerin to sign the memorandum which he has had since 9 January. We are all waiting on him . . . companies, Japanese customers and all the people whose jobs depend on a secure future for the industry.
He should sign that agreement, in accord with his previously expressed views, not to intrude into domestic forestry operations. And he should sign it as soon as possible.

That is what the Premier said. I could not agree with him more. If Mr Kerin has looked at the voting in Tasmania and feels that the Labor Party there lost the conservation vote to Dr Brown and Dr Bates and for that reason is now going back on his agreement, and if Mr Kerin thinks that that is the way to get the vote in Tasmania, he has got another think coming. It is a disgraceful way to operate. It will destroy his credibility. No one in Tasmania will ever be able to trust a Minister's word again. If the Minister does not stick to his original agreement, I believe the Labor Party in Tasmania will live to regret this ridiculous decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Walters. I am disturbed by the heading stating that a battle over constitutional rights is brewing in Tasmania because the Federal Government wants to have a say in the harvesting of timber. I believe that it is a State responsibility and each State should have control over the domestic use of its timber resources and timber harvesting. It is not the province of the Federal Government to intrude on State rights. We acknowledge that the Commonwealth has a responsibility in respect of exports.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take a few minutes to indicate to the Senate the interest of the people of Tasmania in forestry and conservation issues, because I think this is often not understood by people on the mainland. We Tasmanians have long been aware of the value of our fine hardwood forests as an industrial resource and, given the present economic climate, the importance of encouraging the development of our local industries. Regeneration and reafforestation are essential if forest-based industries are to continue in the future to represent a significant sector of the economy.

I wish to point out a number of topical issues that are of concern to both the Government and interested people within our State. We are concerned that small saw-mills are going out of business simply because there are not enough logs to go around. We are aware that the royalty income covers the recurrent costs of managing the forests. We are concerned that the Forestry Commission never has been a commercially orientated and commercially managed organisation. We are also aware that over 40 per cent of our forests are not touched as such. The State Government is concerned and is examining the volume of timber used in woodchipping. It is concerned about the manner in which and the intensity with which it is taken. It is concerned about those areas in which the woodchip companies are allowed to operate.

We now have a very highly capitalised woodchip industry which consumes most of the timber which is felled in the State. As I mentioned, we acknowledge that we have problems with an ailing saw-mill industry and we are trying to lift some of the job opportunities in forestry. A sizable number of people within the State have concerns about and interests in the environmental consequences of current forestry management.

Things are being done by the State Government. Inquiries are being held. For example, the State Government does recognise the need for a balance to be established between the demands of environmental control and economic viability. The Legislative Council inquiry into forest management advocated a revamping, for example, of the concessions system and the exercise of tighter environmental controls by the State Government, but not by the Federal Government, because the State Government is adequately equipped to handle these issues.

Another area of concern is the future and the fate of the Tasmanian rainforest stands. I must point out to the Senate that at present there is a moratorium on the logging of pure rainforests in Tasmania which will operate until 1988. The State Government recently announced that there will be an inter-departmental study to examine the question of conservation of rainforests. So the State Government-the Parliament-is taking steps to preserve the forests and to make sure that there is a proper balance between environmental concerns and the need to exploit them on the basis of a long term sustainable yield. Therefore, we will be looking to the immediate months ahead because important decisions must be made by the State and not by the Commonwealth. Decisions may be made by the Commonwealth only in relation to export industries. I am concerned about this subtle intrusion into the domestic use of timber. I am concerned about harvesting levels, conservation measures and the maintenance and expansion of employment opportunities within the industry in order that both the harvesting and the regeneration of forests will continue to accrue greater environmental and economic benefits for all Tasmanians.

The new forest practices legislation that was passed last year will assure the community that excesses of irresponsible forest operators will be curbed. Beneficial management on that scale demands close co-operation between the State and Federal governments, but not dictatorial determinations by the Federal Government. It also requires co-operation with conservation groups, the forest-based industries and the public to ensure that harvesting of our forest resources is attuned to the economic, environmental and social needs for the future of our forests.

It has been necessary for programming reasons to proceed with tender and contract developments following approval by the Joint Standing Committee of the interior design for the Senate Chamber.
